abstract.text: We have recently shown that activation of CAR, a potent transcription factor in the nuclear receptor family, reduces liver cell apoptosis and injury in a murine model, following administration of Jo2 (a Fas agonistic antibody). However, whether Con A liver injury is reduced by CAR activation remains unknown. Thus, our aim was to ascertain if the CAR agonist ligand TCPOBOP attenuates acute and chronic Con A-induced liver injury. Methods: Acute liver injury: C57/BL6 CAR wild type (CAR ϩ/ϩ ) and knock out mice (CAR -/-) were injected i.p. (3mg/kg) daily with the CAR agonist TCPOBOP or vehicle (corn oil) for 3 days. Next, mice were injected with Con A 25 mg/kg i.v. and liver injury (H&E, and serum ALT determinations) was assessed 15 hrs later. Apoptosis was determined by the TUNEL assay and immunofluorescence for activated caspase 3/7. Chronic liver injury: Mice were injected with TCPOBOP or vehicle (corn oil) i.p. weekly followed by weekly Con A i.v. injections 8 mg/kg or vehicle for 6 weeks. Liver fibrosis was assessed in sirius red stained liver sections and ␣SMA mRNA expression by RT-PCR, respectively. Results: Acute injury: Following Con A administration, serum ALT values were elevated 120-fold in CAR ϩ/ϩ vehicle and CAR -/animals vs. TCPOBOP treated CAR ϩ/ϩ animals. TUNEL positive cells and caspase 3/7 immunofluorescence was also elevated in CAR ϩ/ϩ vehicle and CAR -/animals, but not TCPOBOP-treated mice after Con A administration. Chronic injury: ␣SMA mRNA expression was decreased by approximately 50% in TCPOBOP treated CAR ϩ/ ϩanimals compared to vehicle. Sirius red staining showed marked fibrosis in liver sections from animals without TCPOBOP pretreatment. In Conclusion, these original findings support a prominent role for CAR cytoprotection against Con A mediated acute and chronic liver injury. CAR agonists may represent a novel approach for reducing liver injury and fibrosis in immune mediated liver diseases.

We have previously shown that Bid, a pro-apoptotic Bcl-2 family protein, plays an important role in TNF-␣ and anti-Fas antibody induced apoptosis in primary cultured murine hepatocytes. However, the bid-deficient hepatocytes eventually died after 24hrs although the process delayed by 6hrs compared to wild type cells after TNF-␣ treatment. This suggests that a Bid-independent pathway may contribute to the cell death after TNF-␣ treatment. In the present study, we found that the reactive oxygen species (ROS) level was lower at the early time point but increased significantly at later time points after TNF-␣ treatment in bid-deficient cells. Moreover, MnTBAP, a superoxide dismutase mimetic, significantly inhibited the cell death in both wild type and biddeficient cells, suggesting that ROS may be involved in the Bidindependent pathway. Bax, another pro-apoptotic Bcl-2 family protein, can translocate from the cytosol to the mitochondria to induce mitochondrial apoptotic factors release. Indeed, using three different approaches, GFP-tagging, immunostaining and Western blot, we observed Bax translocation following TNF-␣ treatment in both wild type and bid-deficient hepatocytes. We further found that ROS could also mediate TNF-␣-induced c-jun-N-terminal kinase (JNK) activation. Interestingly, the antioxidant MnTBAP, the mitochondria permeability transition pore inhibitor, cyclosporine A, and the JNK inhibitor, SP600125, all can inhibit Bax translocation, cytochrome c release and the subsequent caspase activation and apoptosis in both wild type and bid-deficient hepatocytes. All the above evidence suggests that ROS may play a critical role in regulation of Bax translocation and the subsequent mitochondrial dysfunction and apoptosis even in the absence of Bid in hepatocytes. The understanding of the role of ROS in the death-receptor activation induced liver injury thus may help to develop new strategies to alleviate such liver injury by using antioxidants.

In HCC, however, its direct cytotoxic activity is still controversial, and indeed, most hepatoma cell lines are resistant to IFN-mediated apoptosis in vitro. In this sense, some combination agents may be needed to overcome IFN resistance. At DDW 2005, we reported the combined anticancer effect of cyclooxygenase (COX)-2 inhibitor, NS-398, and IFN-␤ on human hepatoma cell lines. Recently it was reported that IFN induced apoptosis through up-regulating tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-related apoptosis-inducing ligand (TRAIL) even in solid tumor cells. In this study, we aimed to clarify the precise mechanism of the combined anticancer effect through TRAIL-mediated pathway and the different potential of IFN-␣ and IFN-␤ to synergy with a COX-2 inhibitor. Methods: Three human hepatoma cell lines (HepG2, PLC/PRF5, and HuH7) were employed. The growth inhibitory effect was evaluated by MTS assay. Apoptosis was observed by using DAPI and fluorescent microscopy. Caspase activity was measured using a colorimetric assay kit. Expression of apoptosis-inducing molecules such as TRAIL, death receptor (DR) 4, and DR5 was evaluated by Western blotting and realtime PCR technique. Results: Only a minimal growth inhibition was observed by a single treatment with IFN in three hepatoma cell lines. In contrast, combination treatment with NS-398 and IFN-␤ effectively inhibited the proliferation in a dose and time-dependent manner. These cytotoxic effects were recognized as apoptosis by DAPI staining. IFN-␣ showed almost same effect as IFN-␤ when administered alone, while the combined effect with NS-398 was much lower than that of IFN-␤. Treatment with IFN-␤ up-regulated both messenger RNA (mRNA) and protein levels of TRAIL in all of the hepatoma cell lines, while the increase by IFN-␣ was faint. This difference might contribute to the stronger anticancer effect by IFN-␤ and NS-398. Treatment with NS-398 up-regulated the level of DR5, and TRAIL expression was unchanged. Consequently, the combination treatment upregulated the expression of both TRAIL and DR5, and the activity of caspase-8 and -3 was dramatically enhanced. We confirmed the contribution of TRAIL to the antiproliferative effect by using neutralizing antibody against TRAIL. In HepG2, treatment with IFN-␤/NS-398 reduced the cell viability to 38.4% at 48 hours, and administration of TRAIL neutralizing antibody recovered the cell viability to 67.0%. In Conclusion, we demonstrated that IFN-␤ and NS-398 synergistically induce cell death through TRAIL /TRAIL receptors-mediated apoptotic pathway in human hepatoma cell lines.

The following authors have indicated they have no relationships to disclose: Nobuhiro Ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) inhibits classical mitochondrial pathways of apoptosis either by directly stabilizing mitochondrial membranes or modulating specific upstream targets. Furthermore, UDCA regulates apoptosis-related genes from transforming growth factor ␤1 (TGF-␤1)-induced hepatocyte apoptosis by a nuclear steroid receptor (NSR)-dependent mechanism. In this study, we further investigated the potential role of the glucocorticoid receptor (GR) in the anti-apoptotic function of UDCA. Our results with short interference RNA (siRNA) technology confirmed that UDCA significantly reduces TGF-␤1-induced apoptosis of primary rat hepatocytes through a GR-dependent effect. Immunoprecipitation assays and confocal microscopy showed that UDCA increases free GR levels with subsequent GR nuclear translocation. Interestingly, when a carboxy-terminus deleted form of GR was used, UDCA no longer induced GR/hsp90 dissociation and/or GR translocation nor protected against TGF-␤1induced apoptosis. In cotransfection experiments with GR response element reporter and overexpression constructs, UDCA reduced the transactivation of GR with TGF-␤1. Finally, using a flourescently-labeled UDCA molecule, the bile acid appeared diffuse in the cytosol but was aggregated in the nucleus of hepatocytes. Interestingly, both siRNA experiments and transfections with the carboxy-terminus deleted form of GR showed that nuclear trafficking of UDCA occurs through a GR-dependent mechanism. In conclusion, these results further clarify the antiapoptotic mechanism(s) of UDCA, and suggest that GR is crucial for the nuclear translocation of this bile acid for attenuating apoptosis. The hepatocyte growth factor/scatter factor (HGF/SF) and its receptor c-met support a pleiotrophic signal transduction pathway that controls regulation of cell survival. Previously, we have shown that mice lacking c-met in hepatocytes were hypersensitive to Fas-induced liver injury and died from fulminant hepatic failure after treatment with Jo-2 mAb that did not affect survival of wild-type mice. In the present study, we used primary cultures of hepatocytes isolated from c-Met-deficient (MetLivKO) and Alb-Cre control (AlbCre-Ctrl) mice to examine the mechanisms of hepatoprotective effects of HGF. Hepatocytes were treated with 0.5 ug/ml of Jo-2 mAb either alone or after pretreatment with rhHGF (40 ng/ml) for different time periods. MetLivKO primary hepatocytes showed reduced survival in culture and were more sensitive to Fas-induced apoptosis verified by PI staining as well as cleavage of caspase 3 and cytochrome C realease. HGF pretreatment diminished Jo-2-induced apoptosis in AlbCre-Ctrl but not in MetLivKO cells. Similarly, phosphorylation of AKT, Erk1/2, and STAT3 was detected within the first hour of HGF treatment only in AlbCre-Ctrl cells. HGF protection against apoptosis was time dependent and peaked after 6-12 h of HGF exposure. In addition, AlbCre-hepatocytes treated with HGF showed a time dependent induction of anti-apoptotic proteins including Bcl-XL, Bcl-2 and Mcl-1. We next examined the status of NF-kB. EMSA assay showed an increase in NF-kB activation in HGF treated AlbCre-Ctrl cells when compared with MetLivKO hepatocytes, moreover, the activation of NF-kB correlated with degradation of the IkB-␣ in cells treated with HGF. In order to assess the involvement of Akt, Erk1/2 and STAT3 in NF-kB activation, we pretreated the AlbCre-Ctrl hepatocytes with PI3K inhibitor worthmaninn, AKT inhibitor LY294002, MAPK inhibitor PD98059, and a peptide inhibitor of STAT3. Inhibition of PI3K and AKT abolished NF-kB activation and the anti-apoptotic effect of HGF, and was correlated with a decrease in the expression of anti-apoptotic proteins. Inhibition of STAT3 and ERK 1/2 was less effective in protection against Jo2-induced apoptosis. These findings indicate that HGF/ c-Met signaling pathway protects hepatocytes from Fas-mediated apoptosis via the AKT pathway and NF-kB activation.

Background: In acute liver failure, hepatocytes are exposed to various cytokines that activate both cell survival and apoptotic pathways. NF-kB is a central transcription factor in these responses. In inflammatory conditions, hepatocyte survival is dependent on NF-kB activation. Blocking NF-kB causes apoptosis, suggesting the existence of NF-kB regulated anti-apoptotic genes. The Bcl-2 protein family is critical in regulating cell death. This family consists of pro-and anti-apoptotic members, which together regulate the integrity of the mitochondrial membrane. Previously, we have demonstrated the cytokine-inducible, NF-kBdependent expression of the anti-apoptotic Bcl-2 family member A1 (Bfl-1) in hepatocytes. In principle, A1 is a candidate for gene therapy of liver disorders characterized by mitochondrial disruption and apoptosis. Aim: To investigate whether overexpression of A1 protects hepatocytes against apoptosis. Methods: Full length rat A1 was prepared by high-fidelity PCR and correct sequence of the rat A1 cDNA was verified (Genbank sequence AF-378332). The full-length A1 cDNA was cloned into a pCR®-Blunt II-TOPO®-plasmid. An A1 expressing recombinant adenovirus (AdA1) was constructed using the AdEasy system. Bile acid sensitive HepG2.ntcp cells were exposed to the pro-apoptotic bile acid glycochenodeoxycholic acid (GCDCA: 100 M) or TNFa (20 ng/ml) in combination with the transcriptional inhibitor actinomycin D (200 ng/ml). HepG2.ntcp cells were infected 48 hours before addition of test substances with AdA1 and AdLacZ at a MOI of 10. Adenovirus containing the lacZ gene (AdLacZ) was used as a control virus. Expression of A1 in HepG2.ntcp cells was determined by RT-PCR. Apoptosis was determined by measuring caspase-3 activity. Results: (1) A1 full length cDNA was prepared, sequenced and a recombinant adenovirus expressing A1 (AdA1) was succesfully constructed.
(2) Infection of HepG2.ntcp hepatoma cells with AdA1 resulted in overexpression of A1 compared to non-infected HepG2.ntcp cells.

(3) GCDCA strongly induced caspase-3 activity in non-infected and AdLacZ-infected HepG2.ntcp cells. Overexpression of A1 significantly reduced GCDCA induced apoptosis, but not TNF/ActD-induced apoptosis compared to control (noninfected) and AdLacZ-infected HepG2.ntcp cells.

Overexpression of A1 in HepG2.ntcp cells protects from GCDCA induced apoptosis. These results demonstrate that therapy aimed at preserving mitochondrial integrity protects hepatocytes against apoptosis.

Background: Metformin is a drug used in the treatment of diabetes mellitus type 2. In this disease, metformin improves the glucose tolerance. Furthermore, metformin treatment reduces liver injury in an experimental mouse model of non-alcoholic-fatty-liver disease (NAFLD), and in patients with NAFLD Thus, metformin is a hepatoprotective drug. The hepatoprotective mechanism of metformin has not been elucidated yet. Metformin is presumed to activate the 5'-AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK). AMPK is a cellular energy sensor that is activated in conditions that increase the AMP:ATP ratio. The AMP:ATP ratio is important in regulating apoptosis. Therefore, metformin could modulate apoptosis of hepatocytes in chronic liver diseases. Aim of the present study was to examine whether metformin is hepatoprotective via inhibition of apoptosis. Methods: Primary rat hepatocytes were exposed to the pro-apoptotic bile acid glychochenodeoxycholic acid (GCDCA: 50 M) for 4 hrs or TNFa/Actinomycin D for 6 hrs to induce apoptosis. Metformin (0.1-2 mM) was added simultaneously. AMPK was inhibited using iodotubercidin (0.1-10 m), and the AMPKdownstream target mammalian Target Of Rapamycin (mTOR) was inhibited using rapamycin (50-500 nM). Caspase-3 activation was measured with a fluorometric assay. Necrotic cell death was detected using the Sytox Green nuclear staining. Results: Both GCDCA and TNFa/ActD induced caspase-3 activation was dose-dependently reduced by metformin (25% at 0.1mM, 58% at 0.5mM; 80% at 1mM). Furthermore, the anti-apoptic effect of metformin did not result in necrosis. Neither the AMPK-inhibitor iodotubercidin nor the mTOR inhibitor rapamycin had any effect on the protective effect of metformin on GCDCA induced caspase-3 activity. Conclusion: Our results demonstrate a completely novel antiapoptotic action of metformin. Metformin protects against various forms of apoptosis in primary rat hepatocytes. However, this protective effect is independent of AMPK or mTOR, suggesting the involvement of alternative mechanisms. Furthermore, our results suggest that the hepatoprotective effect of metformin in NAFLD, studied in animal models, could be based on reduction of apoptosis. In addition, metformin could be an important treatment in liver diseases in which apoptosis plays a major role.
However, the exact mechanism by which TGF-b induces cell death is still unknown. We previously examined a potential role of various death receptor/ligand systems in TGF-b-induced apopto-

in primary human hepatozytes, strengthening the controversial point than TRAIL is not hepatotoxic. Furthermore, we have now explored the mechanism by which TGF-␤ upregulates TRAIL expression. The 5'-flanking region of the TRAIL gene was isolated and characterised. Deletion mutants of the 5'-untranslated region of the TRAIL gene revealed a region comprising nucleotides -1900 to -1100 responsible for TRAIL induction following treatment with TGF-b. Within this region we have identified an activator protein-1 (AP-1) site indispensable for TGF-␤-mediated induction of TRAIL. Mutation of the element abolishes TGF-␤ responsiveness.

We report (i) that the promoter-proximal activator protein 1 (AP1) site is essential for the response of TRAIL to TGF-b and (ii) that Smads and activator protein-1 functionally cooperate to mediate TGF-␤-induced transcriptional activation of the TRAIL gene. All together, our results provide evidence that the TRAIL system is critically involved in TGF-b-induced cell death in liver pathology.

Here, we demonstrate the in vitro and in vivo interaction between the HCV core protein with the tumor suppressor PML. We show, that these two proteins colocalise in subnuclear granular structures, PML nuclear bodies. Using a reporter assay, we show that HCV core inhibits the transcriptional activity of PML on genes involved in apoptosis regulation. Moreover, we demonstrate that HCV core is able to directely inhibit PML-induced apoptosis. Additionally, HCV core protein decreases the Ser15 phosphorylation of p53. All together, our results clearly indicate that the HCV core protein interferes with PML function: it colocalises with PML in NBs, interacts physically with this tumor suppressor protein and inhibits its apoptosis-inducing activity by interfering with PML-associated modulation of p53. This mechanism may importantly contribute to the HCV-associated pathogenesis with respect to the development of HCC as well as immune escape and persistence of infection.

Background: Onset of the mitochondrial permeability transition (MPT) causes apoptosis in liver and other tissues after ischemia/ reperfusion. Previously, we showed that anti-apoptotic XIAP (Xlinked inhibitor of apoptosis protein) decreases progressively during ischemia to cultured hepatocytes, an effect associated with increased apoptosis after reperfusion (Kim et al., Gastroenterology 2005; 128 Suppl. 2:A-708). Here, our Aim was to assess apoptosis induced by ischemia/reperfusion in hepatocytes isolated from XIAP deficient mice and after infection with an XIAP-expressing adenovirus. Methods: Cultured mouse hepatocytes were incubated in anoxic Krebs-Ringer-HEPES buffer at pH 6.2 for 0.5-3 h to simulate tissue ischemia. To simulate reperfusion, hepatocytes were reoxygenated in hormonally defined medium at pH 7.4 for 8 h with fructose and glycine to prevent necrosis. At various times, cell lysates was prepared from hepatocytes and Western blot analysis was carried out. To assess apoptosis, caspase 3 activation and morphological changes in nuclei were evaluated, respectively, by FAM-DEVD-fmk, a fluorochrome inhibitor of caspase 3 (FLICA), and propidium iodide staining. To further investigate the role of XIAP, apoptosis after 8 h of reperfusion was determined in hepatocytes isolated from XIAP-KO mice. In some experiments, XIAO-deficient hepatocytes were infected with an adenovirus encoding XIAP and then subjected to ischemia/reperfusion in the presence or absence of 2 M cyclosporin A (CsA), an MPT blocker. Results: XIAP levels progressively decreased to 41% and 12% of normoxic levels after 1 h and 3 h of ischemia to wild type hepatocytes and did not recover during reperfusion. In wild-type hepatocytes, caspase activation after reperfusion increased from 3.8% to 29.2% when ischemia was extended from 30 min to 3 h. However, in XIAP-deficient hepatocytes, 40.4% of cells showed activation of caspase 3 even after 30 min of ischemia, a greater than 10-fold enhancement of apoptosis compared to wild type. After 3 h of ischemia, 61.7% of XIAP-deficient cells were FLICApositive. Evaluation of nuclear morphology with propidium iodide confirmed substantial apoptosis in XIAP-deficient cells. Pretreatment with an XIAP-expressing adenovirus, but not a LacZ-expressing adenovirus, and reperfusion with CsA markedly suppressed caspase 3 activation in hepatocytes from XIAP-deficient mice after short periods of ischemia. Conclusion: Decreases of the anti-apoptotic protein, XIAP, sensitize hepatocytes to MPTdependent apoptosis after reperfusion. The accumulation of toxic bile acids within the hepatocyte is a primary factor in the pathogenesis of cholestatic liver injury. Mitochondrial (mito) pathways involved in cell death have been implicated in this process, including induction of the mito permeability transition (MPT), generation of reactive oxygen species, reduced ATP production and release of pro-apoptotic pro-teins such as cytochrome c. The role of these mito pathways in neonatal liver injury has not been evaluated. This is important because the neonate is particularly susceptible to cholestatic injury which is associated with predominantly necrotic rather than apoptotic hepatocyte death. Therefore, the objective of this study was to test the hypothesis that there are developmental differences in mito pathways of hepatocyte cell death. Methods: Hepatic mitos were isolated by differential centrifugation from adult male Sprague-Dawley rats, or pooled livers from 6, 10,21 and 36 day old male rats. Electron microscopy was performed on glutaraldehydefixed mitos, and content of specific proteins relevant to the MPT were analyzed by immunoblotting. To quantitated bile acid-induced MPT, mito swelling was measured by absorbance at 540 nm during 5 minutes exposure of succinate-energized mitos to graded concentrations (0-500M) of glycochenodeoxycholic acid (GCDC) and expressed as ⌬OD/5 min. After the MPT experiment, remaining mito cytochrome c content was determined. Results: At a concentration of 50M GCDC, adult rat liver mitos underwent an extensive MPT (⌬ODϭ0.56Ϯ0.01) when compared with neonatal mitos (⌬ODϭ0.06Ϯ0.02, 0.08Ϯ0.04, 0.12Ϯ0.01, and 0.20Ϯ0.05 for 6, 10, 21 and 36 day old rats, respectively). Similar patterns of agerelated induction of MPT were observed for GCDC at 25-500M. MPT was inhibited by cyclosporine A (Ն98%) in rats of all ages, implying an intact cyclophilin pathway. GCDC-induced release of mito cytochrome c paralleled the extent of MPT. Basal mito levels of MPT pore proteins, VDAC and ANT, were similar in all ages of rats, whereas cytochrome c and BCL-XL increased with age. Ultrastructure of hepatic mitos revealed similar size and morphology at all ages. Conclusions: Neonatal rat liver mitos are relatively resistant to bile acid induced MPT, undergoing an MPT only at high GCDC concentrations. Mito morphology and levels of ANT, VDAC, BCL-XL, and cytochrome C do not explain this finding. Thus the neonate is protected against bile acid induced hepatocyte injury by an as yet unknown mechanism inhibiting the MPT. Disclosures: The following authors have indicated they have no relationships to disclose: Ronald Sokol, Rolf Dahl, Michael Devereaux, Eric Gumpricht, Jason Soden 778 AN ACTIVATED PI3-KINASE/AKT PATHWAY EXERTS PRO-SURVIVAL AND ANTI-APOPTOTIC EFFECTS IN PRIMARY MOUSE CIRRHOTIC HEPATOCYTES Takashi Nitta, UNC at Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC Background: Primary cirrhotic mouse hepatocytes resist TGFƒÒinduced apoptosis, in part, through a ROS-dependent mechanism (J Hepatology 40:942, 2004). However, the PI3-Kinase/Akt pathway is a well-documented, alternative pro-survival or anti-apoptotic pathway that may alter TGF␤-induced Smad signaling and, thereby, affect apoptosis. Aims: The two-fold aims are: (1) To determine if the PI3-Kinase/ Akt pathway is up-regulated in cirrhotic hepatocytes, and, if so, whether inhibition influences apoptosis, and (2) To assess inhibition of the PI3-Kinase/Akt pathway and related changes in the Smad signaling pathway. Methods: Cirrhosis was induced in BALB/c mice by twice-weekly injections of 50% CCl4 for 8 weeks. P-Akt expression in the cirrhotic liver was assessed by immunohistochemistry and immunoblots of liver lysates. Primary hepatocytes were pre-treated with the PI3-Kinase inhibitor, LY294002, prior to TGF␤ administration. Immunoblots for total Smad2 and 3, p-Smad2 and 3, total Akt, and p-Akt were performed. Apoptosis was determined morphologically by Hoescht stain and biochemically by fluorescent caspase-3 activity. Results: Immunohistochemistry revealed that p-Akt was consistently up-regulated in cirrhotic, but not in normal, livers. These findings were confirmed by immunoblots that uniformily demonstrated increased p-Akt expression in cirrhotic liver lysates. TGF␤ treatment (5 ng/ml) induced p-Smad2, p-Smad3, and p-Akt in both normal and cirrhotic hepatocytes. P-Akt expression in normal and cirrhotic hepatocytes was independent of insulin concentration in the medium. Pretreatment of hepatocytes for 1 hour with LY294002 inhibited TGF␤-stimulated p-Akt expression in a dose-dependent manner. Furthermore, in cirrhotic hepatocytes only, PI3-Kinase inhibition decreased Smad2 signaling at 6 hours. HEPATOLOGY, Vol. 42, No. 4, Suppl. 1, 2005 AASLD ABSTRACTS 501A Total Smad2 and Smad3 expression were unaffected. Additionally, treatment of cirrhotic hepatocytes with 25 M LY294002 alone resulted in increased apoptosis and caspase-3 activity which was further enhanced by the addition of TGF␤. Conclusion: The PI3-Kinase/Akt pathway is up-regulated in cirrhotic mouse liver. Inhibition of this pathway in unstimulated cirrhotic hepatocytes increases apoptosis suggesting that PI3-Kinase/Akt has an insulin-independent pro-survival effect. Furthermore, PI3-Kinase/Akt inhibition in cirrhotic hepatocytes enhanced TGF␤-induced apoptosis despite decreased p-Smad2 expression implying that PI3-Kinase also has an anti-apoptotic effect and that TGF␤-induced apoptosis may occur through a non-Smad2-dependent pathway in cirrhotic hepatocytes. Background: Na accumulates in hepatocytes during hypoxic and toxic cell injury, and low Na medium decreases cell killing (Carini et al., BBRC 1995; 206: 180-1852). The mechanisms of protection may be prevention of uncontrolled osmotic swelling or inhibition of intracellular alkalinization by Na/H exchange. Accordingly, the AIM of this study was to characterize the role of Na, pH and cellular swelling in the pathogenesis of hypoxic injury to isolated perfused rat livers. Methods and Results: When livers were perfused with hypoxic Krebs-Henseleit bicarbonate buffer (KHB) containing 143 mM Na, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) release began after 30 min and was maximal after 60 min. In livers perfused with choline-substituted low Na (25 mM) KHB, LDH release was delayed and began after 60 min and peaked after 120 min or longer. Trypan blue nuclear labeling confirmed protection by low Na KHB. The following authors have indicated they have no relationships to disclose: Domenico Introduction: Chronic viral hepatitis causes irreversible liver damage and hepatocellular carcinoma. Regeneration factors of the host organism, which are expressed to reconstitute the damaged hepatocyte population, might contribute to malignant cell transformation. To address this question we first, examined the serum levels of regeneration factors (HGF and EGF) during viral hepatitis. To unravel the role of regeneration factors in viral associated carcinogenesis, we examined the influence of HGF and EGF on HEPATOLOGY, Vol. 42, No. 4, Suppl. 1, 2005 AASLD ABSTRACTS 503A
CD95-dependant apoptosis and searched for concomitant structural changes of primary human hepatocytes (PHH).

Western Blot analysis, Immunflourescence and caspase activity assays in vitro. Further observations of PHH changes were performed by FACScan and confocal microscopy. Results: Patients chronically infected with hepatitis virus show high serum concentrations of EGF and HGF. In contrast healthy controls contain significantly lower serum levels of these growth factors. Sensitivity of PHH cultures against CD95-dependant apoptosis was reduced by a combined exposure to EGF and HGF. The analysed signal cascades in PHH where characterized by a reduced activation of caspase-3 and caspase-8. After short term EGF/HGF-exposure we observed activation of Akt-kinase and Stat3. EGF and HGF promoted adhesion to collagen and an apoptosis resistant phenotype. The enhanced adhesion could be attributed to beta-integrin induction by HGF and EGF. The new cellular phenotype paralleled both beta-1-Integrin expression and accumulation of focal adhesions. Discussion: Compensatory regeneration programs of the liver are induced during viral infections and protect against apoptotic cell elimination. Inhibition of apoptosis contributes to the survival of infected host cells and therefore indicates a mechanism of viral immune evasion. Moreover, persisting changes of the cellular matrix, which are associated with hepatocyte regeneration or rescue, might be part of sequential events responsible for malignant cell transformation during chronic hepatitis.

Background: FXR (NR1H4) is a member of the group I nuclear receptor superfamily. Two major forms of FXR,a and b, have been identified in mammals that share significant sequence identity, especially in the DNA binding domain (DBD). The a form, which is activated by bile acids (CDCA), regulates key genes involved in bile acid synthesis and transport. However, the b form in mouse is not activated by CDCA, but rather by lanosterol, a precursor of cholesterol. The structure/function relationship of the ligand binding domain (LBD) and its promiscuous ligand specificity are still unknown. Aim: To further elucidate the receptor/ligand structure relationship of FXR by identifying and characterizing an evolutionarily primitive Fxr from the marine skate, Leucoraja erinacea, whose predominate bile salt is scymnol sulfate, a sulfated bile alcohol. Methods: PCR, 5' and 3' RACEs were used to identify the skate Fxr (sFxr) gene. A Dual-luciferase assay was applied for functional characterization by co-transfecting sFxr with the human ileal bile acid binding protein (hI-BABP) promoter in a pGL3-basic vector into HEK293 cells. In parallel, human FXRa (hFXRa) was also tested and compared with sFxr. Results: The full length sFxr gene encodes for 518 amino acids. Sequence alignment shows that sFxr shares overall 57% identity to hFXRa, but 60% and 91% identity in the LBD and DBD, respectively. sFxr shows overall 52% identity to mouse Fxrb, but 53% and 92% identity in the LBD and DBD, respectively. A phylogenetic analysis places sFxr between a and b forms of FXR. Luciferase reporter assays demonstrate that sFxr activates hI-BABP promoter 30 times over vector control, indicating that the DBD of sFxr can bind to the IR-1 response element in the hI-BABP gene. Addition of 9-cis retinoic acid stimulates sFxr activity further, suggesting that sFxr forms a heterodimer with human RXR to activate this promoter. Both CDCA and scymnol sulfate activate hFXRa and sFxr in a dose dependent manner, but to a much lesser extent for sFxr than hFXRa. Lanosterol failed to stimulate either sFxr or hFXRa.

Bile canalicular formation is essential for biliary secretion and is disrupted in cholestasis. Many components, including cytoskeletal elements and motor molecules, are proposed to participate in canalicular biogenesis; however, their specific requirement is unknown. Two distinct routes are utilized for delivery of membrane proteins to the canaliculus. Proteins having GPI anchors or single transmembrane domains are targeted to the sinusoidal plasma membrane from where they transcytose to the canalicular domain (1, 2). In contrast, canalicular ATP-binding-casette (ABC) transporters, which are required for energy-dependent biliary secretion of bile acids (ABCB11), phospholipids (ABCB4) and nonbile acid organic anions (ABCC2), lack initial residence in the sinusoidal plasma membrane and traffic directly from Golgi to the canalicular membrane (3, 4). While investigating mechanisms of canalicular targeting in WIF-B9 cells, a polarized hepatic cell line (5), we observed that rab11a and myosin Vb are required for canalicular biogenesis. Depleting rab11a by RNA interference or overexpression of rab11a dominant negative form prevented canalicular formation. Overexpression of myosin vb motorless tail domain that acts as dominant negative inhibitor of rab11a positive endosome sorting also prevented canalicular formation. In exploring the basis for these effects, we observed distribution of canalicular ABC transporters. Prior to canalicular formation, canalicular ABC transporters colocalized with transcytotic membrane proteins in rab11a positive endosomes and, unlike the transcytotic membrane proteins, did not distribute to the plasma membrane.

We propose that polarization of hepatocytes (ie, canalicular biogenesis) requires recruitment of rab11a and myosin Vb to intracellular membranes which contain canalicular ABC transporters and transcytotic membrane proteins permitting their targeting to the plasma membrane. In this model, polarization is initiated upon delivery of rab11a-myosin Vb-containing endosomes to the surface which causes plasma membrane at the site of delivery to differentiate into the bile canaliculus. Cholestasis is likely to result from inheritable and acquired defects in these processes.

Mammalian hepatic cytochromes P450 (P450s) are endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-anchored hemoproteins engaged in the metabolism of numerous xeno-and endobiotics. P450s constitute 5-10% of the ER content, exhibit widely ranging half-lives, and utilize both lysosomal and ubiquitin-dependent 26S proteasomal (Ub/ 26S) pathways for degradation. Although the degradation of suicidally inactivated CYPs 3A in isolated hepatocytes and of "native" CYP3A4 in S. cerevisiae occurs via the Ub/26S pathway, the physiological turnover mechanism of hepatic CYPs 3A in their native form has not yet been elucidated, largely because of a lack of a suitable experimental model. Herein, we characterize the degradation of native CYPs 3A in cultured rat hepatocytes, seeded on type I collagen coated plates and overlaid with Matrigel. CYPs 3A were induced by dexamethasone (5 mM) treatment. To examine the specific route of CYP3A degradation in these cultured hepatocytes, proteasomal (MG-132 and MG-262) and lysosomal [NH4Cl and 3-methyladenine (3-MA)] inhibitors were used. Pulse-chase analyses followed by 35S-CYP3A protein immunoprecipitation (IP) revealed a basal 52% loss of 35S-CYP3A, which was stabilized by the inclusion of proteasomal inhibitors MG-262 and MG-132 (35S-CYP3A levels of 91 Ϯ 35% and 76 Ϯ 22%, respectively). By contrast, no corresponding stabilization of CYP3A was detected with either lysosomal inhibitor NH4Cl (52 Ϯ 12%) or 3-MA (50 Ϯ 10%). Furthermore, this MG-262-induced CYP3A stabilization was associated with a high molecular weight CYP3A protein ladder extending between 55-200 kDa indicative of CYP3A polyubiquination, which was indeed confirmed by immunoblotting (IB) analyses of CYP3A immunoprecipitates with anti-Ub IgGs. These studies thus verified that native CYPs 3A were also degraded by the Ub/26S pathway. To identify the other cellular participants involved in this pathway, cross-linking experiments were performed with paraformaldehyde (PFA). Similar IB analyses of CYP3A immunoprecipitates after PFA-cross-linking revealed the presence of p97, a cytosolic AAA ATPase instrumental in the delivery of ubiquitinated ER proteins for proteasome degradation. p97-CYP3A interactions was increased following suicidal inactivation of CYP3A, an event known to accelerate the Ub/26S degradation of hepatic CYPs 3A. Preliminary proteomic analyses confirmed these results. These findings thus reveal that in common with the suicidally inactivated species and CYP3A4 in yeast, native CYPs 3A also undergo Ub/26S proteasomal degradation and for the first time implicate a role for p97 in this process. Background and Aims: We previously reported that endothelin (ET)-1 may be involved in the contraction of hepatic sinusoidal endothelial fenestrae (SEF). Rho has emerged as an important regulator of the actin cytoskeleton and consequently cell morphology. To clarify the role of endothelin receptors in ET-1 induced contraction of SEF, we studied the size of hepatic SEF under various experimental conditions. Methods: Liver sinusoidal endothelial cells (SECs) isolated from rat livers by collagenase infusion method were cultured and divided into five groups: control, ET-1 (10-7 to 10-10 M)-treated, ET-1 ϩ selective ET-A receptor antagonist (BQ610)-treated, ET-1 ϩ ET-B receptor antagonist (BQ788)treated, and ET-1 ϩ Bosentan-treated groups. SEF morphology was observed by scanning electron microscopy. F-actin stress fiber formation was observed by confocal microscopy. Rho A and phosphorylated myosin light chain kinase were analyzed by Western blotting. Active Rho was measured by Ren's modification. Intracellular free Ca2ϩ concentration ([Ca2ϩ]i) was measured by fluorescence digital imaging using fura-2 AM by Aqua Cosmos (Hamamastu). Each experiment was based on the observation of 600 fenestrae (15 to 20 fenestrae per cell, 20 cells per dish, 10 dishes). We also investigated the ET receptors in SECs by confocal fluorescence microscopy and Western blot. Results: Endothelin B receptor (ETBR) antagonist and Bosentan pretreatment abolished SEF contraction induced by low ET-1 concentrations (10ᮀ|8 to10ᮀ|10 M), whereas endothelin A receptor (ETAR) antagonist pretreatment did not block SEF contraction at low to high endothelin concentrations (10ᮀ|5 to10ᮀ|10 M). F-actin stress fibers and Rho A levels were similar in control and various treatment conditions. Phosphorylated myosin light chain kinase levels remained the same in various treatments. Active Rho was not detected in control and various treatments. ET treatment led to an increase in[Ca2ϩ]I after 20 min. ET-1-induced increase in [Ca2ϩ]i was partially blocked by BQ610 and Bosentan, but not by BQ788. Confocal microscopy depicted prominent ETBR-positive aggregates in the cytoplasmic periphery of SECs. Western blot showed prominent ETBR but scarce ETAR protein expression in SECs.

The present findings demonstrated that both ETBR and ETAR are not involved in SEF contraction induced by over 10-8 M of ET-1, and Rho is also not activated. Therefore ET-1 may induce aggregation of hepatic sinusoidal endothelial fenestrae rather than contraction.

A cDNA arrays analysis of gene expression profiles of cirrhotic tissues, macronodules and HCCs pointed us to focus on Klf6, a zinc finger transcription factor. We observed that Klf6 mRNA expression was up-regulated in HCCs as compared to macronodules. Inactivating mutations of this gene (exon 2) have been reported in many human solid tumors by other authors. Klf6 is thus described as a potential tumor suppressor gene in epithelial carcinomas. Background/Aims: Despite biochemical, cell biological, and genetic advances, how intracellular cytoskeleton and signaling proteins connect and communicate with extracellular matrix (ECM) remains a fundamental question. To address the question of which genes are influenced in hepatocytes in response to Engelbreth-Holm-Swarm (EHS) gel, a model of the basement membrane matrix, we used cDNA microarray and studied the relationship with cytoskeleton and cell differentiation. Methods: Isolated rat hepatocytes were cultured on type I collagen or EHS gel. The fluorescently labeled cDNA was applied to a microarray glass containing 3,757 supplied clones and hybridized. Changes in mRNAs were analyzed by Northern blot. Hepatocytes were stained with FITC-conjugated phalloidin. Results: When hepatocytes were cultured on EHS gels, they retained the normal cell polarity and structure, and maintained liver-specific gene transcript compared with hepatocytes on type I collagen. By cDNA microarray, genes involved in cell signaling and metabolism were induced by EHS gel, and genes involved in gene/protein expression and cell structure were suppressed by EHS gel. We focused on 21 genes in cell signaling and 6 down-regulated genes in cell structure. After careful examination of the 27 genes, we found two important genes, phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PI(4,5)P2) phosphatase and cofilin, which are respectively associated with actin polymerization and depolymerization. Using Northern blot analysis, phosphatidylinositol 4-phosphate (PI(4)P) 5-kinase mRNA, by which PI(4)P is converted to PI(4,5)P2, was decreased by EHS gel, indicating that EHS gel could affect the level of PI(4,5)P2 in cultured hepatocytes. In fact, hepatocytes cultured on EHS gel exhibited a decreased level of PI(4,5)P2 staining. The level of intracellular actin filament (F-actin) was totally suppressed in hepatocytes cultured on EHS gel, but not in hepatocytes cultured on type I collagen. After the treatment with PI(4,5)P2, F-actin increased and albumin mRNA decreased in hepatocytes on EHS gel. In contrast, the treatment with gelsolin that induces actin depolymerization had the level of F-actin suppressed and albumin mRNA increased in hepatocytes cultured on collagen. Conclusion: Our results showed that cell adhesion to the ECM induces changes in the assembly of actin filament through an actin-binding protein, PI(4,5)P2. These changes in cytoskeletal filament assembly that occur following cell attachment to the ECM and/or alterations in the pattern of actin-binding proteins played crucial roles in the determination of the differential phenotype of hepatocytes.

The failure to meet these requirements has prevented the development of a reliable liver cell culture system. The aim of this study was to further evaluate this co-culture strategy and to determine the impact of mimicking normal cell/ matrix interactions by co-culturing on a micro-porous poly(DLlactic acid) scaffold. Methods: Primary rat hepatocytes and HSCs were co-cultured on a mono-layer of poly(DL-lactic acid) to form spheroids. VA StarD5, a member of the StarD4 subfamily of START domain proteins, like other START domain proteins it is capable of binding cholesterol as well as uniquely binding the potent regulatory oxysterol, 25-hydroxycholesterol. Although recently localized to Kupffer cells, its function remains unknown. Objective: To further characterize this newly discovered sterol binding protein by determining its cellular/subcellular localization, cholesterol transport capabilities, and expression in different cell types. Methods: Western analysis and immunohisto/cytochemistry were performed to characterize StarD5's cellular localization. Increased intracellular expression of StarD5 was achieved using a recombinant adenovirus encoding human StarD5. Subcellular fractions were obtained to characterize the directional movement of cholesterol by StarD5. Results: Hepatocytes represent the equivalent of StarD5 knockout cells, lacking detectable StarD5 protein. Overexpression of StarD5 in 1 o hepatocytes led to the detection of StarD5 in the cytosol and Golgi with an associated marked increase in only microsomal free-cholesterol; total cell cholesterol was unchanged.

StarD5 was also detected in the following human inflammatory cells: monocytes, macrophages, mast cells, basophils, and promyelocitic cells. Markedly increased StarD5 levels were found within human hepatocellular carcinomas as compared to normal liver tissue. Immunocytochemistry placed this increased protein within CD68 (i.e. Kupffer-like) positive cells. StarD5 was not found in other tested human cells (i.e 1 o human hepatocytes, HepG2 cells, endothelial cells, fibroblasts, brain tissue, or osteocytes). Immunocytochemistry of macrophages localized StarD5 intracellularly to intense Golgi staining with a more diffuse cytosolic pattern. Interestingly, cellular fractionation studies only showed the detection of StarD5 within the cytosolic fraction, suggesting a loose association of StarD5 with the Golgi membrane. Conclusions: The presence of StarD5, previously described as widely distributed, can be ascribed to its localization within inflammatory associated cells. Subcellular localization of StarD5 to the Golgi and cytoplasm, its selective binding of 25hydroxycholesterol/cholesterol, and the increase in free-cholesterol within microsomal fractions after expression in hepatocytes, led us to hypothesize StarD5 as a 'regulatory sterol' transporter within the cell; one with Golgi targeting. Furthermore, its presence within inflammatory cells and its selective sterol binding abilities, suggest an important role for StarD5 in cholesterol homeostais related with immune inflammatory associated processes (atherogenesis/cancer).

Increased rates of apoptosis have been reported to play a role in the pathophysiology of many disorders, including liver diseases. Conversely, genetic mutations which result in impairment of programmed cell death have been associated with cancer development. However, apoptosis resistance can also be the result of non-genetic stress adaptation as seen in the cancer-prone metabolic liver disease hereditary tyrosinemia (HT1). To clarify whether stress induced apoptosis resistance is a more common feature of chronic liver diseases an animal model of chronic cholestasis was examined. Studies were performed with mice before and two weeks following bile duct ligation and with Fah-/-and Fah/p21-/-mice before and after NTBC withdrawal. Here we show that bile-duct ligation induced profound resistance against Fas mAb-mediated hepatocyte death. The apoptosis-signaling pathway was blocked downstream of caspase-8 activation and proximal to mitochondrial cytochrome C release. In controls, activation of the Fas receptor resulted in rapid dephosphorylation of Bid and its subsequent cleavage, whereas Bid remained phosphorylated and uncleaved in chronic cholestasis. To determine the significance of the alterations of Bid phosphorylation seen here in BDL mice, we wondered whether a similar pattern was present in other liver models. Resistance against apoptosis seen in HT1 does not occur in mice which are doubly mutant in the gene responsible for HT1, Fah, and the cell cycle regulatory protein p21/Cip/Waf. Fah/p21-/-mice develop a similar liver damage as WT mice following Fas mAb injection. Phosphorylation of Bid was not different in Fah-/-/p21-/-and Fah-/-mice before Fas mAb injection. Importantly however, Bid was not dephosphorylated in the apoptosis resistant Fah-/-mutants but almost completely dephosphorylated in the apoptosis competent Fah-/-/p21-/-double mutant mice following Fas mAb injection. In summary, our data show that resistance against apoptosis is a common feature of chronic liver diseases such as HT-1 and chronic cholestasis. In terms of evolution, this can be viewed as an adaptive response, allowing survival during chronic liver injury. However, survival might come at a price, because hepatocytes can retain DNA damage and become malignantly transformed. We propose therefore a model in which phosphorylation/dephosphorylation of Bid determines the apoptotic threshold of hepatocytes during chronic liver diseases. Understanding the changes in apoptosis sensitivity during chronic diseases might help to reduce the long-term risk of cancer development.

body_text.text: Until now, we have been investigating the pathogenesis and significance of the intermediate filament inclusions by transfection of mutant cytokeratin (CK) 18 or treatment with proteasome inhibitors (Hanada S et al. Exp Cell Res 304;2005, and unpublished data). Mallory bodies, the hepatocyte cytosolic inclusions composed of CKs, ubiquitin and heat shock proteins (HSPs), are observed in many liver diseases, however, the precise mechanism and significance of these structures are poorly understood. The endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is the organelle responsible for proper folding and delivery of proteins to the secretory pathway. One central regulator of this process is the quality control machinery, which contains a sophisticated protein proofreading and elimination of the unfolded proteins. Therefore, failure of this function leads to increase of the defective proteins in the cell and may result in the formation of inclusion bodies. Recently, it has been considered that oxidative stress influences the pathogenesis and progression of many liver diseases including viral hepatitis, alcoholic liver injury and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. In this study, we examined whether the oxidative stress induced the ER stress in a cultured human hepatoma cell line (Huh7 cells). Moreover, we examined the effect of oxidative stress on localization of CKs, ubiquitin and HSPs. Treatment with exogenous glucose oxidase resulted in the continuous oxidative stress to the cultured cells (Tirosh A et al. J Biol Chem 274;1999), and phosphorylated PERK, which is one of the hallmarks of the ER stress, was upregulated in the Western blotting. Under this condition, CK inclusion formation appeared near the nuclei in the immunofluorescent analyses. These inclusions were localized at gamma-tubulin, a marker of microtubule organizing center as well. Moreover, HSP 70, 90 and ubiquitin were redistributed to the CK inclusions. We showed for the first time that oxidative stress affects the formation of the CK inclusions in cultured cells and this influence may be through induction of the ER stress. We also speculate that Mallory body formation occurs under the continuous oxidative stress condition.

body_text.text: Introduction: The ileal basolateral bile acid transporter, OST␣-OST␤, is thought to be responsible for bile acid efflux in ileum and other apical sodium-dependent bile acid transporter (ASBT) expressing tissues. Little is known of the transcriptional regulation of the basolateral transporter, although results from ASBT null mice suggested a positive regulation by bile acids. Methods/Results: The 5Ј flanking regions of mOST␣ (1.7 and 1.2kb) and mOST␤ (3.0 and 0.9 kb) were subcloned into a luciferase reporter. The 1.7 kb mOST␣ encoded potential cis-elements for both liver receptor homologue-1 (LRH-1) and farnesoid X receptor (FXR) whereas mOST␤ 1.2 only encoded the LRH-1 site. mOST␤ 3.0 and 0.9kb encoded both LRH-1 and FXR sites. Promoter constructs were transiently transfected into CT-26 mouse intestinal cells, that endogenously express mOST␣-␤ and ASBT mRNA. Following CDCA treatment, endogenous expression of mOST␣ and ␤ mRNA were induced and ASBT was repressed. CDCA treatment of transfected CT-26 cells led at least 4-fold increases in the activities of mOST␣ 1.7kb and both mOST␤ constructs, whereas mOST␣ 1.2kb activity decreased 73%. Co-transfection of FXR enhanced the bile acid response of mOST␣ 1.7kb and both mOST␤ constructs. CDCA activation of mOST␣ 1.7kb was abrogated by a dominant negative FXR or siRNA-knockdown of FXR; mutation of the potential FXRE in mOST␣ 1.7kb reduced basal promoter activity and eliminated the bile acid response. Reducing endogenous FXR activity using siRNA knockdown of the familial intrahepatic cholestasis-1 (FIC1) gene reduced endogenous mOST␣ and ␤ mRNA expression, while increasing ASBT mRNA expression in CT-26 cells. FIC1 knock-down also reduced the activity of the mouse OST␣1.7kb promoter construct. Cotransfection of SHP decreased basal promoter activity of all four constructs, whereas SHP siRNA (siSHP) increased promoter activity. siSHP in the presence of CDCA showed enhanced promoter activation in all except the mOST␣ 1.2kb construct. Cotransfection of LRH-1 increased mOST␣ and mOST␤ promoter activity, while the opposite was seen in siLRH-1 co-transfection. Mutation of the LRH cis element in mOST␣ 1.7kb promoter abrogated siSHP mediated increase in promoter activity. Conclusions: The mOST␣ and ␤ promoters contain functional FXR and LRH elements, that mediate positive and negative feedback regulation by bile acids. The positive response to bile acids is dominant. The physiologic consequences of both responses are not yet known, but may permit fine regulation of bile acid efflux. The profound diarrhea seen in FIC1 disease may be partly explained by enhanced expression of ASBT in the setting of reduced OST␣-OST␤.

body_text.text: Background: Bile acid (BA) homeostasis is maintained by BA synthesis and enterohepatic transport. The key regulator is farnesoid X receptor (FXR), which is one of RXR-heterodimer dependent nuclear receptors and acts as a sensor of intracellular bile acids including chenodeoxycholic acid (CDCA). FXR activates the transcription of bile salt excretory pump (BSEP), small heterodimer partner (SHP) and ileal BA-binding protein (I-BABP) genes, which play important roles in BA synthesis and transport. However, the transcriptional regulation of these FXR-induced gene expression has not been fully clarified and there is considerable cross-talk among the nuclear receptor signaling pathways. Recently, we have shown the inhibition of FXR-induced BSEP gene expression by ligand-activated vitamin D receptor (VDR). Therefore, the aim of the present study was to determine whether VDR could influence the transcriptional regulation of the other FXR-induced gene expression as well. Methods: CV-1 cells were co-transfected with an expression plasmid for rat FXR and a luciferase-based reporter gene containing the promoter regions of the human BSEP (-165 to ϩ8), SHP (-332 to ϩ10), or mouse I-BABP (-1031 to ϩ40) gene. The FXR transactivation assays were performed with or without the transfection of expression plasmids for human VDR or the other RXR-partners including RAR-alpha, TR-beta1, LXR-alpha, and mouse PPAR-gamma in the presence or absence of the corresponding specific ligands. The in vitro protein-protein binding assays were performed using FXR fusion protein to glutathione S-transferase (GST). Real-time PCR was performed to quantitate mRNA levels of BSEP and SHP in HepG2 cells and I-BABP in Caco2 cells. Results: VDR inhibited the CDCA-induced FXR transactivation of the three reporter constructs (BSEP, SHP and I-BABP) in the presence of 1, 25-hydroxyvitamin D3 (VitD), but not in the absence of VitD (maximal inhibition of 51%, 67%, and 88%, respectively; pϽ0.05). Similar inhibitory effects were not seen with the other RXR-partners tested. In vitro translated VDR directly bound to GST-FXR. VitD diminished the CDCA-induced upregulation of BSEP, SHP and I-BABP mRNA expression (maximal inhibition of 66%, 58%, and 62%, respectively; pϽ0.05).

body_text.text: Background: PC-TP is a phosphatidylcholine binding protein that is highly enriched in liver, but its physiological function remains incompletely understood. Recent studies have shown that PC-TP expression is potently upregulated by peroxisome proliferator activated receptor ␣ (PPAR␣), which regulates the adaptive response of hepatic triglyceride (TG) homeostasis to fasting. Aim: To explore the role of PC-TP in hepatic TG metabolism and its response to PPAR␣ activation. Methods: Eight week old male wild type (WT) and Pctp -/-(KO) mice on an FVB/NJ genetic background were fed for 7 d with chow (WT, nϭ7; KO, nϭ8) or chow supplemented (0.2%) with the PPAR␣ agonist fenofibrate (WT, nϭ8; KO, nϭ8). Mice were fasted for 4 h and then sacrificed. Hepatic TG concentrations in liver (mg/g) were measured enzymatically. Plasma concentrations of TG (mg/dl) and ␤-hydroxybutyrate (mM) were quantified using standard assays. Using separate groups of mice fed 7 d with chow (WT, nϭ8; KO, nϭ6) or fenofibrate (WT, nϭ6; KO, nϭ6), rates of hepatic TG secretion (mg/kg/ hr) were determined from serial measurements of plasma TG following i.v. administration of the lipoprotein lipase inhibitor, Triton WR1339. Results: In chow fed mice, the absence of PC-TP expression was associated with a 62% greater concentration (meanϮSEM) of hepatic TG (WT, 7.3Ϯ0.5; KO, 11.8Ϯ1.6). Neither plasma concentration of TG (WT, 89Ϯ13; KO, 65Ϯ17) nor ␤-hydroxybutyrate (WT, 0.33Ϯ0.05; KO, 0.30Ϯ0.03), which reflect rates of hepatic fatty acid oxidation, was influenced by PC-TP expression. However, hepatic TG secretion rates were 34% higher in KO mice (WT, 76Ϯ5; KO, 102Ϯ5). In WT mice, fenofibrate feeding increased both hepatic TG concentrations and secretion rates by 2 fold, without influencing plasma concentrations of TG or ␤-hy-droxybutyrate. By contrast, fenofibrate feeding to KO mice did not change TG concentrations in liver or plasma and increased hepatic TG secretion more modestly (1.5 fold). These changes were accompanied by a 43% reduction in plasma ␤-hydroxybutyrate concentration. Conclusions: In chow fed KO mice, elevated hepatic TG concentrations and secretion rates in the absence of reduced fatty acid oxidation indicate that PC-TP expression limits either de novo lipogenesis or the supply of plasma-derived fatty acids. Moreover, unaltered plasma TG concentrations in KO mice imply that PC-TP also reduces peripheral utilization or storage. Impaired fatty acid oxidation in fenofibrate fed KO mice is compensated by further upregulation of hepatic TG secretion. We speculate that defective regulation of TG metabolism by PC-TP may contribute to the pathogenesis of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

body_text.text: Methods: Bile duct ligation (BDL) was used in single (FXRKO and PXRKO) and double knockout (P/FXRKO) 8-week old male mice, as a model of acute cholestasis. They were sacrificed after 6 days, and serum and tissue samples collected to measure serum lipids, LFTs, and histology, with quantitative morphometric analysis of necrosis. RNA was prepared and RT-PCR used to evaluate expression of genes involved in cholesterol and bile acid metabolism, and transport. Individual bile acids were quantitated using LC/MS. Results: FXRKO mice had a mortality and morbidity advantage after BDL. PXRKO mice had more extensive areas of liver injury (17%) than WT mice (3.3%), as we have previously demonstrated (1). However, FXRKO mice had a reduction in area of bile infarcts (0.6%), and the P/FXRKO genotype also had a marked reduction in liver injury compared to PXRKO. FXRKO mice had a biphasic lipid profile after BDL, with an increase in HDL cholesterol and triglycerides by day 6, and expression of apoAV was reduced in these mice. Expression of peroxisome proliferator-activator-coactivator 1alpha (PGC-1alpha) and phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK) were both regulated by FXR, implicating a pivotal role for this NR in gluconeogenesis and energy homeostasis. Induction of both Mdr1 and Mdr2, crucial drug and phospholipid transporters, was also found to be regulated by FXR, and not PXR, as had previously been suggested in the literature. Conclusions: FXR co-ordinately regulates a broad range of metabolic pathways, including bile acid synthesis and transport, lipoprotein and lipid metabolism, and hepatic gluconeogenesis. In addition, we found that manipulation of multiple NRs offers greater potential for therapeutic intervention in cholestasis. These nuclear receptors may represent therapeutic targets for the treatment of cholestasis and common metabolic disorders.

body_text.text: Introduction: Anti-cholesterol antibodies (ACHA) are natural antibodies against the 3beta-OH group of free cholesterol. Binding to LDL/VLDL has been reported, but not to the cell membranes. High level ACHA was reported in SLE, HIV and hepatitis C infected patients. ACHA is subject of recent research in atherosclerosis. Hypercholesterolaemia is common in PBC, although its clinical significance is not fully clarified. We aimed to investigate ACHA and its correlation with lipid and clinical parameters in patients with PBC compared to healthy controls, to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and Wilson disease patients. Subjects and Methods: 108 patients with PBC (age:59.3°Ó 9.6 years, each AMA positive, stage I-IV), 31 patients with NASH (age: 51,8°Ó 16,6) and 52 patients with Wilson disease (age:28,5°Ó 12,4) were investigated. Age-matched healthy persons served as controls for each group. ACHA was measured in sera by solid phase enzyme immunoassay as described. Correlation between ACHA and other parameters as serum total, LDL and HDL cholesterol, triglyceride(TG), serum bilirubin, AST, ALT, GGT, ALP, IgA, IgG, IgM was analyzed. Results: Higher serum ACHA level was found in patients with PBC (41.9°Ó 25.1 AU/ml) compared to both healthy controls (28.8°Ó 11.3 AU/ml, pϽ0.0001) and NASH (34,2°Ó 15,5 AU/ml, pϽ0,05) patients. The ACHA values showed an increasing tendency with severity of PBC. Comparing stages IIIϩIV with stages IϩII the difference was significant (pϭ0.013). The serum cholesterol level was slightly elevated in PBC (total: 6.0°Ó 1.1mmol/l), while serum TG level was in the normal range (1.5°Ó 0.8 mmol/l). In NASH patients there were no significant difference in the level of serum ACHA compared to the agematched control group despite of the elevated serum cholesterol level. No correlation was found between serum ACHA concentration and either serum cholesterol level, titre of AMA, immunglobulin levels or any liver function test. In Wilson disease, surprisingly we found decreased serum ACHA level compared to age-matched healthy controls (17,4"b8,9 AU/ ml, pϭ0,000005). The serum ACHA levels in the three control groups were almost the same. Conclusion: Our novel finding of elevated serum ACHA in PBC is in concordance with published data on ACHA in SLE, although its significance is not known. Our results on stage-dependent elevation of serum levels of anti-cholesterol antibodies might stimulate further research to clarify the clinical significance of ACHA. The normal ACHA levels in NASH could shown that not only the hypercholesterolemia may be responsible for the elevated serum ACHA level in Wilson disease. defined. Numerous laboratories have shown increased levels of hepatic 27-hydroxycholesterol (27OH-Chol) in females from various mouse species. This oxysterol, the product of CYP27A1 hydroxylation of cholesterol, has been proposed to function as a regulator of cholesterol homeostasis. Our lab has shown that CYP27A1 specific activity and subsequently, intracellular levels of 27OH-Chol, can be regulated by mitochondrial cholesterol transport in human, rat and mouse hepatocytes. A regulable StARD1like mitochondrial cholesterol transporter has now been identified in human, rat and mouse hepatocytes as well as whole liver tissue (i.e. liver StAR). Objectives: To look for a correlation between higher liver 27OH-Chol levels in female C57BL mice and mitochondrial cholesterol transport; to explain the accumulation of this oxysterol in the liver where it is normally processed quickly to bile acids; and to look for resultant changes in hepatic and whole body cholesterol homeostasis. Results: Female mice showed 54% higher liver StAR protein levels than male controls of the same general age and weight. Hepatocellular CYP27A1 mRNA, protein, and specific activity were also higher (21%, 64%, and 43%, respectively). Interestingly, liver CYP7B mRNA and specific activity were dramatically lower (85% and 51% respectively). Hepatic 27OH-Chol levels were 8X's higher in female C57BL mice. HMG-CoA reductase mRNA levels were the same, while protein and specific activity were significantly lower (53% and 31% respectively). In females, higher hepatic LDL-receptor mRNA levels (15%) were coupled with significantly lower serum cholesterol levels (12-19%). Conclusion: Numerous factors may contribute to lower serum cholesterol levels in females. This study demonstrates that a change in the balance of mitochondrial cholesterol transport, CYP27A1 activity, and CYP7B activity can regulate cholesterol homeostasis by coordinately increasing cholesterol metabolism, altering 27OH-Chol levels, lowering cholesterol synthesis, and increasing hepatic uptake of cholesterol. Previous studies have suggested that 27OH-Chol plays little to no role in cholesterol homeostasis in the liver due to its rapid degradation to bile acids. This study demonstrates that there are physiological instances in which higher levels of 27OH-Chol play a significant role in hepatic cholesterol homeostasis.

body_text.text: Bile acid biosynthesis is the primary pathway for cholesterol degradation in vivo. There are two major pathways of bile acid synthesis: the "neutral" pathway, initiated by highly regulated microsomal cholesterol 7a-hydroxylase (CYP7A1); and the "acidic" pathway, initiated by cholesterol 27a-hydroxylase (CYP27A1) and regulated by mitochondrial cholesterol transport. The present study has identified that a novel regulatory nuclear oxysterol generated in mitochondria via the "acidic" pathway upregulates cholesterol uptake and increases rates of bile acid synthesis. At forty-eight hours after infection with recombinant adenovirus encoding a mitochondria cholesterol transport protein (StAR) in primary rat hepatocytes, bile acid synthesis increased by 5-fold. Concurrently, a 14C-oxysterol with retention time at 11.50 min in HPLC elution profile was dramatically increased both in the mitochondria and in the nucleus, suggesting a mitochondriagenerated oxysterol translocates to the nucleus. LC/MS/MS analysis shows the nuclear oxysterol with a molecular weight 482 in the parental spectra, and the presence of fragment ions at m/z 80, 97, and 124 in its daughter spectra. An oxysterol product could be extracted into the chloroform phase from methanol/water phase after sulfatase treatment, suggesting the nuclear oxysterol is a sulfated C27 oxysterol. Addition of the nuclear extract from the cells overexpressing StAR or the addition of the purified oxysterol to primary rat hepatocytes significantly increased cholesterol uptake and the rates of bile acid synthesis by 4-fold, suggesting this oxysterol is a regulatory oxysterol. These results demonstrate a mechanism by which the "acidic" pathway of bile acid synthesis generates a novel potent regulatory nuclear oxysterol in mitochondria, which translocates into the nucleus, upregulating cholesterol uptake and increasing bile acid synthesis. We conclude that the "acidic" pathway plays an important role in the regulation of intracellular cholesterol homeostasis by generating potent regulatory oxysterols.

body_text.text: Plant sterols and plant stanols sterically interfere with intestinal cholesterol absorption and thereby lower plasma LDL cholesterol levels in humans. These compounds or their esters are available in a variety of functional foods for human consumption. We hypothesized that the beneficial effect of plant sterol-/stanol-enriched functional food is (partly) due to effects on expression of genes involved in cholesterol transport, via activation of the Liver X Receptor (LXR), rather than to intraluminal, competitive effects. In this study, male C57BL/6J mice were fed a sterol-poor semisynthetic diet (control) or semisynthetic diets containing cholesterol (0.12%) only or cholesterol combined with either plant sterols or plant stanols (0.5%) for four weeks. Feces, blood, liver and intestine were harvested for analysis of lipid composition and gene expression profiles. As anticipated, feeding cholesterol-enriched semisynthetic diet increased fecal neutral sterol excretion in C57BL/6J mice (ϩ61%). Addition of plant sterols or plant stanols to the diet resulted in a massive increase in neutral fecal sterol excretion (ϩ268% and ϩ166%, respectively, compared to cholesterol fed mice). Cholesterol-enrichment of the diet did not result in cholesterol accumulation in plasma. Instead, unesterified cholesterol, cholesterol ester and triglyceride concentrations increased in liver tissue of mice fed the cholesterol-enriched diet (2.4-, 10.3-and 2.8-fold, respectively). Addition of plant sterols and plant stanols to the diet completely prevented this hepatic lipid accumulation. Hepatic expression of LXR target genes (e.g., Srebp1c: ϩ87%, Abcg5: ϩ194%) was highly induced on cholesterol diet when compared to cholesterol-free diet. In the intestine, only a small induction of Abca1 expression (maximal 2-fold) was found in mice receiving cholesterol or plant sterol diet, without any effects on other LXR target genes. No cumulative effect of cholesterol plus plant sterols/stanols on hepatic or intestinal gene expression was found.

Although previous experimental evidence has identified oxidative stress as a potential hazard and mitochondria as a possible target, the determinants of susceptibility to nimesulide-induced liver injury have remained unclear. -Aim: To explore whether underlying impairment of mitochondrial function and mildly increased oxidative stress might precipitate potential hepatic adverse effects of nimesulide. -Experimental approach: We used heterozygous superoxide dismutase 2 (Sod2 ϩ/-) mice on a C57BL/6 background as a model, because these mice exhibit clinically silent mitochondrial abnormalities but otherwise appear phenotypically normal. Nimesulide was administered daily for 4 weeks (10 mg/kg, ip, bid, comparable to human therapeutic doses based on a dose scaling factor). -Results: Nimesulide was readily absorbed and attained peak plasma levels similar to human therapeutic plasma concentrations. Drug treatment did not cause any detectable liver injury, as assessed by plasma ALT activity and histopathology. However, we found that nimesulide potentiated mitochondrial oxidative damage (-51% decrease in aconitase activity, ϩ34% increase in protein carbonyls) in the liver of Sod2 ϩ/mice, but not their wild-type littermates, as compared to the respective vehicle controls. Furthermore, nimesulide treatment resulted in increased hepatic cytosolic levels of cytochrome c (ϩ87%) and caspase-3 activity (ϩ38%). Finally, we demonstrated that exposure of mitochondria isolated from untreated Sod2 ϩ/mice to nimesulide caused a marked net increase in superoxide anion formation (dihydroethidine fluorescence), while the drug did not produce any detectable increased oxidative stress in mitochondria from Sod2 ϩ/ϩ mice. -Conclusions: Prolonged administration of low doses of nimesulide can superimpose an oxidant stress, potentiate mitochondrial oxidative damage, and activate pro-apoptotic factors in mice with genetically compromised mitochondrial function, while nimesulide has no detectable effects in healthy control animals. Thus, inherited or acquired abnormalities in mitochondrial function may be one of the contributing determinants of susceptibility to nimesulide-induced idiosyncratic liver injury.

body_text.text: Background: AP is a safe drug at therapeutic doses, but it is hepatotoxic after large-single-dose. Repetitive doses of AP produce resistance to its toxicity in human and animals, though the mechanism is poorly understood. Mrp2 and Mrp3 transport the major metabolite AG through the canalicular and basolateral pole of the hepatocyte for its biliary and urinary elimination, respectively. We evaluated the effect of AP treatment on Mrps expression in rats, as a potential mechanism of decreased drug toxicity. Methods: Male Wistar rats (250-290 g) were used: Repeated protocol (R), rats were injected ip with daily increasing doses of AP (0.2, 0.4, 0.6, and 1.0 g/kg); Single protocol (S), rats received a dose of 1.0 g/kg; Controls (C) received the same volumes of vehicle. Experiments were performed 24 hr after the last injection. Biliary and urinary AP and AG excretion rates were determined in vivo after iv administration of a single test dose of AP (150 mg/kg). Entero-hepatic recirculation of the drug (after same test dose) was estimated in vivo through biliary excretion of AG in animals with intact vs interrupted enterohepatic circuit. Expression of Mrp2 and Mrp3 was evaluated by western blotting and confocal immunofluorescence. Mrp3 activity was assessed in basolateral plasma membrane vesicles. AST and ALT were measured as markers of liver damage. Survival to AP was calculated as living vs total injected rats. Data are meansϮSD, nϭ3-6. Results: Cumulative biliary AG excretion (% dose) after 180 min decreased in R (3.2Ϯ1.9) and S (5.1Ϯ2.2) vs C (15.2Ϯ4.9) (pϽ0.05), whereas urinary excretion increased in R (21.9Ϯ2.5) and S (20.2Ϯ4.6) vs C (10.7Ϯ3.5) (pϽ0.05). Biliary and urinary AP excretion was minimally affected by AP pretreatment. Biliary AG excretion (nmol/min/g liver) in animals with preserved recirculation was lower in R (0.9Ϯ0.6) vs C (2.9Ϯ1.2) (pϽ0.05) and similar between groups in the model of interrupted circulation, suggest-ing diminished AP recirculation in R. Mrp2 plasma membrane level increased by 65% in R or S, whereas Mrp3 increased by 540 and 400% in R and S, respectively. Confocal Mrp2 and Mrp3 detection and Mrp3 activity confirmed preferential Mrp3 induction. Liver damage markers increased to a lesser extent in R vs S, agreeing with higher survival in R (92%) vs S (57%). Conclusions: In the intestine AG is hydrolyzed and the liberated AP is partially reabsorbed. Our data demonstrate a shift from biliary to urinary elimination of AG in AP pretreated groups. Mrp3 induction may contribute to attenuate AP hepatotoxicity by decreasing the permanence of the intact drug in the entero-hepatic circuit, particularly in response to chronic treatment.

Results: Liver histology from KK-Ay mice showed small vesicular fat accumulation in hepatocytes with mild inflammatory infiltration, indicating that KK-Ay mice develop mild steatohepatitis spontaneously. AAP as low as 300 mg/kg induced focal necrosis in the hepatic lobules in KK-Ay mice, but not in C57Bl/6 mice. In turn, elevation in serum ALT levels 6 hours after treatment with 600 mg/kg AAP was significantly higher in KK-Ay mice than in C57Bl/6 mice, the values reaching 6937Ϯ1510 IU/L and 2956Ϯ530 IU/L, respectively. Hepatic contents of GSH in KK-Ay mice were 20% lower than those in C57Bl/6 mice. Increases in serum TNF-␣ levels 6 hours after AAP treatment were the same in both strains. In hepatocytes isolated from C57Bl/6 mice, basal increment of DCF fluorescence for 3 hours was 281% over the initial levels, whereas DCF fluorescence was increased to 417% in the presence of 10 mM AAP for 3 hours as expected. In contrast, cells from KK-Ay mice, which contained obvious lipid droplets in cytoplasm, demonstrated higher basal increment (613%) as well as enhanced elevation in DCF fluorescence 3 hours after addition of AAP to the levels being 818% over controls. Conclusions: KK-Ay mice are more susceptible to AAP-induced toxic liver damage, most likely due to augmented oxidative stress in hepatocytes. body_text.text: Recently we showed that the SNP 1457TϾC (V444A) of ABCB11 might be important for low BSEP protein expression in normal human liver (Hepatology 2004;40 Suppl, 1120A). Thus the aims of this study were (1) to look for DC specific ABCB11 and ABCB4 mutations and (2) to study whether the ABCB11 SNP 1457TϾC appears more frequently in DC and ICP patients in comparison to non-cholestatic individuals. Methods: ABCB11 and ABCB4 were sequenced in 59 cholestatic patients (24 DC and 35 ICP) and 52 non-cholestatic individuals (12 with drug-induced hepatitis (DH) and 40 with normal pregnancies). The distribution of ABCB11 1457TϾC was studied in 205 healthy Caucasians using PCR. Results were analysed with Chi square and Fisher exact test (pՅ0.05). Results: Among 59 cholestatic patients, 3 DC specific mutations (L1082Q for ABCB4, D676Y and G855R for ABCB11) and one ICP specific ABCB4 mutation (L237I) were identified. In 55 cholestatic patients (21 DC; 34 ICP) without a disease-associated mutation, the ABCB11 SNP 1457TϾC distributed as TT genotype in 3, as TC in 4 and as CC in 14 of 21 DC patients. This genotype distribution was significantly different to healthy Caucasians (TT 38, TC 101, CC 66; pϭ0.006). The allelic frequency of the 1457C allele was higher for DC (76%) compared to Caucasians (57%; pϭ0.01). There was a similar trend between DC and DH (54%; pϭ0.059). Also, 1457TϾC was distributed significantly differently in 34 ICP patients (TT 2, TC 13 and CC 19) compared to 40 controls with normal pregnancies (TT 7, TC 15, CC 8; pϭ0.005) and Caucasians (pϭ0.017), resulting in a higher allelic frequency of the 1457C allele (75%) for ICP compared to controls (51%; pϭ0.002) and Caucasians (57%; pϭ0.003). In addition, 4 of 5 DC patients with contraceptive-induced cholestasis exhibited the CC genotype. Thus, the 1457C allele occurs in 75% of cholestatic patients with no additional mutation. Conclusion: Our data indicate that ABCB11 1457TϾC which has been associated with low BSEP expression occurs more frequently in patients with DC and ICP and is therefore a predisposing risk factor for these two forms of acquired cholestasis.

body_text.text: Background: Adeofovir dipivoxil, an esterase-activated prodrug of PMEA has a recommended dose of 10 mg QD, which is suboptimal due to dose-limiting nephrotoxicity. Pradefovir is a CYP3A4 activated prodrug of PMEA with excellent liver-targeting properties in rats and better safety than adeofovir dipivoxil in a one-month monkey toxicity study. Thus pradefovir may optimize its clinical efficacy with potentially lower nephrotoxicity compared to adefovir dipivoxil. Aim: To evaluate the metabolic conversion of pradefovir to PMEA and its potential as an inhibitor or inducer for cytochrome P450 (CYP). Methods: Metabolic conversion of pradefovir to PMEA was the evaluated with major cDNAexpressed CYPs and human liver microsomes with and without the addition of ketoconazole and MAb3A4. The potential of pradefovir (0.2, 2 and 20 M) as an inhibitor for various CYP isozymes was evaluated in human liver microsomes. The potential of pradefovir (0.1, 1 and 10 g/mL) as an inducer was evaluated in human hepatocytes following once daily treatment for three consecutive days and in rats following daily dosing of 300 mg/kg for 8 days. Results: CYP3A4 is the only P450 enzyme catalyzing the conversion of pradefovir to PMEA among major cDNA-expressed CYPs. It was converted to PMEA in human liver microsomes with a Km of 60 M, a Vmax of 228 pmol/min/mg protein and an intrinsic clearance of 3.8 l/min/mg protein. The addition of ketoconazole and MAb3A4 significantly inhibited the conversion of pradefovir to PMEA in human liver microsomes. Ketoconazole was a non-competitive inhibitor for the conversion of pradefovir to PMEA in human liver microsomes with an inhibition constant of 12.5 nM. Pradefovir was neither a direct inhibitor nor a mechanism based inhibitor for CYP3A4, CYP2D6, CYP2C9, CYP2C19, CYP2E1 and CYP1A2 in human liver microsomes. Pradefovir was neither an inducer of CYP1A2 nor CYP3A4/5 in primary cultures of human hepatocytes. In rats, daily oral dosing of pradefovir did not affect body weight, liver weight and liver-body weight ratio, liver microsomal protein content, total CYP content, enzyme activities for CYP1A, CYP2B, CYP3A and apoprotein content for CYP1A1, CYP2B1/2, CYP3A1/2 and CYP4A1/3. Conclusions: Pradefovir is a substrate of CYP3A4, but neither an inhibitor nor an inducer for CYPs.

For patients with decompensated liver cirrhosis or acute liver failure, those molecules are challenging, as they are poorly metabolized in this state.
