Methods: Commercial HSA, alternative preparations containing less OC and NAC and commercial HSA which was purified from those ligands by a "bed side" medical device were used to administer albumin therapy in an in vitro model. Plasma samples from healthy donors "spiked" with albumin bound toxins as well as Plasma Samples from patients with liver failure containing albumin bound toxins were used as "patient model". After adding the above described albumin preparations in an equivalent of 1:8 to the patients samples, the ABiC was measured by adding a binding site II (diazepam binding site) specific fluorescence marker (Dansylsarcosine, DS) and subsequently measuring the amount of unbound DS by fluorescence detection after ultrafiltration, which corresponds to the albumin binding capacity. Results: In plasma samples with an impaired ABiC, an improvement could be achieved by adding deligandized albumin, whereas commercial HSA was associated with a further decrease of ABiC. Even in a and healthy plasma donor samples with a normal baseline ABiC (median 116%; range 93 -169) it was impaired if HSA was added (median 77%; range 74 -91%). Conclusions: As recent papers have demonstrated the role of albumin binding sites in regulating vasoactive substances, as prostaglandins and NO, the presence of octanoate and NAC might be responsible for the unsatisfying performance of HSA in clinical studies, especially in hemodynamic impairement due to liver failure. disease. body_text.text: Backgrounds: Tumor recurrence rates remain high after curative treatments including surgical resection and liver transplantation for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Among many novel trials targeting recurrent tumors, the immunomodulatory agents including cytokines and chemokines are believed to enhance the innate and acquired immune responses in conjunction with tumor cell apoptosis induced with the suicide gene therapy. We have reported that the antitumor effects of the herpes simplex virus thymidine kinase/ganciclovir (HSV-tk/GCV) system are enhanced by codelivery of monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1) (Cancer Gene Ther 10:260,2003). The current study was designed to evaluate the prolonged immunomodulatory effects of a bicistronic adenovirus vector expressing both HSV-tk and MCP-1 on HCC cells. Methods: Bicistronic recombinant adenovirus (rAd) vector Ad-tk-MCP1 harboring HSV-tk and human MCP-1 genes, and Ad-tk and Ad-lacZ expressing HSV-tk and the control lacZ genes, respectively, under the universal CAG promoter were prepared. To evaluate the in vitro effects, we measured cytokine production by macrophages or dendritc cells (DCs) when co-cultured with HCC cells infected with the rAds. To estimate the immune-mediated effects in a murine model of HCC, Huh7 cells were subcutaneously transplanted to athymic nude mice (BALB/c-nu/nu) on day 0, and subsequently eradicated with Ad-tk-MCP1 or Ad-tk. The control mice were injected with mitomycin C treated Huh7 cells and Ad-LacZ. On day 14 these mice were rechallenged with Huh7 cells, and tumor development was monitored. Results: Macrophages and DCs secreted large amounts of IL-12 when co-cultured with apoptotic HCC cells induced with Ad-tk, and further produced it with those infected with Ad-tk-MCP1 (PϽ0.05). In the mouse model, the growth of rechallenged tumors was markedly suppressed when primary tumor cells had been eradicated with Ad-tk-MCP1 compared to the mice treated with Ad-tk or Ad-lacZ (PϽ0.001). In animals treated with Ad-tk-MCP1, serum levels of IL-12 and IL-18 were significantly elevated after the administration of rechallenged tumor cells, and NK cells were recruited and IFN-gamma production was enhanced in the rechallenged tumor tissues. In addition, the antitumor responses were abolished by inactivating NK cells using anti-asialo GM1 antibody. Furthermore, the Ad-tk-MCP1 induced antitumor effects were similarly seen in wild type immunocompetent mice. Conclusions: Eradication of HCC cells using the suicide gene with codelivery of MCP-1 exerts the prolonged, NK cell-mediated antitumor effects in a model of HCC, suggesting a plausible strategy to prevent HCC recurrence.

The current study, using an immunocompetent mouse model of intrahepatic hepatoma implantation with micrometastases, was designed to investigate whether MCP-1 gene delivery may potentiate the antitumor effects of the suicide gene system. Methods: BNL 1ME A.7R.1 (BNL), a BALB/c mousederived HCC cell line, was infected with recombinant adenovirus vectors expressing HSV-tk (Ad-tk), MCP-1 (Ad-MCP1) and LacZ (Ad-LacZ) at various multiplicities of infection (MOIs): Ad-tk/Ad-MCP1 ϭ 3/0.03 (group A), 3/0.3 (B) and 3/3 (C), Ad-tk/Ad-LacZ ϭ 3/3 (D), and Ad-LacZ ϭ 3 (E). BALB/c mice were transferred with these adenovirus-infected BNL cells via portal vein on day 0. Subsequently, 75 mg/kg of ganciclovir was administered for 5 days. Animals were sacrificed on days 1, 3, 7, 14 and 21, liver tissues were weighed and examined by immunohistochemistry and real-time PCR for expression of IL-4, IL-10, IL-12, IL-18 and IFN␣, and splenocytes were tested for cytolytic activity against 51Cr-labeled BNL cells. Results: When compared to the mice in control group E, mean liver weight (ϮSD) was increased by 2.45 Ϯ 0.36 g in group A due to the intrahepatic implantation and growth of tumor cells on day 21, which was significantly smaller than that in group D (5.80 Ϯ 0.58 g; PϽ0.01). In contrast, the increase in liver weight was not suppressed in groups B and C whose tumor cells had been treated with higher titers of Ad-MCP1. In group A, immunohistochemical analysis of liver tissues showed remarkable Mac-1ϩ cell infiltration on day 1 and CD8ϩ T cell infiltration inside the tumor nodules on day 14, and IL-12 and IL-18 expression was increased after the tumor cell transfer. The highest tumor-specific cytolytic activity was induced with splenocytes of group A. Conclusions: The antitumor effects of the suicide gene are enhanced by codelivery of an adequate amount of MCP-1 in an intrahepatic implantation model of HCC, which are exclusively associated with the recruitment of monocytes/macrophages and CD8ϩ T cells, T helper 1 cytokine gene expression and cytolytic activity of the splenocytes. The results suggest an immunomodulatory effect of MCP-1 on the suicide gene therapy of HCC by orchestrating the innate and acquired immune responses.

Mononuclear cells from patients with chronic HCV infection express fgl2 mRNA and protein and successful treatment with IFN and ribavirin results in loss of fgl2. Fgl2 now has been shown to be expressed as both a membrane associated protein as well as in a soluble form. Soluble fgl2 generated by CD4ϩ CD25ϩ regulatory T cells in response to viral core protein and/or IFN-gamma binds to dendritic cells (DC) and inhibits DC maturation and subsequent T and B cell effector anti-viral function. To identify and characterize the receptor for fgl2, an fgl2 fusion protein was generated by transfection of CHO-K1 cells with a Pires-neo-3-Fc-fgl2 plasmid. Purified biotinylated fgl2 protein binding was studied in mouse peritoneal macrophages, bone marrow derived dendritic cells and LPS stimulated and unstimulated spleen cells from mice resistant (A/J) and susceptible (Balb/cJ) mice. Fgl2 bound specifically to peritoneal macrophages, dendritic cells and LPS-stimulated B cells from susceptible mice, but did not bind to cells from resistant mice. Screening of a cDNA library constructed from receptor positive B cells has tentatively identified the receptor for fgl2 as the low affinity Fc-gammaRIIB receptor which contains an immunotyrosine inhibitory motif (ITIM) and is known to inhibit phagocytosis, ADCC and inflammatory mediator release and is associated with increased susceptibility to infection. Antibodies to CD16/32 blocked binding of fgl2, confirming that the fc-gam-maRIIB is the fgl2 receptor. These studies demonstrate that soluble fgl2 binds to fc-gammaRIIB, expressed primarily on antigen presenting cells and provides a mechanism whereby experimental and human viruses may evade immune surveillance.

body_text.text: Introduction: Interferon-a (IFN) therapy causes thrombocytopenia induced partly by inadequate TPO production without decreased TPO-mRNA expression, pointing to a posttranscriptional control mechanism. Hepatocytes produce different TPO-transcripts through alternatively spliced 5'-UTR's with highly variable translation efficiencies due to upstream AUG codons. A short alternative spliced TPO mRNA isoform, lacking exon 2, displayed high efficiency of translation compared to the regularly spliced transcripts, suggesting that alternative splicing may serve as a control mechanism for TPO production in IFN therapy. Considering the contribution of SRp40 to the unusual high frequency of alternative splice site usage seen in liver, we hypothesized that HRS/SRp40 might be involved in the regulation of exon 2 skipping in TPO pre-mRNAs during IFN treatment. We have now addressed this by examining the splicing of both wild type and mutant forms of ABCB11. An in vitro minigene system was used to create constructs containing wild type ABCB11 exons 9 or 14, along with 500 bp of intronic sequence either side of these exons. Site-directed mutagenesis was used to introduce the E297G mutation (nt 890, A to G) to exon 9 and the D482G mutation (nt 1445, A to G) to exon 14. These constructs, along with the native minigene system, were introduced into HepG2 cells using liposome-mediated transfection. After 48 hours, total RNA was isolated and reverse transcription was performed. Subsequently, a PCR using primers specific to the spliced form of the minigene system was performed. Products were sized by electrophoresis to look for the inclusion/exclusion of the ABCB11 exons in the system, as well as variant splicing forms. PCR products sequenced to look for small product size changes. Real-time PCR was used to determine the levels of included/excluded products and variant splicing forms. Total RNA was also isolated from the liver of patients with either the E297G or D482G mutations. PCR products generated using primers in the exons flanking those under study, and they were sized and sequenced and levels measured by real-time PCR. E297G was spliced normally in the minigene system, as well as in the liver from affected patients. Furthermore, mRNA levels associated with this mutation are similar to that of wild type exon 9 in vitro and in vivo. The effect on protein trafficking and function is now being assessed. D482G was associated with a severe disruption of the normal splicing of exon 14, resulting in the predominance of a differentially sized PCR product compared to wild type. Therefore, the true mechanism by which D482G causes liver disease is primarily at the level of disrupting ABCB11 mRNA processing. Integrity of mRNA processing is relatively difficult to analyse, but disruption is probably an underestimated mechanism of human disease.

Further analysis of this collection of 91 hepatocellular carcinomas, whose gene expression profile differed according to the prognosis, revealed that HINT2 mRNA was less abundant in the subclass (nϭ40) of HCC with a poor prognosis when compared with the subclass (nϭ51) with better prognosis (1.7-fold, pϽ1.0 x 10-5 Previous work from our group has indicated that the transcriptional response to IFN-␣ varies between different donors in vitro, which lead us to hypothesize that the analysis of the in vivo IFN response in HCV patients might reveal specific profiles that are associated with response and non-response to therapy. To identify those profiles, 21 caucasian patients were treated with standard combination antiviral therapy consisting of pegylated IFN-␣2b (1.5g/kg body weight once weekly) in combination with ribavirin (800-1200 mg daily) for 12 months (HCV genotype 1, nϭ14) or 6 months (HCV genotype 2/3, nϭ1/6), respectively. Peripheral blood was collected 12h before and 12h after the first injection of IFN-␣ and the transcriptional profile was analysed using human genomic microarrays (Affymetrix HG U133A) and quantitative real-time rt-PCR. Three data sets were obtained and analysed: a) basal expression (BE): expression level 12h before the first injection of IFN, b) induced expression (IE): expression level 12h after the first injection and c) fold change (FC): fold difference between BE and IE. Then, class prediction was performed using the PAM software package after pre-filtering the initial 22.000 genes by selecting those that were present in at least 20% of the patients, resulting in 8238 genes. So far, 18 patients have completed the study with 2 patients in follow-up and one patient lost to follow-up. 7 patients were non-responders (NR) to therapy while 11 patients had a SVR. BE, IE and FC were compared between NR and SVR using the PAM software. The data indicate that the SVR can be predicted in all three data sets with different levels of accuracy. FC was the only parameter that allowed correct class prediction in all patients. 100% of the patients were classified correctly with 97 genes, while only 13 and 2 genes were necessary to correctly classify 95% and 90% of the patients, respectively. Analysis of BE and IE revealed maximum levels of accuracy of 95% (12 genes) and 90% (14 genes), respectively. Interestingly, the ISGs that predicted SVR did not overlap with those associated with the immediate antiviral activitiy of IFN. These data indicate that a sustained virological response in HCV monoinfected patients can be predicted by analysis of the transcriptome before or at the very beginning of combination therapy. It suggests that the SVR is largely dependent upon the genetic background of the patient provided she or he is adherent to therapy. Finally, the functional analysis of the differentially regulated genes that were identified in this study could lead to the discovery of novel drug targets to improve the efficacy of HCV therapy.

Background and aim: Demethylating agents, such as 5-aza-2'deoxycytidine (DAC) have been used for treatment of cancer. Its clinical utility, however, is limited due to several side effects. Recently, procaine (PCA) and procainamide (PCAA), which have been widely utilized for clinical use, were revealed to be demethylating agent. In this study, we investigated whether PCA had growth-inhibitory effect on human hepatoma cells. Materials and Methods: Six human hepatoma cell lines (HLE, HuH7, HepG2, Hep3B, PLC/PRF/5, HuH6) and primary human hepatocytes were treated with 1mM of PCA or 1microM of DAC or 1mM of PCAA together with or without 0.67 microM of trichostatin A (TSA) for 96h and the viability of the cells was measured by MTS assay. Nude mice bearing xenograft were treated with weekly intravenous injection of PCA (low dose: 0.5 mg or high dose: 1 mg) or DAC (17.5 microg) or PCAA (1mg) or saline as a control for 8 weeks. Results: The viability of HLE, HuH7 and HuH6 cells was significantly decreased by the treatment with PCA (77.4%, 70.1% and 86.9% compared to control, respectively)(pϽ0.0001). In these cells, the combination treatment with TSA and PCA exhibited stronger growth-inhibitory effect compared with TSA alone (66.0%, 83.3% and 76.9% compared to control, respectively) (pϽ0.0001). In contrast, 2mg of PCA treatment or combination treatment of PCA and TSA did not induce the reduction of viability of primary human hepatocytes. High dose of PCA treatment resulted in significant tumor reduction (57.7 ᮀ} 8.8 %, relative to the tumor volume before the treatment) in xenograft bearing mice compared to that of the other treatments, such as low dose of PCA, DAC, PCAA treatment (76.2 ᮀ} 5.2 %, 77.5 ᮀ} 9.6 %, 62.3 ᮀ} 8.8 %, relative to the tumor volume before the treatment, respectively) (pϽ0.0001). Conclusion: PCA exhibited growth-inhibitory effect on human hepatoma cells without interfering with primary human hepatocytes. Growth-inhibitory effect of PCA might be partially due to restoration of tumor suppressor genes inactivated through DNA hypermethylation. PCA may be a safe candidate for future therapy of hepatocellular carcinoma based on epigenomics.

body_text.text: Background: Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) is a pleiotropic factor that promotes mitogenesis, morphogenesis, angiogenesis, and anti-apoptosis of a wide spectrum of tissues, which suggests a very effective regenerative factor. On the other hand HGF has "scattering" function which promotes cancer cell invasion and metastases. Recently HGF-MSP chimera (Metron Factor-1, MF-1) was engineered to have favorable effects of HGF, being separated from the adverse effect of invasiveness (Nature Biotech, 2002). MF-1 binds to both Met and Ron (MSP receptor), eliciting a biological signal through Met-Ron heterodimerization. Aims: We examined biological effects of MF-1 in vitro and in vivo, and try to determine whether MF-1 can be a useful and safe regenerative factor for livers. Methods: MF-1 protein, produced in MDA-MB 435 cells, was purified by two-step affinity chromatography. For in vitro study hepatocytes were exposed to MF-1 or HGF (10-100 ng/ml), and mitogenesis was examined by 3 H-thymidine incorporation, Fas-mediated apoptosis by Cell Death Detection ELISA, receptor activation, signal transduction and cell cycles by Western blotting, respectively. Matrigel invasion assay was performed using human HCC cell lines HepG2 and Huh-1. For in vivo study, acute CCl 4 liver injury was induced in Balb/c mice together with the treatment of MF-1 intravenously or saline as control, and the livers were analyzed. Results: Hepatocytes expressed both c-Met and RON, and phospholylated AKT and ERK1/2 were detected at 10 min, peaked at 30 min and decreased gradually after the treatments with MF-1 (50ng/ml) and HGF (50ng/ml). The time course and relative induction folds of both treatments were almost same. 3 H-thymidine incorporation was increased with 2.4 folds by MF-1 and 3.3 folds by HGF comparing to that of control. Cyclin D1 and Cdk4 expressions were increased in the same manner by treatments of both factors. Concerning anti-apoptotic function, MF-1 suppressed Fas-mediated apoptosis by 78%, while HGF suppressed by 41 %. Moreover MF-1 didn't affect HepG2 cell invasion through Matrigel, while HGF promoted significantly (417 vs. 637, pϽ0.05). In vivo study, serum ALT levels in acute liver injury showed significant suppression by MF-1 treatment compared to the control group (3465 IU/L vs. 1832 at 2 day, 753 vs. 339 at 3 day, pϽ0.005). TUNNEL-positive hepatocytes were significantly fewer in MF-1 treated group. Conclusion: MF-1 has favorable functions of proliferation and anti-apoptosis on hepatocytes, and no adverse effect of invasiveness on HCC cells. These results suggested MF-1 can be a useful and safe growth factor for liver regeneration. Introduction: Loss of susceptibility to apoptosis is a central step in carcinogenesis. Since failure to induce apoptosis triggered by membrane receptors has been described in several tumors, sensitization of tumor cells to apoptosis may have therapeutic relevance. Src is a well characterized oncogene which is overexpressed in many tumors including hepatocellular carcinoma. Even though its pathophysiological role has been related to various aspects of carcinogenesis, including invasivity and angiogenesis, its function remains still largely elusive.

body_text.text: We investigated whether Src affects cell survival by influencing death receptor-mediated apoptosis. Hepatoma and colon carcinoma human cell lines have been stimulated with the pro-apoptotic molecules anti-APO-1 or TRAIL while the activity of Src was inhibited by pharmacologic inhibitors or RNA interference. Apoptosis and cell cycle changes were assessed by flow cytometry. Caspase activity was also targeted by RNA-interference and western blot was used for protein quantification. To assess the effect of Src inhibition in non-tumour cells, in vitro stimulation of primary hepatocytes with and without concomitant downregulation of Src activity has been performed. Results: Inhibiton of Src activity by PP2 increased CD95-and TRAIL-induced apoptosis in colon carcinoma and hepatoma cell lines independently of p53 function. In the Chang hepatoblastoma cell line administration of the Src inhibitor PP2 caused 25% apoptosis. Stimulation of Chang cells with anti-APO-1 (150ng/ml) or TRAIL (5ng/ml) caused 10% and 12% apoptosis, respectively . Combination of PP2 with anti-APO-1 or TRAIL, however, dramatically increased apoptosis up to 86 and 82%, respectively. Similar results have been obtained by targeting Src with a specific siRNA.

Furthermore, siRNA inhibition of caspase 8 expression prevented the effects of Src inhibition and death receptor stimulation. PP2 administration, but not specific RNA interference directed against Src led to cell cycle arrest. We could also observe that although high doses of TRAIL efficiently induced apoptosis in primary hepatocytes, PP2 and TRAIL administration in these cells had only a mild pro-apoptotic effect at doses effective in tumor cell lines. Conclusion: Src contributes to tumourigenesis by inhibition of apoptosis. Due to the tumour selective enhancement of receptor mediated apoptosis pharmacologic Src inhibition and concomitant pro-apoptotic membrane receptor targeting is a promising new therapeutic strategy in hepatocellular cancers overexpressing Src.

body_text.text: Background: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) has a poor prognosis. Dendritic cells (DCs) are professional antigen presenting cells able to prime T-cells against tumor-associated antigens, but their potential to induce HCC regression is limited. IL-12 is an essential factor for induction of cellular immune responses. In this study, DCs pulsed with tumor lysate and subsequently transduced with an adenovirus (Ad) encoding murine IL-12 enhanced inhibition of HCC-growth in mice. Methods: Two adenoviruses were generated: Ad-GFP (encoding green fluorescence protein) and Ad-mIL-12 (encoding murine IL-12). DCs were obtained from bone marrow of C3H-HeNcrl mice and cultured with GM-CSF and IL-4. DCs were pulsed with tumor lysate on day 5 and infected with adenoviruses (MOI 500) on day 6. Transgene expression of Ad-GFP and expression of CD80, CD86 and CD40 were assayed by flow cytometry. IL-12expression was detected by ELISA. DCs were injected in the left flank of mice s.c. twice at weekly intervals. One week after the last vaccination, a hepatocellular tumor was induced by inoculation of 106 Hepa129-cells s.c. into the right flank of mice. Results: 48h after transduction of DCs with Ad-GFP Ͼ40% of cells expressed GFP. Ad-IL-12-transduced DCs showed a dose-dependent IL-12-secretion in the supernatant which could be detected already at MOI 100. Expression of DC maturation markers CD80, CD86 or CD40 was not reduced by adenoviral transduction. DCs pulsed with tumor lysate and transduced with Ad-IL-12 could inhibit significantly (pϭ0,0286) hepatocellular tumor volume in vaccinated mice as compared to control mice, which were treated with tumor lysate pulsed and Ad-GFP-transduced DCs. On day 19 the mean tumor volume was 361.5ϩ/-91.3 mm3 in IL-12-DCvaccinated vs. 992.4ϩ/-250.5 mm3 in control mice. Mice treated with IL-12-transduced DCs displayed stronger protection to tumor challenge than control mice. All treated animals were tumorfree for one week vs. only 25% of control mice. Mean survival of IL-12-DC-treated mice was significantly prolonged (32.5ϩ/-1.4 days vs 21.2ϩ/-1.0 days, pϭ0,0007) after challenge with Hepa129cells. Conclusions: Our data show that transduction of tumor lysate pulsed-DCs with Ad-IL-12 yields high IL-12-expression. S.c. vaccination with these bio-engeneered DCs can significantly inhibit hepatocellular tumor growth in mice after s.c. challenge with Hepa129-cells. Background: AFP is a tumor-associated antigen (TAA) expressed in most HCC. It may be useful as a target-molecule for immunotherapy of HCC. However, breaking immune tolerance to selfantigens is difficult. Few recent studies demonstrate that use of xenoantigens of homologous TAA can induce a potent immune response to tumor-associated self-antigens. Human (h)AFP and murine (m)AFP are highly conserved and display high homology. In this study, we transduced DCs of healthy human donors with adenovirus encoding hAFP or mAFP to stimulate immunologic effector cells against hAFP-expressing hepatocarcinoma-cells. Methods: Three recombinant adenoviruses were generated: Ad-GFP (encoding green fluorescence protein), Ad-hAFP (encoding hAFP) and Ad-mAFP (encoding mAFP). Peripheral blood lymphocytes were isolated from healthy donors (nϭ3) by Ficoll density gradient centrifugation to obtain DC and lymphocytes. DCs were cultured with GM-CSF and IL-4 and were infected with adenoviruses at MOI 200 on day 6. Efficiency of adenoviral transduction was assayed by flow cytometry. Lymphocytes were stimulated with mab CD3, IL-2, IFN-gamma and IL-1b and cocultured with transduced DCs. Ability to lyse hAFP-expressing Huh7-cells was determined in a 51Cr-release assay. Results: 48h after transduction of DCs with Ad-GFP, 60 to 80% of transduced cells expressed GFP. The transgene expression of hAFP measured in the supernatant was Ͼ200ng/ml and Ͼ1500ng/ml 48h and 8 days, respectively, after transduction with Ad-hAFP. The transgene expression of mAFP in DCs could be detected by Western blot already at MOI 100. Adenovirally transduced DCs displayed a mature phenotype 13 days after generation, as judged by decreasing coexpression of CD14 and CD1d and increasing expression of typical molecules such as CD80, CD83, CD86 and HLA-DR. Using Ad-mAFP-transduced DCs, we found that the induced cytotoxicity of effector cells against Huh7-cells was significantly (pϽ0.04) higher than the induced cytotoxicity of Ad-hAFP-transduced DCs. Conclusions: Our data show that breaking immune tolerance against hAFP can be increased by using the homologous xenoantigen mAFP in vitro. We suppose the more immunogenic epitopes of mAFP enhance the stimulatory capacity of human DCs against hAFP-expressing HCC-cells. This approach may serve as a novel immunotherapy for HCC. Further investigations of single epitopes of mAFP cross-reacting with hAFP-epitopes are needed. ray analysis to examine the global changes in gene expression that accompany the differentiation of HBC-3 hepatoblast cells in response to Matrigel, 3.5% DMSO or 5mM sodium butyrate. Matrigel was used to induce cholangiocyte differentiation. DMSO or sodium butyrate was used to induce hepatocyte differentiation. We have used 27,000 spot cDNA arrays for transcriptional profiling to identify pathways of gene regulation that are specific to hepatocyte or cholangiocyte differentiation. Using this analysis we have identified 522 genes that are significantly up regulated specifically during Matrigel induced differentiation. Additionally, 120 genes were significantly up regulated during both DMSO and sodium butyrate but not during Matrigel treatment. Further analysis of these gene lists revealed that there are significant differences in the expression of genes involved in three key signaling pathways, the Wnt/beta-catenin, TGFbeta/BMP and Notch signaling pathways. The differential regulation of these pathways during cholangiocyte and hepatocyte differentiation was confirmed using western blot analysis of nuclear and cytoplamic fractions of cells treated with either Matrigel or DMSO suggesting that the interaction of these signaling pathways may be important for determining the fate of hepatoblasts within the developing liver. Notch signaling is known to play a role in bile duct development. To investigate whether the TGFbeta/BMP pathway plays a role in vivo we immunostained sections of liver from day 16 and 18 of gestation embryos and 1 day old pups. Nuclear staining with Smad 5 was found in hepatoblasts surrounding the developing vasculature within the e16 and e18 day liver. However, hepatoblasts that were not surrounding the vasculature did not have Smad 5 staining suggesting that the TGFbeta/BMP pathway plays a role in cholangiocyte differentiation in vivo. On going studies will determine the interplay of these three pathways in bipotent hepatoblast differentiation.

body_text.text: The hepatocyte growth factor/scatter factor (HGF/SF) c-met signal transduction pathway is essential for controlling hepatocyte motility, survival and proliferation. Our aim was to characterize the sequential induction of HGF/c-met target genes in mouse primary hepatocytes, and to detect the effects of c-met deletion on hepatocyte gene expression. We used oligonucleotide microarrays, containing 21997 unique probes, to identify HGF/c-met target genes in wild-type and c-met knock-out (KO) mouse primary hepatocytes. Previously, we have generated a c-met conditional KO mouse using the Cre-loxP system, where the Cre recombinase is controlled by albumin promoter inactivated c-met in postnatal hepatocytes. Serum-starved wild-type or c-met KO hepatocytes were treated in triplicate experiments with recombinant HGF for 0.5, 2, 12 and 24 hours respectively. Total RNA from each experiment was used in reverse-fluor hybridizations. Using the SAM algorithm (1.7-fold difference, Ͻ10% FDR), 426 HGF/c-met regulated genes showing significantly different expression levels between Cre-control and c-met KO hepatocytes were identified. Direct HGF/c-met target genes were verified in samples treated with the translation blocker cycloheximide. In addition to previously described HGF target genes, such as osteopontin, Hmga1 or Egr1, in treated control samples we also detected induction of genes involved in cell proliferation (CDK4, G0/G1 switch) integrin-mediated cell motility (integrin alpha 3, beta 1, fibronectin) and cytoskeletal organization (Cap1, tubulin-b, myosin IC). As expected c-met null hepatocytes did not respond to HGF treatment, but showed persistently higher expression of metabolic stress response genes including the Nrf2 transcription factor and its target genes Gsta-1,-2,-4, and GCLC. Pi3kr1 regulator of PI3kinase also showed continuously higher expression in c-met knock-out cells. With 155 homologous c-met regulated genes, cross-species cluster analysis of expression profiles from mouse primary hepatocytes and from 113 human hepatocellular carcinomas (HCC), disclosed forty seven HCCs with enhanced activation of HGF/c-met signaling. Patients with tumors showing high expression of c-met targets had significantly (pϽ0.0001) worse survival rate (40 deaths out of 47) compared to other HCC patients (34 deaths out of 66). In conclusion, besides regulating cell motility and proliferation, HGF/c-met may also be involved in maintaining metabolic homeostasis of hepatocytes. Our data also suggest that specific expression profiles could be useful to identify activation of signaling pathways that play crucial roles in the progression of hepatocellular carcinoma.

body_text.text: The following authors have indicated they have no relationships to disclose: Pal Kaposi-Novak We have previously reported that amphiregulin (AR), a ligand of the EGF-receptor which is not expressed in healthy liver tissue, is induced during acute and chronic liver damage including human liver cirrhosis. Our data indicated that AR induction is likely part of the endogenous adaptive response of the liver to injury, aimed at the restoration of hepatocellular mass and the prevention of cell death. However, the establishment of a proliferative tissue microenvironment by elevated expression of growth factors such as AR, can contribute to the multistep process of hepatocarcinogenesis. We have evaluated the contribution of AR to different traits related to the neoplastic phenotype of HCC. AR gene expression was analyzed in samples of human HCC tissue (nϭ19) by real time PCR, and found to be significantly elevated in 73% of the cases. Interestingly, the expression of the metalloproteinase ADAM17/TACE, involved in AR shedding from the cell surface, was also upregulated in human HCC and in cirrhotic liver when compared to healthy controls. These findings support the existence of a putative autocrine/paracrine loop involving AR in chronic liver injury and HCC. The functional relevance of such autocrine mechanism was addressed in human HCC cell lines. We first observed that HCC cells (PLC, Hep3B, HuH7 and HepG2) express and release AR to their conditioned media, and that AR production is enhanced in the absence of serum. Furthermore, interference with the release of AR, or incubation with AR neutralizing antibodies, resulted in reduced EGFR signaling and HCC cell growth in serum-free conditions. Nevertheless, the most compelling evidence supporting the biological significance of ARmediated autocriny in HCC was obtained when AR expression was silenced by AR-specific si-RNAs. Indeed, downregulation of AR gene expression significantly reduced HCC cell growth, and greatly enhanced the efficacy of the antitumor drug doxorubicine on HCC cell apoptosis. In conclusion, the upregulation of AR, and its processing enzyme ADAM17/TACE, in the preneoplastic cirrhotic liver suggest that AR can be a novel player in the continuous process of hepatocarcinogenesis. Moreover, our data indicate that AR is also involved in the maintenance of the neoplastic phenotype of HCC cells, and thus constitutes a novel therapeutic target in liver cancer. Interleukin-12 (IL-12) is a potent antitumoral cytokine, but it can be toxic at high doses. In order to minimize its side effects we have generated a plasmid vector able to direct expression of murine IL-12 in a liver-specific and doxycycline (Dox)-inducible manner. The plasmid was transferred to mice by the hydrodynamics-based procedure and the antitumor effect of IL-12 was evaluated in a transgenic L-PK/c-myc mouse model of spontaneous hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). These animals over-express the c-myc oncogene under the control of the liver-specific pyruvate kinase (L-PK) promoter and develop tumors in 6-8 months that resemble human HCC in terms of biology and gene expression profile. After several rounds of IL-12 induction with Dox (2 mg/ml given in drinking water) for 5-10 days along six months, a clear inhibition of tumor growth and increased survival was observed in treated mice (nϭ10) compared to controls (nϭ9). The effect of IL-12 was also evaluated in histology samples and by quantification of AFP and VEGF mRNA levels in tumoral and non-tumoral tissues. In order to improve the non-invasive detection of HCC in the L-PK/c-myc mice we have tested different PET tracers (18FDG, 18FDOPA and 11C-Choline). Animals were examined in a Philips Mosaic microPET scanner. 11C-Choline was able to detect 58% tumor nodules, while 18FDG detected 55% of the tumor lesions (similar results to those observed in human HCC). 18FDOPA allow the detection only of 1 out of 3 lesions. The combined analysis of 18FDG and 11C-Choline given separately allowed detection of 75% tumor lesions. In any case, the size of the tumor did not determine detection, since small lesions (5x3 mm) could be detected while bigger lesions (up to 15x12 mm) were not always seen. Both ex vivo PET imaging of extracted organs and gamma counter data confirmed the in vivo images. We conclude that a gene therapy strategy based on the intrahepatic administration of IL-12 from a plasmid vector can improve the prognosis of a human-like mice model of well-differentiated HCC and that the combined analysis of 11C-Choline and 18FDG images may increase the possibilities of properly diagnose HCC lesions.

body_text.text: High levels of endotoxin (LPS) are often detected in the blood of patients with cirrhosis. These levels are thought to be responsible for the activation of TNF-␣ mediated pro-inflammatory pathways. BPI is a cationic protein with bactericidal and endotoxin binding capacity that is largely produced by polymorphonuclear leukocytes. Endotoxin neutralization occurs because BPI competitively antagonizes the binding of LPS to LBP. Objectives: To evaluate the functional state of the anti-inflammatory pathway mediated by BPI in cirrhotic patients. Patients and Methods: Forty-two cirrhotic patients with diverse etiologies (alcoholic, nϭ28; viral, nϭ4; mixed, nϭ4; others, nϭ 6) and classified according Child Pugh stage (8 Child A, 20 Child B and 14 Child C) were enrolled. Patients with history of recent infection were excluded. Ten healthy subjects served as controls. Plasmatic BPI, LBP and TNF-␣ levels were measured using immunometric assays. An adaptation of the LAL assay was used to determine the endotoxin (LPS) plasma level. BPI mRNA expression in PMN was quantified by real-time PCR. Results: In the cirrhotic patients we have observed an increase in BPI mRNA and BPI plasmatic level compare to control subjects (pϽ0.05). There was also a significant difference when comparing Child C stage (mRNA: 10.51 ϩ 12.9; BPI: 23.66 ϩ 29.07 ng/mL) with Child A (3.95 ϩ 2.5; 8.35 ϩ 7.08) pϽ0.05. Moreover, Child B-C patients showed higher plasma levels of LPS (0.71 ϩ 0.45ug/ml) and LBP (12.84 ϩ 6.31ug/ml) than Child A patients ( 0,58 ϩ 0,6 UA/ml; 9,88 ϩ 4,12 ug/ml), although this difference was not statistically significant. An increase of plasmatic TNF-␣ levels was observed in Child C patients (10.29 ϩ 6.5 ng/mL) respect to Child A (6.29 ϩ 4.6). A significant correlation between BPI and LPS plasma levels and between BPI and TNF-␣ level was observed (pϽ 0.05). Conclusions: 1. Both, mRNA BPI expression in PMN and BPI protein levels in plasma are increased in cirrhotic patients, particularly in those with the worst functional impairment degree (Child C). 2. The amount of BPI in plasma correlates positively with the levels of endotoxin and TNF-␣. These results suggest that the cirrhotic patients show an activation of the anti-inflammatory pathways mediated by the BPI, which possibly plays a regulatory role antagonizing the pro-inflammatory mechanisms mediated by TNF-␣.

body_text.text: The Background: Based on our early in vivo studies that defined the asialoglycoprotein receptor (ASGR) as an indicator of liver cell terminal differentiation we sought a tissue-culture model that could be experimentally manipulated. The Aim of this study was to uncover the molecular elements that regulate ASGR expression during hepatocellular differentiation. We performed the studies in the human cell line, HuH-7. The simple experimental paradigm of HuH-7 mimics the importance of cell density as a regulatory element seen in fetal hepatocytes during differentiation and can be rigorously controlled. Methods and Results: The expression of ␣-fetoprotein decreased and albumin increased while the level of GAPDH remained unchanged as HuH-7 cells approached confluence. As we previously demonstrated in developing mouse liver, ASGR binding activity and the steady state level of receptor protein increased as the cells approach a more differentiated state. Metabolic labelling of HuH-7 cells confirmed that the increase in ASGR was the direct result of increased receptor synthesis. Total RNA was isolated from cells at high and low density for Northern blot analysis and probed with an ASGR H 2 b subunit specific cDNA sequence. The observed increase in ASGR expression in the absence of a concomitant increase in transcript abundance indicated that ASGR expression was regulated at a posttranscriptional level. To determine the posttranscriptional mode of regulation, membrane-bound polysomal RNA was isolated and probed with the H 2 b specific sequence. The absence of ASGR mRNA in the membrane fraction in proliferating cells strongly indicated that repressed expression of the receptor was regulated at the translational level. By inserting the ASGR 5' untranslated region (UTR) between the SV40 promoter and the firefly luciferase AUG start site of a reported plasmid (pCBG99), we demonstrated that the regulated expression of luciferase activity in transfected HuH-7 cells was dependent upon the state of HuH-7 differentiation. Adaptation of an electrophoretic mobility shift assay provided the means to directly compare the specific activity of trans-acting factor in cytosol isolated from cells at different proliferative states. The observed increase in the specific activity of trans-acting factor in quiescent HuH-7 suggests an activation pathway was responsible for de-repression of ASGR translation during hepatocellular differentiation. Conclusion: Taken together, the results obtained from cell culture and in vitro experiments provide support for the notion that protein interaction with the ASGR 5' UTR plays an important regulatory role in differentiation-dependent translation.

body_text.text: Introduction: The apical sodium-dependent bile acid transporter (ASBT) mediates bile acid transport in the ileum, kidney and bile ducts. Extensive analyses of the transcriptional regulation of ASBT have been performed. Previous studies have indicated that transcriptional regulation alone cannot fully explain the ontogenic regulation of the rat ASBT (J. Clin. Invest. 1995, 95:745; Am. J. Physiol. 1996, 271:G377). The following studies focused on elements in ASBT that might influence RNA stability. Methods: Full-length (3.1 kb), 1.7 kb and 0.3kb of rASBT 3' untranslated region RNA (3'UTR), all of which contained the poly(A) signal, were subcloned downstream of an SV-40 promoter driven luciferase reporter (pGL3) and also downstream of a c-fos promoter driven ␤-globin (pBBB) gene reporter (Genes Dev. 1991, 5:221). Rat IEC-6 cells were transfected with the luciferase reporter constructs followed by luciferase assays, or with the pBBB expression constructs to examine the ␤-globin mRNA half-life by Northern blot analysis. Serum withdrawal was used to terminate transcription of the pBBB-rASBT constructs. Band-shift assays were performed with the IEC-6 cytoplasmic extract and the 3ЈUTR fragments transcribed in vitro from the pSPT-rASBT/3Ј7UTR constructs. Results: Appropriate sized mRNA transcripts were identified by Northern blotting using the pGL3 and pBBB systems. The hybrid constructs containing the 0.3kb, 1.7kb and 3.1kb of the 3'UTR expressed 17%, 5% and 1.5%, respectively, of the luciferase activity possessed by the SV-40 driven pGL3 construct harboring no rASBT 3'UTR. Steady-state mRNA levels of these hybrid constructs were similarly effected by the rASBT 3'UTR. ␤-globin mRNA stability decreased with increasing length of rASBT 3'UTR, as shown by half-lives of 36.5, 2.8, 1.6 and 0.9, hours for the pBBB-rASBT 3'UTR hybrid mRNAs containing none, the 0.3kb, 1.7kb and 3.1kb 3'UTR, respectively. Band-shift assays revealed multiple RNA-protein bands formed with all the three 3'UTR fragments, suggesting that cis-trans interactions at this region may be involved in the regulation of rASBT mRNA decay, as seen in the half-life analysis of the ␤-globin mRNA chimeras. Conclusion: The 3'UTR of the rASBT gene contains sequences that may have significant effects on mRNA stability. These elements may have a major impact on the regulation of bile acid transport in the ileum, kidney and bile ducts.

body_text.text: Aims: We reported Wee1 kinase was a down-stream target existing from TGF-b1-mediated G1 cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in human HCC at last AASLD meeting. We present here inhibition of Wee1 kinase induced apoptosis in human HCC cell lines through de-phosphorylation of Tyr15 on cdc2, suggesting that molecular targeting of Wee1 kinase can be an exceptional option for eradication of human HCC. Materials and Methods: Materials and Methods°jHuman HCC cell lines, HuH2, HuH7 and HepG2, were maintained in DMEM supplemented with 5% of FCS, while TGF-b1 (2ng/ml) treatment was performed in medium containing 0.1%FCS. The cell population at each cell cycle was analyzed by FACS and the protein expression was determined by immunoblotting. To inhibit Wee1 kinase, we adopted either a chemical inhibitor PD (PD166286, kindly gifted Pfizer Pharmatheutical Co.) or short hairpin RNA (shRNA) cloned into plasmid expression vector, which targeted two different sites of Wee1 kinase mRNA. Roscovitine was used for inhibition of cdc2 kinase activity in TGF-b1-or PD-treated cells. HCC tissue samples surgically resected were stained with an anti-Wee1kinase antibody using DAKO EnVision system. (We obtained informed consent from each patient for using their HCC samples). Results: TGF-b1 induced apoptosis through down-regulation of Wee1 kinase, followed by de-phosphorylation of Tyr 15 on cdc2, and this apoptosis was inhibited by pretreatment with roscovitine. PD treatment also stimulated apoptosis in HuH2, HepG2 and HuH7 in a dose dependent manner resulting in a decrease of cell number on day 7. Pretreatment with roscovitine completely suppressed PD-mediated apoptosis in HuH7 cells. Moreover, HuH7R, which was isolated from HuH7 cells as a resistant clone against TGF-b1mediated apoptosis, exhibited resistant to PD-induced apoptosis.

body_text.text: Colorectal cancer is one of the most common malignancies worldwide. Gene therapy with immunostimulatory molecules seems to be a promising approach in cancer therapy. Flt3L has evolved as a very potent hematopoetic cytokine augmenting the numbers of Dendritic Cells (DC) and Natural Killer (NK) cells in mice and humans as well as effecting growth and differentiation of progenitor and stem cells. DCs play a major role in antigen presentation and in the induction and regulation of immune responses and are therefore thought to play a major role in the antitumor immunity. In this study we describe a gene-therapeutic approach to stimulate antitumor immunity by a adenoviral mediated transfer of Flt3L. We generated and produced an adenovirus expressing the Flt3L gene (pAdFlt3L) and confirmed expression by Western Blot and ELISA: in vitro infection of a mouse colon carcinoma cell line (CT26) with adenoviral vector expressing Flt3L induced high levels of Flt3L in the supernatants as well as in the cell lysates. We injected CT26 cells subcutaneously into the flank of 4-week-old, female BALB/c mice as a model of colon carcinoma liver metastasis. After 13 days tumor nodules were palpable. Flt3L immunotherapy was initiated 13 days after tumor inoculation by injecting 109pAdFlt3L into the tail vein or directly into the tumor. High levels of Flt3L in the serum of pAdFlt3L-treated mice during the first 3 days after i.v. as well as i.t. injection were detected by ELISA with a maximum Flt3L level after 24 hours, but with an approximately 1000 to 10000 fold higher Flt3L level after i.v.-treatment. Interestingly animals with a second infection 7 days after the first infection showed a second peak of Flt3L levels showing the low immunogenicity of the adenoviral vector. Spleen size and weight was strongly augmented in mice treated with pAdFlt3L. Analyzing the specific array of surface markers of DCs by FACS, therapy with Flt3L was shown to cause a remarkable increase of DCs in treated animals. Tumor infiltration by high frequencies of DCs could be detected by H.E. staining and differentiated by anti-CD11b and anti-CD11c staining corresponding with high serum levels of Flt3L in tumor bearing mice. Furthermore we vaccinated a group of mice with CT26-cell lysate and coinjected the Flt3L adenovirus s.c. Mice in the vaccinated group were challenged with the CT26 cell line; while in the control group all mice died, in the vaccination a approximately 100%survival was observed, demonstrating the potential of costimulation with Flt3L. Our results indicate that immunostimulatory antitumor effects are provided by Flt3L adenoviral therapy through stimulation and proliferation of DCs.

body_text.text: Hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) is a potent mitogen for hepatocytes. Recent studies have shown that, depending on the physiological conditions, HGF enhances hepatocyte function without stimulating proliferation. However, the mechanisms of dual activity of HGF are unknown. p53, a transcription factor, is recognized traditionally as a cell-growth suppressor because the expression of p53 and the G 1 cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor, p21 WAF1/CIP1 , is closely linked in various cell lines and malignant tissues. Aim: To examine the significance of the relationship between p53 and p21 in the regulation of hepatocyte proliferation stimulated by HGF. Methods and Results: 1) In vivo experiments: Five to six week old male SD rats were subjected to a two-thirds resection of the liver or a sham operation. After the partial hepatectomy, hepatic p53 protein levels were elevated with increased hepatic HGF levels. Following the increase of HGF and p53, an increase of p21 protein levels was not significant. In contrast, after the sham operation, a minor, but significant increase in hepatic HGF and p53 levels was observed followed by a prominent increase of p21 levels. 2) In vitro experiments: Primary rat hepatocytes were seeded at low and high densities. In the presence of HGF, DNA synthesis was increased in a dose related manner in hepatocytes cultured at low density, but not in hepatocytes cultured at high density. Cellular p53 levels increased in the hepatocytes cultured at low and high densities following the addition of HGF. In addition, p21 levels in hepatocytes cultured at high density were increased after HGF addition, and correlated with cellular p53 levels. However, no significant increase of p21 was observed in the low-density culture. When the activity of p53 was suppressed in hepatocytes cultured at high-density in the presence of HGF by pifithrinalpha, an inhibitor of p53, cellular p21 levels were reduced and DNA synthesis was significantly increased. Treatment with p21 antisense oligonucleotide in addition to HGF resulted in a similar increase of DNA synthesis in high-density cultured hepatocytes. Discussion and Conclusions: Our results suggest that p53 expression in rat hepatocytes is stimulated by HGF, and, when p53 induces p21 expression, DNA synthesis by hepatocytes is suppressed by the p21. Previously, we reported that the mitogenic activity of HGF depends on the increased activity of transforming growth factor alpha induced by p53 in proliferating hepatocytes (Hepatology 2002;36:336-44). Taken together, the induction of diverse effector genes by p53, depending on the physiological situation, may regulate the hepatocyte proliferation stimulated by HGF.

body_text.text: Efficient and prolonged siRNA silencing approach and target site for anti-HBV replication on HepG2.2.15 cells Recent studies have demonstrated a great therapeutic potent of inhibition of HBV replication using siRNA silencing technology in. both vitro and in vivo. Among the several critical criteria for applying the siRNA silencing technique in clinical treatment, the choice of the targeted sequence within HBV genome by designed siRNA is the important determinant for inhibitory efficacy, and the primary activation forms, e.g. siRNA or shRNA, exerts the influence to the efficacy as well. To efficiently screen the siRNA target sites for anti-HBV replication, we have succeeded to establish the screening protocol using PCR-based HBV siRNA expression cassette (SECs) and has applied it to screen several potential siRNA target site within HBV genome with the HBV viral producing cell line, HepG2.2.15. The results have shown that, among total of four tested siRNA targeting sites including two of them in the different positions on HBsAg gene and another two on HBV preC and HBeAg genes, the siRNA targeted to HBV S gene at 458 to 478 bases position and designed as SECs-S2 has demonstrated the greatest inhibition effects on HBV DNA replication and on both HBsAg and HBeAg productions with the inhibitory rate of 87.49 % and 66.8 %, respectively. The inhibitory effects by SECs-S2 has further showed a dose dependent fashion and up to 10 days of prolonged inhibition period with started at very first day, peaked at second day and maintained at peak inhibitory effects until day 7-day 8 of post transfection on the HBV viral producing HepG2.2.15 cells. On the other hands, the variability of the tested cells were maintained in constant and SECs-S2 siRNA cassette didn't shown any effects to the lucuferase activity in the cotransfection experiment with luciferase expression vector and SECs-S2 siRNA cassette. These data indicated that SECs-S2 siRNA specifically targeted to HBV genome RNA. In conclusion of the presented study, PCR-based HBV siRNA expression cassette is an efficient approach that can be used to optimize the targeting sites for siRNA silencing. The site at 458 to 478 bases pair of HBsAg gene exposes the great potential as siRNA -base therapeutics target for anti-HBV.

body_text.text: Liver transplantation is the only curative treatment for advanced liver cirrhosis. Therapies aimed at halting the progression of the disease are urgently needed. Previous studies have shown that the administration of recombinant insulin-like growth factor-I (IGF-I) induced hepatoprotective effects and corrected hypogonadism in experimental cirrhosis. In this study, we analyzed the efficacy of a Simian Virus 40 vector (rSV40) encoding IGF-I (rSVIGF-I) to prevent cirrhosis progression. Mice injected intraportally with rSV40 encoding luciferase (rSVLuc) showed hepatic expression of the transgene for more than 7 months. Luciferase expression was low but increased significantly in CCl4-damaged livers and upon IGF-I administration, thus favouring transgene expression from vectors encoding this hormone. Healthy male Wistar rats were treated by intraportal injection of rSVIGF and liver cirrhosis was induced by CCl4 inhalation during 36 weeks. At the end of the study the hepatic levels of IGF-I mRNA and of IGFBP3 protein (an IGF-I binding protein whose synthesis is induced by IGF-I) were higher in rSVIGF-I-treated rats than in control cirrhotic animals. Cirrhotic rats treated with rSVIGF-I had reduced serum bilirubin, serum transaminases and liver fibrosis scores as well as increased intrahepatic expression of Hepatocyte Growth Factor as compared to control cirrhotic animals. Furthermore, cirrhotic animals showed testis atrophy and altered spermatogenesis while both testicular size and histology were normal in those cirrhotic rats that received rSVIGF-I therapy. Our results show that rSV40mediated sustained expression of IGF-I in the liver slowed cirrhosis progression.

body_text.text: Background/Aims: Understanding the host response to HCV infection is critical to the development of strategies to alter its pathogenesis. We used a HCV cell-based system to examine the interaction of HCV infection and host immunity. We also used a microarray-based approach to compare mRNA expression patterns during HCV expression to (1) define how HCV regulates host gene expression; and (2) assess which HCV viral proteins are responsible for specific gene regulation. Methods: Using transcriptional profiling microarray (70-mer, Human Operon Set version 1.1 and CodeLink, GE), mRNA expression patterns were profiled after transfection Huh-T7 cell (Huh7 cells stably expressing T7 polymerase) with pH77, a full length infectious genotype 1 HCV construct under the control of the T7 promoter. These patterns were compared with those produced by pGEM (empty vector) transfection of Huh-T7 cells. Selected upregulated genes were confirmed by real-time PCR. In addition, subgenomic constructs corresponding to the HCV structural and each of the non-structural proteins were transiently transfected into Huh-T7 cells to evaluate which HCV proteins were associated with upregulation of identified host genes. As an independent means of validating the findings, a full length HCV 1b replicon (Huh7-2-3) was also utilized. Results: Of the 13,971 genes profiled in the Human Operon set, 78 were up-regulated and 56 were down-regulated at least two-fold by HCV expression. These 134 genes include cell signaling, immune defense, cytokine, cytoskeletal, cell cycle, apoptosis, and cell metabolism genes. Among these genes, TGF-b1 was up-regulated in both microarray systems. Because of its pivotal role in fibrogenesis, and its potentially important role in host immune regulation, TGF-b1 was further characterized. Realtime PCR analysis confirmed TGF-b1 upregulation by pH77. TGF-b1 was also upregulated (4.7 fold) by Huh7-2-3 cells compared to parental Huh7 cells. HCV subgenomic analysis revealed that in addition to the full-length HCV construct pH77, HCV structural proteins (core-E1-E2), core, and NS5A produced comparable degrees of upregulation of TGF-b1 gene expression. In contrast, NS3, NS4A, NS4B, NS5B and the unrelated protein GFP had no effect on TGF-b1 expression. Conclusions: We conclude that HCV expression significantly stimulates TGF-b1 gene expression. In particular, HCV core and NS5A each upregulate TGF-b1. The up-regulation of TGF-b1 expression in an independent replicon system suggests that this finding is broadly applicable across multiple models of HCV replication and that viral protein expression may directly contribute to hepatic fibrogenesis.

However the molecular basis mechanism for DCP production is still unknown. Vitamin K-dependent ␥-glutamyl carboxylase (GGCX) is known as the enzyme that converts prothrombin precursor/DCP into normal prothrombin. In the current study, we identified novel splicing variant of GGCX and its function on DCP production in HCC cell lines. Methods: Eleven HCC cell lines (PLC, HepG2, Hep3B, Huh7, Huh1, JHH2, JHH4, JHH1, HLF, SKHep1, and HLE) were analyzed. DCP producing levels were analyzed by Western blot analysis. Sequencing analysis showed that splicing variant of GGCX (VT-GGCX) was expressed in DCP producing HCC cell lines.

body_text.text: Prolonged hepatic hypoxia is a common underlying event in most chronic liver diseases. The metabolic response for adaptation in chronic liver hypoxia is poorly understood. Chronic hypoxia, results in an increase in nutrient supply which provides cells with energy for survival. This is accomplished by increase uptake of glucose through the plasma membrane via glucose transporter 1, 2 and 3. Hypoxia-inducible factor 1 (HIF-1) activates transcription of genes encoding proteins that mediate the adaptive response to hypoxia. These genes include erythropoietin, VEGF and glycolytic enzymes. In the present study, we determined the hepatic expression of hypoxia-inducible factor 1 (HIF-1) in hypoxia and of downstream genes that carry the hypoxic response element (HRE) related to glucose metabolism such GLUT-1 and 3. GLUT-2 was evaluated but it is a NON-HRE gene. Adult male Spragne-Dawley (SD) (n ϭ 6-8) rats were kept in a hypoxic chamber at 10% O2 level (hypoxic groups) and a control group kept at 21% O2 level (normoxic groups) for 7, 14, 21 and 28 days. Animals were killed by decapitation at the appropriate time points and blood and liver samples were collected. Samples from normoxic and hypoxic rats were analyzed for different genes and proteins using histological analysis, immunohistochemistry, Western Blotting (WB) and EMSA and serum ALT, hematocrit, lipid peroxides (total 8-isoprostane) were also measured. Our results showed that there was a significant increase in the hematocrit from day 7 to day 28 in the hypoxic rats. The liver morphology, serum ALT and total 8-isoprostane levels were normal in both groups. Nitrotyrosine protein levels were not significantly increased at any of the time-points. Results from immunohistochemistry showed that HIF-1 alpha was expressed at the nuclei of the sinusoidal liver cells and hepatocytes. GLUT-1 was expressed by the endothelial cells in the pericentral lobular veins. GLUT-2 and GLUT-3 were expressed by the hepatocytes in the liver parenchyma. WB analysis showed that the GLUT 1-3 proteins were upregulated from day 7 to day 28 (p Ͻ 0.05). HIF-1 alpha (EMSA) was upregulated in hypoxic liver when compared to the normoxic control from day 7 to day 28 (p Ͻ 0.01). Our data suggest that the metabolic adaptive ability of the liver in chronic hypoxia triggers compensatory mechanisms for survival by increasing the availability of glucose through upregulation of GLUT 1-3 mediated at least in part, by HIF-1 alpha. This adaptive response probably prevents the increase in oxidant stress and liver damage.

body_text.text: We have previously shown that 12-14 weeks treatment is effective in HCV-2 or -3 patients in whom HCV-RNA become undetectable after 4 weeks of therapy (rapid virologic response, RVR). Aims: To identify predictors of SVR, RVR and relapse following short treatment. Patients: Data from two sets of patients (from Italy and Norway) were pooled (nϭ 403); patients had been treated with PegIFN ␣-2b (1.0, nϭ281 or 1.5 g/kg, nϭ122) and ribavirin (800-1200 mg) for 12-14 or 24 weeks, depending on negative or positive HCV-RNA at week 4. Patients were Ͻ45 yrs (51%), 58% were males, infected with HCV-2 (60 %), 53% had low (Ͻ600,000 IU/ml) viremia, 78% had absence of bridgingfibrosis/cirrhosis. and 57% moderate/severe steatosis. Methods: Primary end point was undetectable HCV-RNA 24 weeks after therapy (SVR). Possible predictors of SVR, RVR and relapse following short treatment were analyzed by logistic regression models. Results: SVR was obtained in 313/403 patients (78%). SVR differed between cases with or without RVR (85% vs 62%, PϽ.0001), mild or bridging fibrosis/ cirrhosis (82% vs 67%, Pϭ.004), absent/mild or moderate/severe steatosis (84% vs 72%, Pϭ.014), HCV-2 or -3 (81% vs 73%, Pϭ.05) low or high viremia (80% vs 67%, Pϭ.05). In a logistic regression model, RVR (OR 2.48, CI 1.12 -5.0), mild fibrosis (OR 2.39, CI 1.12 -5.1), and HCV-2 (OR 2.07, CI 1.03 -4.1) were independent predictors of SVR. RVR was obtained in 274/403 (68%) patients, 163/242 (67%) HCV-2, and 111/161 (69%) HCV-3. Patients with RVR had, as compared to those without RVR, more frequently low grade steatosis (72% vs 64%, Pϭ.011), mild fibrosis (70% vs 63%, Pϭ.03), and high PegIFN dose (78% vs 64%, Pϭ.005); RVR was independent of viral load. In a logistic regression model, absence of severe fibrosis independently predicted RVR (OR 0.35, CI 0.18 -0.68). In RVR patients, SVR was achieved in 85% of both HCV-2 and HCV-3. Virologic relapse was observed in 29/274 RVR patients (10.6%), and was more frequently observed among those with low ALT levels (14% vs 5%, Pϭ.033), high viremia (14% vs 6%, Pϭ.018), and severe fibrosis (18% vs 8%, Pϭ.011). Peg-IFN dose, steatosis and genotype were not associated with risk of relapse. Severe fibrosis (OR 2.75, CI 1.19-6.4) and low ALT (OR 0.08, CI 0.01 -0.63) were independent predictors of relapse. Conclusion: In HCV-2 or -3, the HCVRNA status after 4 weeks of therapy may guide treatment duration. Short treatment duration is effective in both HCV-2 and -3 patients with RVR, but those with severe fibrosis are less likely to experience both RVR and SVR, and more frequently relapse off therapy.

body_text.text: Objectives: To evaluate efficacy, safety, and impact on natural history of PegIFN␣-2b (1.0 g/kg) and ribavirin (800-1000 mg/ daily), administered for 24 weeks, in type C decompensated cirrhosis. Patients and Methods: From Sept 2003 to May 2004, 78 consecutive pts, admitted for ascites (72%), variceal bleeding (16%), encephalopathy (18%), naïve to therapy, were offered treatment: 40 pts agreed and those who did not (nϭ38) served as controls. Therapy was started when pts were compensated. Treated and control pts presented, respectively, in Child-Pugh (CP) class A (13% and 5%), B (60% and 61%) and C (27% and 34%); their respective mean ages were 63 Ϯ 9 vs 65 Ϯ 7; HCV-1 was typed in 60% and 79%. The main end point was the effect of therapy on the natural history, estimated by the Kaplan-Meier method. Undetectable HCV-RNA 24 weeks off therapy (SVR) and safety were secondary end points. Results: 3 pts dropped out prematurely for intolerance. Antiviral therapy was associated with 20 adverse events (4 severe infection with death, 12 mild infections, 2 bleedings, and 2 HCC); during the same span of time, 20 events were registered in controls (4 severe infections with death, 7 mild infections, 5 bleedings, and 4 HCC). All but one severe infections occurred in CP class C. SVR rates were achieved in 8/40 pts (20%), including 6/13 HCV-2 (46%) and 2/27 HCV-1 (7%). After 19Ϯ1,3 months of follow up, the mean CP score, as compared to basal value, improved in pts with SVR (8Ϯ1,3 vs 7Ϯ0,8), was unchanged in non responders (7,9Ϯ1,3 vs 8,2Ϯ1,4), and worsened in controls (8,6Ϯ1,5 vs 9,3Ϯ1,7). In the 64 surviving pts without OLT, CP score at follow up, as compared to basal value, decreased by at least 1 point in 6/8 (75%) pts with SVR, in 4/26 (15%) non-responders and 1/30 (3%) controls; was unchanged in 2 SVR pts (25%), 11 non responders (42%) and 9 controls (30%), and increased by at least 1 point in 11 non-responders (42%) and 20 controls (66%) (pϭ0.001). At Kaplan-Meier evaluation, the number of decompensated events were significantly reduced during the follow up in pts with SVR, as compared to both unresponsive and control pts (Figure) . Conclusions: In decompensated cirrhotics, combination therapy is poorly tolerated, and unsafe in CP class C. The obtained SVR rates are encouraging for HCV-2, but not for HCV-1 pts. In pts with SVR, therapy positively influences natural history of the disease.

This was a prospective randomized clinical trial where treatment-naïve HCV genotype-1 subjects received either CIFN 15 mcg TIW and weight-based generic ribavirin (Ribasphere) (group 1) or PEG-Intron 1.5 mcg/ kg/week and weight based ribavirin (Rebetol), (group 2). Methods: 59 subjects were enrolled, 30 in group 1 and 29 in group 2. Treatment lasted 48 weeks if HCV RNA was undetectable at week 24, otherwise drugs were discontinued. SVR was determined at week 72. Safety laboratory tests and adverse events (AE) assessments were done monthly. To date all subjects have completed week 48 and 56 subjects have finished week 72. Results: At baseline the 2 groups were similar in gender (67% men), age (mean ϭ 44 years), weight (202 lbs men, 152 lbs women), ethnicity (59% Caucasian, 30% African American), high viral load (75%, mean levels: 3.8 and 3.6 million IU/mL for groups 1 and 2) and hemoglobin (mean: 15 g/dL). Cirrhosis was diagnosed in 3 subjects of group 1 and 5 subjects of group 2. The SVR was similar for both groups: 37% for CIFN/RBV and 35% for PEGIFN/RBV. The week 48 and SVR by viral load were: No subject dropped hemoglobin to Ͻ8.5 g/dL. Neutrophils dropped to Ͻ750/uL in 13% and 24% of groups 1 and 2, respectively (pϭ 0.29). Dose modification for one or two drugs were required in 37% and 62% in each of the 2 groups (pϭ0.09). AE were flu-like symptoms in 100% and 93%, headache in 63% and 39%, fatigue in 77% and 50%, mood disorders in 67% and 66%. Serious AE were observed in 6 subjects (3 per group) (cellulitis, severe fatigue, psychosis, seizure, dehydration, EtOH recidivism, and pyelonephritis). Conclusion: CIFN/RBV combination therapy elicited a comparable SVR to PEGIFN/RBV in previously untreated subjects with genotype-1 chronic HCV. There were no relapsers among the CIFN/RBV treated group. The AE profile for CIFN/RBV demonstrated less neutropenia and dose reductions. A larger clinical trial for genotype-1 chronic HCV infection utilizing CIFN and ribavirin is warranted.

In large treatment trials the mean vitality score, as measured by the questionnaire short form 36 (SF-36), is significantly improved in those who obtain a sustained virological response (SVR). However, a significant change in large trials does not necessarily reflect an important difference. The aim of this study was to determine the number of patients who experience an important change (improvement or worsening) in vitality score after HCV treatment. Materials and methods: Pegylated interferon-␣-2b and ribavirin was administered to 76 patients with HCV genotype 2 or 3. The health related quality of life questionnaire SF-36 was administered before and 6 months after treatment. From the answers to 4 of the 36 questions in SF-36 a vitality score was calculated. Previous calculations of the minimal important difference (MID) have consistently found half a standard deviation (SD) to be a threshold for discriminating differences in psychometric testing. We therefore chose 1 ⁄2 SD of the calculated vitality score as MID.

Virus like particles (VLP) expressing the HCV structural proteins as well as synthetic peptides representing well-characterized CTL epitopes might serve as an effective therapeutic vaccine. The humanized trimera mouse model was used to study the immunogenicity of these vaccine candidates in a preclinical animal model. Irradiated Balb/c mice were transplanted with nod.scid mouse bone marrow and reconstituted with human blood lymphocytes (PBMC) from three HLA A2.1 positive chronic HCV patients. These so-called trimera mice were vaccinated intraperitoneally with VLP expressing the structural proteins core, E1 and E2 or with a mixture of HLA A2 restricted synthetic peptide CTL epitopes from the HCV core, E1, E2 or NS3 region. PBMC were recovered 10 days after vaccination and T cell analysis was performed with tetramer staining or gIFN Elispot assay with recombinant HCV antigens, overlapping HCV peptides or the respective CTL epitopes. HCV specific T cell responses could be detected in trimera mice reconstituted with PBMC from two out of three chronic HCV patients, although such responses were undetectable in donor PBMC. Alternatively, instead of PBMC reconstitution, HCV-infected human liver tissue was implanted under the kidney capsule of the trimera mice. HCV quantification in the trimera serum and HE-staining of implanted liver grafts was performed at different time points. Viremia was detectable in several mice for more than three weeks after implantation and histological staining showed viable liver tissue up to this point.

Background: Valopicitabine (NM283) reduces serum hepatitis C virus (HCV) RNA levels in patients and in chronically infected chimpanzees, and is currently in phase II clinical development for the treatment of chronic hepatitis C. NM283 is an orally bioavailable prodrug of NM107 (2'-C-methylcytosine), which inhibits flavi-and pestivirus replication in vitro and shows enhanced antiviral activity in combination with interferon alfa. The present study evaluated the potential for the development of resistance to NM283 using NM107 and a bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) in vitro infection model. BVDV is a pestivirus related to HCV.

However, although prolonged NM107 treatment can eradicate BVDV in a cell line persistently infected with ncp BVDV, lower concentrations of NM107 led to selection of resistant virus after 3 to 5 cell passages. Sequencing revealed resistance was due to a S405T amino acid substitution near the start of the B domain motif of the BVDV NS5B polymerase, confirming that the polymerase is the target for NM107. This motif is highly conserved among positive-strand RNA viruses, including HCV, predicting that the equivalent mutation in HCV polymerase is S282T. The NM107-resistant BVDV strains show at least 50-fold reduced susceptibility to NM107, accompanied by decreased replication fitness in vitro: "small plaque" phenotype, slow growth kinetics and lower virus titers. Importantly, the S405T mutant virus showed ϳ38 fold increased susceptibility to IFN ␣-2b compared to wild type BVDV. Consis-tent with this finding, no viral resistance developed in vitro when NM107 was used in combination with Intron A. To date, we have been unable to find additional compensatory mutations that restore the phenotype of the S405T mutant BVDV to that of wild type.

body_text.text: Background: HCV infection is manifested by a high rate of viral persistence related to high viral mutability as well as diminished CTL effector function. We have previously identified a T cell receptor (TCR) that has relatively high affinity for HLA A2-restricted HCV NS3 1406-1415 peptide. The purpose of this study was to determine whether gene transfer of this TCR into peripheral blood lymphocytes (PBL) from normal healthy controls could induce HCV-specific reactivity that would respond to wild-type and mutant virus. Methods: TCR alphaƒnand beta chain genes from the HCV-specific TCR were cloned and inserted into a retroviral vector capable of delivering the genes into human T cells. The ability of transferred TCR genes to confer HCV reactivity to PBL from 3 healthy donors was evaluated using IFN-gamma production following stimulation with wild type or mutant peptide. Results: TAP-deficient T2 cells were loaded with wild type NS3 1406-1415 peptide (KLVALGINAV), eight different naturally occurring viral mutants (V1408L, A1409T, I1412V, I1412L, I1412N, V1408T and the multiple substituted peptides A1409G/I1412L/ V1408T and V1408S/A1409G/I1412L), or a melanoma control peptide. TCR-transduced PBL (both CD4ϩ and CD8ϩ T cells) produced statistically significant amounts of IFN-gamma following stimulation with wild type HCV peptide and 7 of the 8 HCV mutant peptides but not with melanoma peptide. Moreover, TCRtransduced PBL recognized endogenously processed peptide. Conclusions: We demonstrate the ability to engineer normal PBLderived T cells to specifically recognize HCV independent of immune status. By providing T cell help as well as effector function, this approach represents a promising immunotherapy. Moreover, the ability of TCR-transduced PBL to recognize mutants suggests this approach might prevent antigenic escape variants.

body_text.text: Background: SCH 503034, is an orally active Hepatitis C virus NS3 serine protease inhibitor that exhibits potent and specific in vitro antiviral activity. We report results from our Phase I clinical development program evaluating the pharmacokinetics (PK) and safety of SCH 503034 oral capsules in healthy subjects. Methods: In this randomized, single rising dose, double-blind study, healthy subjects were randomized 2:1 to receive, SCH 503034 oral capsules, (nϭ6/group ) 50 mg, 100 mg, 200 mg, 400 mg, 600 mg, 800 mg or placebo (nϭ3/group). Plasma samples were collected at multiple time points to 120h post-dose. Samples were analyzed by validated LC-MS/MS with a LOQ of 0.5 ng/ml. Pharmacokinetics were analyzed using model independent methods. Safety was assessed by clinical laboratory tests, vital signs, ECGs, physical exams and occurrence of adverse events Results: Fifty-four subjects completed the study, 36 received SCH 503034, 18 received placebo. SCH 503034 was rapidly absorbed following oral administration of capsules (mean Tmax:1-2.25 h across the 6 dosing levels). After attaining Tmax, plasma SCH503034 concentrations declined in a bi-phasic manner, with a mean terminal phase half-life (T 1/2 ) of 7.0 to 15 h. Cmax and AUC increased in a dose-related manner. The safety profiles were similar in subjects receiving SCH 503034 and placebo. Conclusions: SCH 503034 was readily bioavailable when administered as a single dose in an oral capsule formulation and was well tolerated in subjects receiving up to 800 mg orally.

Here, we have identified a lipophilic long-chain base compound, NA255, from a secondary fungal metabolite, as a novel small molecule HCV replication inhibitor using an HCV subgenomic replicon cell culture system. HCV replicon 1b cellbased assay showed that the replication was suppressed by NA255 in a dose-dependent manner with a mean of 50% inhibitory concentration (IC50) of 2 nM. NA255 had no effect on hostcell viability (IC50Ͼ50,000 nM) and cell cycle progression. We found that NA255 prevents the de novo synthesis of sphingolipids, major lipid raft components, thereby inhibiting serine palmitoyltransferase and disrupting the association among HCV nonstructural (NS) viral proteins on the lipid rafts. To determine whether HCV protein could interact directly with sphingolipids, we searched for the sphingolipid-binding domain (SBD) in HCV NS protein. We found that NS5B protein has a SBD in the molecular structure and that the interaction of NS5B with sphingolipids could be involved in HCV replicon replication. Thus, NA255 is a potent anti-HCV replication inhibitor that targets host lipid raft, suggesting that inhibition of sphingolipid metabolism may provide a novel therapeutic strategy for treatment of HCV infection.

body_text.text: Background: Cleavage of the HCV polyprotein by the NS3 protease releases proteins essential for viral propagation. Additionally, NS3-mediated cleavage of host factors integral to Interferon Response Factor-3 signaling may result in abrogated cellular responses to IFN. Thus, blockage of NS3 activity is expected to inhibit HCV replication by direct suppression of viral production and restoration of host IFN responsiveness. SCH 503034, reversibly binds the HCV NS3 protease and specifically inhibits its activity. Methods: SCH 503034 NS3 binding activity was determined spectrophotometrically. Anti-viral potency was assayed in HCV replicon cells exposed to increasing amounts of SCH 503034 for various times up to 15d. HCV replicon RNA and protein expression were monitored by Northern and Western analysis, respectively and replicon copy number was determined by qRT-PCR multiplex reaction. The effect of SCH 503034 on response to IFN was evaluated in replicon cells incubated with increasing amounts of SCH 503034 and IFN for 72h. Toxicity, was assessed by cell viability and doubling time. Results: SCH 503034 exhibited time-dependent inhibition of single chain NS3 with a binding constant (K i *) equal to ϳ14 nM. SCH 503034 inhibition of replicon synthesis was dose-related. The IC 50 and IC 90 for suppression of replicon synthesis following 72-h exposure were ϳ200 nM and 400 nM, respectively. Exposure of replicon cells to SCH 503034 over 15d resulted in log reductions in replicon RNA of ϳ 2.0, 3.5, and 4.0 at 1.2, 6 and 12 x IC 90 , respectively. Isobologram analysis revealed that SCH 503034 ϩ IFN-␣ was more effective than the line of additivity, though the difference was not significant (pϾ0.1). No toxicity was seen after exposure of HuH-7 cells to 50M SCH 503034 for 96 h, or primary hepatocytes to 10 x IC 90 for 1 wk. No changes in doubling times or growth rates of HuH-7 cells were seen after a 3-wk at 10 x IC 90 . Conclusions: SCH 503034 exhibited potent anti-viral activity both alone and in combination with IFN-␣ in the HCV replicon assay. The combination of SCH 503034 with IFN may lead to enhanced clinical efficacy.
