body_text.text: Background: Chronic Hepatitis C Virus (HCV) infection is the leading cause of liver transplantation worldwide. The success of transplantation, however, is compromised by the re-infection of the graft and this problem has begun to worsen in the last decade. Changes in immunosuppressive therapy may have contributed to this deterioration. The aim of this study is to determine the effect of different immunosuppressive compounds on HCV replication and determine the synergy and kinetics of inhibition. Methods: The anti-viral properties of pegylated IFN-alpha 2b (IFN) and immunosuppressive drugs were tested in vitro using an HCV-replication model. Huh-7 hepatoma cells, containing the HCV replicon with a luciferase reporter gene, were cultured for 18 hour with different doses or combinations of drugs. HCV replication was quantified based on luciferase activity, RT-PCR for viral RNA and immunocytochemistry for helicase (NS3) protein. Kinetics of inhibition was determined with the Xenogen IVIS imaging system. Results: Tacrolimus, rapamycin, dexamethason or prednisolon did not inhibit HCV replication, whereas almost complete inhibition (98%) was observed with IFN (10IU/ml). Both cyclosporin A (CsA) (0.5-5.0 ug/ml) and mycophenolic acid (MPA) (2.0-6.0 ug/ ml) blocked HCV replication up to 70%. No cell death was observed with any tested compounds. Proliferation of Huh-7 cells was reduced with MPA, but did not account for the observed inhibition of HCV replication. When CsA and MPA were combined, synergistic inhibition was observed up to 90% at higher doses. Synergistic inhibition was also observed with a combination There was a good correlation between antiviral activity and cyclophilin-binding activity of these compounds. NIM811 was selected for further research because it binds to cyclophilins with similar affinity as CsA but is devoid of significant immunosuppressive activity, as the NIM811-cyclophilin complex does not bind to calcineurin. NIM811 induced a concentration-dependent reduction of HCV RNA in replicon cells with an IC50 of 0.66 ìM at 48 hours, compared to 0.80 ìM for CsA. After a nine-day treatment of replicon cells, a three-log10 reduction of HCV RNA levels was achieved with as low as 1 ìM NIM811. Moreover, NIM811 showed equally potent activity in HCV replicons that were highly resistant to viral protease or polymerase inhibitors. Resistance against this compound appears to be difficult to generate in vitro. In vitro, combinations of NIM811 with other HCV inhibitors produced at least additive antiviral effects. Pharmacokinetic studies in rats showed a t1/2 of circa 14 hours, with hepatic concentrations 10-fold over serum levels. Toxicology studies showed no safety issue at the dose range predictive of therapeutic efficacy. In conclusion, NIM811 has potent anti-HCV activity and is several orders of magnitude less immunosuppressive than CsA in vitro. The fact that it targets a host protein and the demonstration of its uncompromised efficacy in HCV resistant against protease or polymerase inhibitors provide the rationale for combining of NIM811 with other specific antivirals to improve therapeutic efficacy and to suppress emergence of drug-escape mutants.

body_text.text: The non-structural (NS)3-4A protease is essential for hepatitis C virus (HCV) replication and a promising target for new anti-HCV therapy. VX-950, a potent and specific NS3-4A protease inhibitor, has recently demonstrated significant antiviral activity in a phase 1b trial of patients infected with HCV genotype 1 . Median reductions of 2 to 4 log10 IU per mL in serum HCV RNA concentrations were achieved after 14 days of dosing with VX-950. The degree to which a patient responds to treatment and the rate at which viral rebound is observed could in part be due to genotypic differences in sensitivity to the protease inhibitor. The rapid replication rate of hepatitis C virus, along with the poor fidelity of its polymerase, gives rise to an accumulation of mutations throughout its genome. The degree to which sequence variability in the protease region affects the catalytic efficiency of the enzyme or the binding of an inhibitor is not known. Here, we characterize the extent of sequence diversity within the NS3 protease domain of HCV isolated from 34 patients enrolled in the phase 1b trial, before dosing with VX-950. The NS3 protease domain was amplified by nested RT-PCR, cloned, and sequenced. The consensus sequence for each patient's HCV population was derived from an average of 90 independent cDNA clones. The average intra-patient amino acid quasispecies complexity (Shannon entropy) and diversity (Hamming distance) was low (0.332 Ϯ 0.109 and 0.421 Ϯ 0.195, respectively) and no correlation of quasispecies heterogeneity with HCV RNA serum concentration at baseline was observed. The interpatient (individual consensus compared to genotype 1a or 1b consensus sequence) amino acid diversity was 1% for genotype 1a and 2% for genotype 1b. Modeling analysis predicted that amino acid differences observed between consensus sequences of all these patients were expected to have little or no impact on VX-950 binding. Patient specific protease clones were then expressed and tested for inhibition by the protease inhibitor VX-950. In agreement with the modeling observation, there were no significant differences in the enzymatic IC50 of these proteases derived from different patient isolates. In conclusion, it appears that despite the observed sequence diversity in the HCV NS3 serine protease, patients may be uniformly responsive to treatment with the protease inhibitor VX-950.

body_text.text: Current therapeutic options for hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection are limited; therefore, alternative therapeutic approaches are needed. Inhibition of HCV gene expression and replication as well as immunotherapeutic concepts aimed at enhancing the cellular immune response against HCV are being explored. One promising new strategy is the use of immunomodulating agents in combination with IFN and/or ribavirin to treat HCV patients. The nontoxic immunomodulator ammonium trichloro(dioxoethylene-o,oЈ) tellurate (AS101), first developed by us has been shown to have beneficial effects in diverse preclinical and clinical studies. Most of its activities have been primarily attributed to the direct inhibition of the anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10. This immunomodulatory property was found to be crucial for the clinical activities of AS101, demonstrating the protective effects of AS101 in viral-infected mice models. AS101 have also inhibitory effect on different viral catalytic functions such as inhibition of the HIV reverse transcriptase. Phase I clinical trials with advanced cancer patients treated with AS101 showed increased production and secretion of a variety of cytokines, leading to a clear dominance in TH1 responses with a concurrent decrease in the TH2 responses. The aim of our study was to investigate the inhibitory effect of the AS101 on the catalytic activity of HCV NS3 serine protease in order to evaluate its potential as an HCV therapeutic agent. The effect of AS101 on HCV serine protease activity was analyzed in vitro using the fluorometric assay developed in our laboratory. This effect was further confirmed by our novel high-throughput in-vivo genetic screen. This screen is based on the concerted co-expression of a reporter gene and recombinant NS3 in E. coli. The effect of AS101 on HCV in-vivo was determined using a cell-based selectable subgenomic HCV RNA Huh-7 replicon system. In this system HCV RNA replication is monitored in intact cells by the enzymatic assay of placental alkaline phosphatase (SEAP) activity secreted. Our study demonstrates that AS101 specifically inhibits NS3 serine protease catalysis in a dose-dependent manner in the assay system examined. It reaches 70.3 Ϯ 9.5% inhibition at AS101 concentration of 10 mg/ml. Moreover, AS101 specifically inhibited HCV replication as determined in Huh-7 replicon system. Our results suggest that HCV NS3 serine protease is a novel target for AS101 action and of the inhibitory effect of AS101 on HCV replication involve repression of HCV NS3 serine protease.

body_text.text: The current standard of care for treatment of chronic hepatitis c virus (HCV) infection is pegylated interferon alpha plus ribavirin, a guanosine nucleoside analog with weak direct antiviral effects. This regimen results in sustained virologic response in ϳ50% of patients and is associated with significant ribavirin-related toxicity in certain patients. Novel therapeutic regimens with better safety and/or efficacy are the subject of intense interest. Targeted disruption of host cellular processes required for viral replication is being explored as a component of such regimens. Miglitol is an orally available iminosugar inhibitor of endoplasmic reticulum (ER) ␣-glucosidases approved for the treatment of non insulin-dependent (type II) diabetes. These same glucosidase enzymes are crucial for the production of functional glycosylated envelop proteins of HCV and other viruses. ER ␣-glucosidases "trim" N-linked glycan moities added to envelop proteins through cellular glycosylation pathways and, therefore, are required for association of envelope proteins with chaperones and for proper folding of envelope proteins. We hypothesized that miglitol may have utility in the treatment of HCV by prohibiting formation of the glyco-envelope of the viral particle and ultimately blocking assembly of infectious viral particles. To investigate this hypothesis, the effects of miglitol were examined using bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) as a surrogate live pestivirus and the bovine cell line MDBK. Antiviral effects of miglitol were determined alone and in combination with IFN alfacon-1, a potent type I IFN approved by regulatory agencies worldwide for the treatment of HCV. Miglitol and IFN alfacon-1 both showed antiviral activity when used alone [half maximal reduction in viral titer (EC 50 ) values were 155 M and 5 pg/mL, respectively]. Using Chuo-Talalay methods, the combination of the two drugs was investigated for additive, antagonistic or synergistic antiviral effects. Combination of IFN alfacon-1 and miglitol yielded combination index (CI) values indicative of synergy at EC 50 , EC 75 and EC 90 (CI ϭ 0.8, 0.5 and 0.3, respectively) and an isobologram analysis supported synergistic interaction. In conclusion, these data demonstrate that miglitol, a medication with an established safety profile that is indicated for use in the control of type II diabetes, has antiviral activity when used alone and displays synergistic antiviral effects when used in combination with IFN alfacon-1. Thus, the combination of miglitol and a type I IFN such as IFN alfacon-1 may have clinical utility in the treatment of chronic HCV infection. Further study is warranted While the mechanism underlying such states in the liver is still uncertain, it is suspected that the mitochondria and oxidative stress may play a central role in the pathogenesis of liver diseases in HCV infection. Tacrolimus (FK506), widely used in transplantation, has been supposed to have a capacity to protect the mitochondrial respiratory function, while it has recently shown to be ineffective to HCV replication. The aim of this study was to determine whether or not Tacrolimus protects the function of mitochondria and contributes to improvement of lipid and glucose metabolisms in a mouse model for HCV-associated liver disease. Methods: Tacrolimus was administered for three months to HCV core gene transgenic mice, which develop hepatic steatosis, insulin resistance and, finally, liver cancer. As a control, nontransgenic littermate mice were also given Tacrolimus. Levels of plasma glucose and serum insulin and lipid profiles in liver tissues were determined before and after Tacrolimus treatment. Results: In the core gene transgenic mice that were treated with Tacrolimus, steatosis was improved and lipid profile was changed to a pattern resembling that in normal mice. Insulin resistance was also improved in the core gene transgenic mice treated with Tacrolimus compared to those without Tacrolimus. Conclusions: Tacrolimus reversed the effect of the core protein in lipid and glucose metabolisms in vivo. This result may provide a new therapeutic aid for chronic hepatitis C, in which metabolic abnormalities in lipid and glucose contribute to liver pathogenesis.

body_text.text: Background: Valopicitabine (NM283) is a nucleoside analog exhibiting anti-HCV activity via inhibition of viral RNA polymerase, and is currently in phase II clinical development for the treatment of chronic hepatitis C. In a Phase IIa trial, valopicitabine has shown potent anti-HCV activity in combination with pegylated interferon (PegIFN) ␣-2a, with greater than 4.5 log 10 serum HCV RNA reduction, and no viral resistance detected for study periods up to 6 months. In that context, we are reporting pharmacokinetics (PK) of valopicitabine alone and in combination with PegIFN ␣-2b. Methods: Eligible treatment-naïve HCV-genotype 1-infected patients (18-65 yrs, with compensated, chronic liver disease, ALT Ͻ5 ϫULN and serum HCV RNA Ͼ5 log 10 IU/mL) were enrolled in this open-label trial and randomized to receive, at a 2:3 ratio, either valopicitabine monotherapy (nϭ12) or valopicitabine plus PegIFN ␣-2b (nϭ18). Oral valopicitabine was administered once daily starting with 400 mg from day 1 to day 4, 600 mg from day 5 to day 7 and 800 mg thereafter. PegIFN ␣-2b was administered by s.c. injection once weekly starting on day 8. Intensive steady-state PK sampling was performed over 8 hours on day 15 in all patients. Results: Values of steady-state PK parameters of valopicitabine, measured as plasma NM107 (the nucleoside moiety delivered by valopicitabine), were comparable when valopicitabine was administered alone or in combination with PegIFN ␣-2b (Table 1) . Geometric mean ratio (combination vs. monotherapy) and associated 90% confidence interval were 0.95 (0.83-1.11) for C max , 0.90 (0.78-1.05) for AUC 0-t , and 0.93 (0.81-1.06) for T 1/2 , indicating an absence of effect of co-administered PegIFN ␣-2b on the PK of valopicitabine. Conclusions: Co-administration of PegIFN ␣-2b did not alter the pharmacokinetics of valopicitabine, providing pharmacokinetic support for combined use of valopicitabine with PegIFN in future clinical trials for the treatment of chronic HCV infection. body_text.text: To expand the DC population in vivo, 10 g of a human flt3 ligand expressing plasmid (pUMVC3-hFLex) was dissolved in 2 ml saline and injected twice (days 0 and 6) into the tail vein of female Balb/C mice within a 5 second period (hydrodynamic delivery). Splenocytes were incubated for 3 hrs with HCV NS5coated magnetic beads in serum-free medium. The cells were harvested and cells that contained beads were purified by passage over a magnetic column. Non-ingested beads were separated from the purified splenocytes by centrifugation on a 20% Histodenz gradient. The isolated population contained Ͼ80% DCs and was used for immunization (2 x 10 6 cells inoculated in the paw of Balb/c mice). DC expression of the maturation markers CD40, CD80 and CD86 was determined before and after ingestion of NS5-coated beads, showing a significant increase of all maturation markers induced by phagocytosis. The induction of cellular immunity was assessed using a conventional CTL assay, a CFSE-Tcell proliferation assay, intracellular cytokine staining and tumor challenge (with stably NS5 expressing murine myeloma cells). Results: In immunized animals, the CTL activity was increased 3-fold compared to mock immunized mice. Accordingly, tumor challenge with syngenic SP2/0 myeloma cells transfected with and expressing the NS5 gene showed a significant, (Ͼ2-fold reduction) in tumor growth. The number of CD4 ϩ IFN-␥ ϩ cells was increased Ͼ3-fold and the number of CD4 ϩ IL-2 ϩ increased Ͼ5-fold in the DC-NS5-bead immunization group. These results paralleled the proliferative response of splenocytes to NS5 protein obtained from immunized animals with the most significant response in the CD4ϩ population of DC-NS5-bead immunized animals. Finally, this group displayed a significant humoral immune response to NS5 as well. Conclusions: The use of NS5 coated beads combines three important aspects of dendritic cell based immunization in a single step: targeting of the antigen, enrichment and maturation of dendritic cells. The induction of a strong Th1 biased T cell response makes this approach a promising new tool in therapeutic immunization in chronically HCV infected patients.

In contrast, the presence of multispecific CD4ϩ T cell response with Ͼ 10 ELISPOTs to at least 5 peptide pools (Pattern B, n ϭ 4) was associated with viral clearance even when the CD8 response was mono-specific. Pattern C, the lack of CD4ϩ T cell response coupled with vigorous CD8ϩ T cell responses to 4 or fewer pools, was associated with viral persistence (and mutational escape) in 6 patients but with spontaneous clearance in 6 others. Conclusions: Whole HCV genome analysis reveals strikingly heterogeneous responses in the acute phase of infection, although in 45% of the cases, virologic outcome could be predicted. Understanding immune profiles associated with chronicity might lead to identification of patients who would benefit from early antiviral therapy. The absence of CD4ϩ T cells (even in the presence of vigorous CD8ϩ T cell responses) is not infrequently associated with viral persistence. Further elucidation of the mechanisms underlying the failure to develop HCV-specific CD4ϩ T cells and their instructive signals during memory CD8ϩ T cell differentiation has implications for vaccine strategies. All samples were tested against the homologous genotype; those from the 3 mother-pairs also against heterologous genotypes. Percent neutralization was calculated by comparison with HCV-negative human sera. Children were grouped according to their ALT pattern during the first year of life: the first group (nϭ6) had persistently normal ALT or very mild changes (Ͻ80 IU); the second (nϭ6) developed an ALT peak (median 208, range 150-1230). In most cases, the ALT changes coincided with seroconversion (median 9 mos.), which was followed by a different viral evolution in the 2 groups, with an early increase in genetic diversity in the first group. In all children but 1, ALT levels returned to normal or slightly elevated during the second year. NAbs cross-reactive against heterologous genotypes were detected in all 3 mothers tested and in their offspring. Three of the 6 children studied within the first 4 mos. of life showed NAbs that later disappeared, suggesting their maternal origin. During follow-up, NAbs appeared in 8/12 children, after a median of 11 mos. from seroconversion. However, only transient and low-level NAbs were detected in children with mild or no ALT elevations, although the presence of strain-specific NAbs could not be ruled out. NAbs were generally more sustained in those who had previously developed acute hepatitis. The only exceptions were 2 children with acute hepatitis and a complete absence of NAbs, whose virus did not change over time; 1 had the most severe and prolonged hepatitis (ALT peak 1230). These data demonstrate that perinatal transmission of HCV occurs in the presence of broadly reactive maternal NAbs, and provide evidence that the nascent NAb response in perinatally infected children was not associated with viral clearance.

body_text.text: Here we describe quantitative studies using stable isotope labeling methods to identify protein expression changes associated with fibrosis progression in HCV-infected individuals. Quantification of more than 200 proteins revealed an apparent downregulation of lipid metabolism and antioxidant proteins during HCV-associated progression to fibrosis in vivo. Included among these differentially expressed proteins was catalase, a reported protein marker of both HBV and HCV-associated hepatocellular carcinoma. By contrast, the relative abundance of detected chaperone proteins including heat shock 27 kDa protein, another reported marker of HBV and HCV-associated hepatocellular carcinoma, remained unchanged.

body_text.text: Background: Little is known concerning the role of the innate immune response in Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection, even though CD1d-specific natural killer T cells ("NKT") represent a large fraction of cells in the liver. NKT may either protect from liver injury or be pro-inflammatory. We hypothesized that NKT cells would have altered effector function in the presence of HCV. Methods: CD1d-specific NKT hybridomas (DN32.D3), which are immortalized NKT cells, were used as a surrogate for NKT clones. Hepatocytes (HC) were isolated from littermates of 8-12 week male C57BL/6 mice with full length HCV genome (Tgϩ) or negative littermates as a control (Tg-). HC were plated in rat-collagen coated 24-well plates for culture. After 24 hours, NKT hybridomas were added for co-culture in various concentrations and with or without varying concentrations of specific ligand alpha-galactosylceramide to activate NKT. CD1d blocking antibody and isotype control were also added in some wells to confirm CD1d reactivity. ELISA for IL-2 secretion was then performed on the supernatant. Flow cytometry was also performed on both Tgϩ and Tg-hepatocytes to quantify their expression of CD1d.

RI RNA, but not genomic RNA, was also associated with serum ALT (Pϭ.01). Neither measure was correlated with serum HCV RNA level, CD4 count or alcohol use. Finally, the association between RI RNA and grade or stage remained highly significant after adjusting for age, gender, HIV status, HCV duration and alcohol use. Conclusion: Intrahepatic HCV replication is strongly associated with the severity of liver disease in patients with chronic hepatitis C infection, suggesting that active viral replication in the liver is important in the pathogenesis of HCV liver disease. HIV coinfection does not appear to influence the degree of HCV infection or replication in the liver.

In core expressing cells, there was a more rapid initial rise in mitochondrial Ca but this fell to below baseline within 30 s. The rapid decrease corresponded to MPT as evidenced by sudden loss of mitochondrial membrane potential. These findings were confirmed by measurement of cytosolic Ca changes in the presence and absence of the mitochondrial Ca uptake inhibitor, Ru-360. Mitochondrial buffering of cytosolic Ca changes after exposure to thapsigargin was constant in control cells for greater than 5 min, but in core expressing cells mitochondrial buffering of cytosolic Ca changes was transient, began to decline after 30s and was undetectable by 90s. Core protein addition to isolated mitochondria produced an increase in initial Ca uptake. However, similar to the situation in cells, mitochondria isolated from HCV transgenic mice were more sensitive to Ca-or peroxide-induced MPT in vitro. Conclusions: HCV core protein produces ER stress and an initial increase in Ca transfer from ER to mitochondria. However, in response to prolonged stress, core increases mitochondrial sensitivity to oxidantand Ca-dependent MPT. These data suggest that the mitochondrial abnormalities associated with HCV core protein are mediated by changes of ER-mitochondrial Ca communication. Supported by NIH grant AA12863.

body_text.text: Chronic HCV infection is associated with an increased risk of developing progressive liver disease, including fibrosis, cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. The mechanism of liver disease is not fully understood but the immune system is thought to play a prominent role. Microarray analysis was used to study the global expression profiles of liver biopsies from HCV and HCV/HIVinfected individuals in an attempt to understand the cellular events associated with liver disease. Liver needle biopsies were obtained from 13 HCV and 16 HCV/HIV co-infected patients with mild, moderate or severe liver disease as evidenced by inflammation and fibrosis scores. RNA from each of these samples was isolated and compared with RNA from a pool of uninfected, healthy liver tissue.

In summary, the EGE pattern may have prognostic value in identifying individuals who are at an increased risk of either developing or progressing to a higher grade of fibrosis. body_text.section: Analysis of the gene expression data demonstrated that the global gene expression profiles of HCV and HCV/ HIV-infected individuals did not differ significantly. This suggests that while the progression of liver disease may be accelerated in the presence of HIV, the actual mechanism of liver injury is similar in both HCV and HCV/HIV-infected patients. The analysis also identified a subset of patients who share a distinct pattern of gene expression, termed the enhanced gene expression (EGE) pattern due to the high numbers of differentially expressed genes. Specifically, the EGE (ϩ) patients show a dramatic down-regulation of multiple genes associated with the FAS-apoptosis pathway and an up-regulation of lymphocyte adhesion molecules and lymphocyte-specific genes. In addition, some of the EGE (ϩ) patients may have an impairment of the both Type 1 and Type II IFN -mediated antiviral responses. This includes a lack of induction of IFN-␥, an anti-fibrogenic cytokine, relative to the EGE (-) patients.

The definite mechanisms of HCV-induced lymphoproliferation are unknown. Recently, HCV has been demonstrated to induce mutations in the BCL-6 oncogene in vitro possibly leading to deregulation of BCL-6 expression which may result in enhanced lymphoproliferation. body_text.text: We reported recently that HCV core protein induced Huh-7 cell proliferation in association with transcriptional upregulation of growth /oncogenic related genes including wnt-1 and its putative downstream target WISP2 (wnt-inducible signaling protein) (Fukutomi et al., Hepatology 2005, 41:1096) . Gene silencing by siRNA implicated wnt-1, a secreted protein as the major mediator of growth promotion. To determine the role of WISP2 in this process, we cloned its promoter and coding sequence, and performed a functional analysis. Methods: WISP2 promoter was amplified by PCR and cloned upstream of a luciferase reporter gene. The promoter activity was monitored by luciferase assay after transfection into Tet-on inducible core expressing cells or cotransfection with core gene into Huh-7 cells. The WISP2 coding sequence was amplified by PCR and cloned into an expression vector under control of a CMV promoter, and its role in cell proliferation was examined by transient transfection and a modified MTT assay. Results: Core gene expression or the presence of HCV full-length replicon significantly increased WISP2 promoter activity. The promoter activity was also induced by the culture medium from core expressing cells, suggesting secreted factor(s) may be a responsible mechanism. Sequence analysis of the WISP2 promoter revealed a TCF-1 binding motif AACAAAG, confirming it as a downstream target of wnt-1 signaling pathway. Indeed, WISP2 promoter activity was upregulated by cotransfection with the wnt-1 gene, as well as by the corresponding culture medium. Transfection of WISP2 gene significantly increased cell proliferation in a variety of liver derived cells, including Huh-7, Hep-3B, HepG2 and FOCUS. Moreover, the culture medium collected from cells transfected with WISP2 gene promoted cell growth as well, indicating WISP2 as a secreted growth factor. Conclusion: WISP2 transcription is upregulated by HCV core protein and wnt-1, confirming it as a downstream target of wnt-1 signaling. As a member of connective tissue growth factors, WISP2 protein can promote liver cell growth. Further understanding the regulation of wnt-1/WISP2 signaling by HCV core protein may provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of HCV related HCC and begins to define the critical role of viral-cellular protein interactions in this process.

body_text.text: We examined liver tissue from 30 patients with HIV/HCV coinfection and 15 patients with HCV monoinfection. Routinely processed sections were scored for grade of inflammation and stage of fibrosis. ␣-SMA expression in activated HSCs was evaluated using a monoclonal antibody to ␣-SMA, streptavidin-avidin-biotin labeled and signal visualized with diaminobenzidine. The presence of ␣-SMA immunoreactive HSCs was semiquantitatively scored (ASMA score) in portal tracts/fibrous septa and hepatic lobules (perisinusoidal) as described by Schmitt-Graf. Statistical analysis was done using the t test and logistic regression. Results: Serum ALT levels and HCV viral loads were similar in each group, and most patients had genotype 1. Seventy-seven percent of coinfected patients had CD 4 counts Ͼ200. Gender distribution was similar between the two groups with the majority of each group composed of males. Coinfected patients were younger (47Ϯ1.6 years) than HCV patients (52.2Ϯ1.7 years, pϽ0.05). The total ASMA score was similar between the two groups (3.33Ϯ0.34 vs 2.47Ϯ0.40, pϭ0.13) and the portal/septal ASMA score was similar between the two groups (1. 67Ϯ0.18 vs 1.53Ϯ0.22, pϭ0.65) . However, the perisinusoidal ASMA score was significantly higher in HIV/HCV coinfected patients (1.73Ϯ0.18) compared to HIV monoinfected patients (0.93Ϯ0.24, pϭ0.02). Coinfection with HIV was associated with a higher perisinusoidal ASMA score with an OR of 2.1. In both groups, a higher ASMA score was associated with a lower prevalence of inflammation (lower grade) with an OR of 0.46, and an OR of 0.24 when adjusted for HIV coinfection. Discussion: HIV/HCV coinfected patients progress more rapidly to cirrhosis than HCV monoinfected patients suggesting that HIVinduced immunosuppression contributes to disease progression. These coinfected patients were found to have less hepatic inflammation but increased perisinusoidal HSC activation (lower grade with higher ASMA score). Thus, immunosuppression or immune mechanisms within the liver may be associated with increased HSC activation and more rapid fibrogenesis.

body_text.text: We have previously shown that CD4 ϩ CD25 ϩ regulatory T (Tregs) cells are elevated in chronic HCV and may contribute to persistent infection by diminishing viral specific effector T cell response. Hypothesis: Treg-mediated immune regulation in HCV may alter tumor immunity and play a role in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) development. Aim: To determine CD4 ϩ CD25 ϩ Treg frequency, function, and relationship in HCV related HCC. Methods: PBMC from chronic HCV patients with HCC (nϭ20), chronic HCV patients (nϭ30), and normal controls (nϭ15) were analyzed for CD4 ϩ CD25 ϩ T cells frequency and FoxP3 expression. Peripheral CD4 ϩ CD25 ϩ T cells from HCV related HCC were cocultured with CD4 ϩ CD25in the presence of PHA to functionally define their suppressive properties using the 3 H thymidine proliferation. Transwell 3 H proliferation studies using CD4 ϩ CD25 ϩ and CD4 ϩ CD25target cells were also performed. Supernatants were analyzed for IL-10 by ELISA. The relative FoxP3 mRNA level was determined via quantitative PCR in the PBMC and via immunohistochemistry (IHC) in liver tissue/HCC. Viral, ALT, AFP and imaging data with tumor burden were collected for correlation analysis. To study the mechanism of HCC regulation of Tregs, a murine hepatoma cell line Hepa1 was co-cultured with murine CD4 cells and Treg frequency was evaluated. Results: A significantly higher percentage of CD4 ϩ CD25 ϩ Treg was found in the peripheral blood of HCV-HCC patients (nϭ20, mean 8.85%, p Ͻ0.01) as compared to healthy controls (nϭ15, 2.27%), and chronic infected patients (nϭ30, 3.02%). Co-culture studies of CD4 ϩ CD25and CD4 ϩ CD25 ϩ T cells in the presence of PHA at increasing ratios (10:1, 2:1) resulted in a dose dependent suppression of CD4 ϩ CD25 -T cell proliferation. Elevated levels of IL-10 were found in the co-culture experiments. The relative FoxP3 mRNA levels was at least 10-fold higher in HCV-HCC patients compared to healthy controls and chronically infected subjects. Intrahepatic FoxP3-IHC staining was increased in HCC. There was a significant positive correlation between Treg frequency and tumor burden on imaging (rϭ0.54, p Ͻ0.02).

body_text.text: A role for iron in chronic hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection has recently been suggested. Serum iron stores are frequently increased in patients with chronic hepatitis C, who also display enhanced liver fibrosis. However, the molecular mechanisms by which HCV infection deregulates iron metabolism are unknown. Novel iron-regulatory proteins, including transferrin receptor2 and hepcidin have recently been identified. Unlike transferrin receptor1, transferrin receptor2 (trfR2) is expressed primarily in the liver, and its expression is regulated at the protein level by iron-laden transferrin. Hepcidin, a circulatory peptide synthesized by the liver, plays a key role in the regulation of iron homeostasis. HCV core protein has several distinct functions and has been shown to play a role in HCV pathogenesis. Thus, we studied the role of hepatitis C core protein in the regulation of trfR2 and hepcidin expression. The study employed an inducible human hepatoma cell line Huh-7/191-20, expressing HCV core protein under the control of the tet-off promoter, which exhibits tight conditional expression on the withdrawal of tetracycline. Withdrawal of tetracycline for 2 days induced significant expression of HCV protein, as demonstrated by immunohistochemistry and western blot analysis using an anti-HCV core protein monoclonal antibody. Huh-7/191-20 cells cultured in the presence of tetracycline, and hence lacking HCV core protein expression, were used as controls. TrfR2 expression was determined by western blot using a specific polyclonal antibody, and hepcidin expres-sion was determined by real-time quantitative PCR using Taqman fluorescent probes. The expression of trfR2 protein was significantly down-regulated in cells expressing HCV core protein compared to control cells. Ferritin protein expression also was downregulated upon HCV core protein expression. Interestingly, compared to control cells, hepcidin expression was significantly up-regulated in Huh-7/191-20 cells expressing HCV core protein.

body_text.text: Conclusions: Collectively, our findings clearly demonstrate that the expression of HCV core protein induces an iron-deficient environment, as reflected by the down-regulation of trfR2 and ferritin protein expression. The net effect of altered trfR2 and ferritin protein levels on hepcidin expression requires further investigation in vivo. The expression of HCV core protein may be sufficient to deregulate iron homeostasis, and not require the implication of immune mechanisms or direct viral toxicity. These data help clarify our understanding of molecular mechanisms underlying the role of iron in the pathogenesis of HCV-induced liver disease.

The immunological basis for this association has currently been unknown, but the finding is of significance since HLA-B27 has also been shown to have a protective role in HIV-infection. Here, we report the identification of an HLA-B27 restricted HCV specific CD8ϩ T cell epitope in the NS5 protein of the virus that is recognized in the majority of HLA-B27 positive females with resolved HCV infection. In chronically HCV infected patients, analysis of the corresponding viral sequence showed a strong association between sequence variations within this epitope region and expression of HLA-B27, indicating allele-specific selection pressure. Functional analysis performed in three chronically HCV infected patients revealed that the corresponding variant viral epitopes present viral escape mutations. Taken together, our results provide a first insight into the immunological basis for the protective role of HLA-B27 in HCV infection and suggest that the emergence of viral escape mutations within a protective epitope is a hallmark of viral persistence. Thus, our results indicate that the outcome and evolution of HCV are significantly influenced by the presence of a dominant virus-specific CD8ϩ T cell response that is restricted by HLA B27.

body_text.text: Background and Aims: Despite many clinical evidences, the mechanisms by which hepatic iron overload develops in patients with hepatitis C virus (HCV)-associated chronic liver diseases are unknown. In particular whether HCV infection itself, not HCVassociated inflammation, contributes to hepatic iron accumulation is controversial. The aim of this study was to investigate the mechanisms of hepatic iron overload in transgenic mice expressing the HCV polyprotein. Methods: Male C57BL/6 transgenic mice expressing the HCV polyprotein (FL-N35 lineage, Gastroenterology 2002;122:352) and their normal C57BL/6 littermates were fed normal rodent diet and sacrificed at age of 4 and 8 months. These mice were examined for hepatic iron concentrations, localization of iron in the liver, serum iron concentrations and serum transferrin saturation, and the levels of mRNA of transferrin receptor 1 (TfR1), hepcidin and divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1) in the liver. The mRNA levels were quantified by real-time PCR assay. Results: There were no differences in the diet consumption and body weight gain between FL-N35 transgenic mice and nontransgenic mice. Liver histology did not show inflammation in both mice, even though a degree of steatosis was slightly greater in FL-N35 transgenic mice. Serum iron concentrations and serum transferrin saturation were higher in FL-N35 transgenic mice at age of 8 months (PϽ0.05). Hepatic iron concentrations determined by atomic absorption spectrometry were similar at age of 4 months between both mice, but were significantly higher at age of 8 months in FL-N35 transgenic mice (126.0 Ϯ 27 g/g liver weight) than in nontransgenic mice (94 Ϯ 32 g/g liver weight) (PϽ0.05). Hepatic iron was predominantly accumulated in the hepatocytes. The mRNA levels of TfR1 were higher at age of 5 months (PϽ0.05) and lower at age of 8 months (PϽ0.05) in FL-N35 transgenic mice, suggesting the downregulation of TfR1 expression by increased intracellular iron accumulation. The mRNA levels of DMT1 were significantly higher at age of 4 and 8 months. The mRNA levels of hepcidin were similar at age of 4 months between both mice, but were significantly lower at age of 8 months in FL-N35 transgenic mice.

Conclusions: Failure of early immunological control of HCV in HIV-positive individuals is supported by the finding of weak antigen-specific T-cell responses to HCV antigens. Responses to NS3-5 are particularly associated with resolving HCV infection, and these were specifically lost in the co-infected group. The low IL-2 levels are consistent with the lack of significant CD4 proliferation, implying a deficient T-helper response. In addition, the loss of the normal relationship between inflammatory cytokine release and ALT suggests that non-specific responses are mounted which may fail to efficiently control HCV in the acute phase of infection.

body_text.text: Background and Aims: Pegylated IFN-␣ in combination with ribavirin has been widely used as the first-line therapy in chronic hepatitis C (CHC). It has been reported that the enhancement of HCV-specific T helper type 1 (Th1) response is necessary for the HCV eradication by the combination therapy. IFN-␣ and ribavirin have immunomodulatory capacity on immune cells, however, the precise mechanisms of their action remain unclear. Dendritic cells (DC) are antigen-presenting cells that regulate Th1 differentiation in vivo. We have reported that DC from CHC patients had the impaired ability to proliferate CD4 T cells and to drive Th1 response. In the present study, we hypothesize that IFN-␣ and ribavirin directly influences on DC and subsequently enhances DC capacity to induce Th1 response.

body_text.text: Type 1 interferon (IFN ␣/␤) is expressed by most virus-infected cells and, via the jak-stat pathway, induces activation of hundreds of genes, many having critical anti-viral or immune functions. In vitro studies have recently suggested that HCV itself could inhibit this pathway, thus contributing to viral persistence and/or resistance to traetment. In this study we examined the ability of mononuclear cells from patients infected with genotype 1 to respond to stimulation with interferon ␣ in vitro. We studied 22 patients from the Irish anti-D cohort contaminated in 1977 (chronic HCV-infection: nϭ13, spontaneous clearance nϭ9) and 11 healthy controls. PBMCs were collected and cultured in 100 UI/ml of IFN␣ for 6 hours. Real time PCR was used before and after stimulation to measure levels of mRNA specific for OAS2, MXA and PKR, three key genes of the JAK/Stat pathway of IFN␣ activation. Results: OAS2, MXA and PKR gene expression was clearly coregulated at baseline and after IFN␣ stimulation (0.68 Ͻ r Ͻ 0.82, pϽ0.01). At baseline, these genes were on average expressed 2-fold more in HCV-infected patients compared to resolvers and controls (pϽ0.05). Large variations were however observed among HCV-infected patients and 50% of them overlapped with controls. After in vitro IFN␣ stimulation, there was a 12-fold, 29-fold and 14-fold increase in gene expression of OAS2, MXA and PKR respectively in healthy individuals, a result similar to that observed in spontaneous resolvers (13, 23 and 15 fold-increase, respectively). In contrast, the ability of cells from chronically HCVinfected patients to respond to IFN␣ stimulation was significantly impaired when compared to resolvers and controls (6, 11 and 5 fold-change, pϽ0.05). Of particular interest was the considerable inter-individual variation in JAK/Stat gene response to IFN␣ stimulation in vitro in HCV-infected patients, again with overlapping with controls. This IFN␣ response was not correlated to viral load.

body_text.text: Background: Hepatitis C virus (HCV) RNA circulates in blood of persistently infected patients in lipo-viro-particles (HCV-LVP) which are heterogeneous in density and associated with host lipoproteins and antibodies. HCV-LVP with density below 1.10 g/ml contain the infectious particles of HCV, but the variability and lability of these virus/host complexes on fractionation has hindered our understanding of their structure and the determination of the physico-chemical properties of the HCV virion. Methods: In this study, HCV-LVP in serum from an antibody negative immunodeficient patient was analysed using isotonic iodixanol gradient centrifugation. Iodixanol gradients preserve the host lipoprotein/virus complexes and HCV RNA content of gradient fractions was assessed by quantitative real-time RT-PCR. Peak fractions containing HCV were further analysed by ratezonal centrifugation to determine the size of the virus particles and immunoprecipitated with antibodies against host lipoproteins and viral glycoproteins to determine their protein content. Results: All of the HCV RNA was recovered at densities below 1.13 g/ml with the majority of low density less than 1.06 g/ml. Immunoprecipitation with polyclonal antibodies against human apoB and apoE precipitated 99 % and 76 % of HCV with low density respectively, suggesting that the HCV-LVP resemble host VLDL. Immunoprecipitation with antibodies against HCV glycoproteins E1 and E2 precipitated less than 20 % of HCV RNA, suggesting that the viral glycoproteins within the lipo-viro-particle are not fully accessible to the antibodies. Treatment of serum with 0.5 % deoxycholic acid produced HCV with a density between 1.11 and 1.13 g/ml. The diameter of virus at this density was found to be 54nm by rate-zonal centrifugation. Treatment of serum with a stronger detergent (0.18% NP-40) produced HCV RNA containing particles with a diameter of 36 nm. Immunoprecipitation analysis showed that apoB remained associated with HCV after treatment of serum with deoxycholic acid or NP-40, whereas ApoE was removed from HCV with these detergents.

Severe liver failure is one of the common complications during pathogenesis of bacterial sepsis. Group-A-streptococcus (GAS) infections are frequent reasons of septic shock like syndrome in the clinical practice. During sepsis a boost of different cytokines mediates antibacterial and inflammatory events. Especially IL-6 plays a key role during inflammation, but its role in the pathogenesis of GAS induced sepsis is unclear. Therefore we evaluated the role of IL-6 signal transduction pathway in hepatocytes in GAS induced septic shock by analyzing hepatocyte specific gp130-/-mice. Hepatocyte specific gp130-/-(alfpCreϩ gp130 LoxP/LoxP ) mice significantly longer survived after infection with GAS compared to wildtype control animals (gp130 LoxP/LoxP ). Higher survival rates correlates with lower proliferation of group-A-streptococci in hepatocyte specific gp130-/-animals. Bacterial load in blood, spleen, kidney, lung and liver was significantly lower in alfpCreϩ gp130 LoxP/LoxP compared to wildtype controls. Additionally induction of liver damage during GAS sepsis was dependent on gp130 in hepatocytes. Wildtype animals showed elevated serum AST levels and increased numbers of apoptotic bodies in the liver. In contrast hepatocyte specific gp130-/-animals had normal serum transaminases and significantly lower (25 fold) hepatic apoptosis. Infiltration of polymorph nuclear cell (PMN) was also reduced (4 fold) in gp130-/-mice compared to wildtype animals. To analyze cytokine secretion we determined IFN␥ and IL-6 levels during GAS induced septic shock. Hepatocyte specific gp130-/-mice had lower serum levels of IFN␥ and strongly reduced IL-6 levels. In order to identify IL6 dependent mediators of hepatic PMN infiltration we analyzed serum concentration of the chemokine KC, which is known to be a chemotactic stimulus for PMN's. Indeed serum and liver KC protein levels strikingly increased in wildtype but not in hepatocyte specific gp130-/-mice. These data correlate with reduced PMN infiltration during GAS induced septic shock in hepatocyte specific gp130-/-mice. In summary hepatocyte specific gp130-/-mice are less sensitive to GAS induced septic shock concerning survival, bacterial load in liver and other organs. They developed reduced liver damage and hepatic PMN infiltration. Levels of inflammatory cytokines were significantly reduced. The PMN migration mediating chemokine KC is induced in an IL6/gp130 dependend manner in sepsis and seems to be an potential mediator of GAS induced septic liver damage.

body_text.text: Increasing evidence suggests that liver regeneration is suppressed in patients with chronic hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection; however, the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. Previously, we have demonstrated that the TLR3 ligand poly I:C, a synthetic double-stranded RNA which is generated during viral infection, suppresses liver regeneration in the partial hepatectomy (PHx) model via an NK/IFN-ƒϫ-dependent mechanism. Here we examined the role of IFN-ƒϫ-activated downstream signals and genes (STAT1, IRF-1, p21cip1, SOCS1) in poly I:C/IFN-ƒϫ suppression of liver regeneration and hepatocyte proliferation. Disruption of the STAT1 gene enhanced liver regeneration and markedly abolished poly I:C suppression of liver regeneration, while the inhibitory effect of poly I:C on liver regeneration was only weakly diminished in IRF-1-/-and p21cip1 -/-mice. In vitro treatment with IFN-gamma inhibited cell proliferation of wild-type mouse hepatocytes but not STAT1-/-mouse hepatocytes. The inhibitory effect of IFN-gamma on hepatocyte proliferation was also partially diminished in IRF-1-/-and p21cip1-/-mouse hepatocytes. In contrast, IFN-gamma treatment induces more profound suppression of hepatocyte proliferation in SOCS1-/-hepatocytes, which correlates with enhanced STAT1 activation by IFN-gamma in these cells. Finally, STAT1 was activated and induced in the livers of patients with chronic HCV infection, which was inversely correlated with hepatocyte proliferation (PCNA staining) in these patients. In conclusion, STAT1 is involved in TLR3 ligand suppression of liver regeneration, and may also be implicated in suppressed hepatocyte proliferation in patients with chronic hepatitis C virus infection in light of hyperactivation of STAT1 in these patients. body_text.text: Chronic ethanol consumption can lead to a variety of pathological consequences by as yet undefined mechanisms. Recently it has been noted that alcohol-associated liver disease is often accompanied by morphological liver changes that include the increased production of apoptotic cells. In addition, recent data from our laboratory demonstrated that hepatocellular uptake of apoptotic cells was impaired after ethanol treatment. We hypothesize that this ethanol-induced accumulation of apoptotic cells may lead to the production and release of pro-inflammatory cytokines linked to hepatocyte damage, such as interleukin (IL-6) and tumor necrosis factor (TNF-alpha). The goal of the present study was to determine whether ethanol administration altered responsiveness of Kupffer cells to the presence of apoptotic cells in culture. Methods: Kupffer cells were isolated from female Wistar rats after 8 weeks of feeding with a fish-oil diet containing ethanol or an equivalent amount of dextrose as a control. Isolated Kupffer cells were cultured for up to 24 hours in the absence or presence of apoptotic hepatoma cells, non-apoptotic hepatoma cells, and lipopolysaccharide (as a control measure of Kupffer cell activity). After incubation, media was collected, clarified by centrifugation and assayed for the presence of TNF-alpha and IL-6 by immunoassay detection. Total RNA was also obtained from the same Kupffer cell cultures using Trizol Reagent followed by the determination of TNF-alpha and IL-6 mRNA expression by real-time polymerase chain reaction. Results: Kupffer cells from both ethanol and control-fed animals were responsive in our culture conditions, as shown by increased TNF-alpha and IL-6 production in the presence of LPS. When Kupffer cells were cultured for 24 hours in the presence of apoptotic cells, significantly more TNFalpha and IL-6 (80 and 60% respectively, pϽ0.05) were produced in cells from ethanol-fed animals compared to controls; nonapoptotic cells did not affect cytokine production in either cell type. Additionally, after as early as 4 hours in culture and in the presence of apoptotic cells, mRNA levels of both cytokines were increased (2-5 fold) in cultures from ethanol-fed animals compared to controls. Conclusions: Chronic ethanol administration to rats results in the in vitro activation of Kupffer cells in response to apoptotic cells with a subsequent release of pro-inflammatory cytokines. Further characterization of these results will help elucidate the effect of ethanol on apoptotic cell production, on responses of liver cells to apoptotic cells, and on the pathological injury that occurs following these events.

body_text.text: Objective: To determine the extent of liver disease in patients with chronic hepatitis B and normal serum ALT. Methods: Patients were eligible with HBeAg positive CHB, serum HBV DNA Ն 10 6 copies/mL, and 2 ALT measurements within normal limits in the 2 years prior to liver biopsy. The mean value of the 2 ALT measurements was calculated. Liver biopsies were scored using the Batts and Ludwig scoring method with a 4-point scoring scale for inflammation and fibrosis. Results: 9 men and 4 women were enrolled. Median age was 26 (range 19-46). All had endemically-acquired infection by history. Nine patients were born in China, 2 in Vietnam, 1 in Korea, and 1 in Cambodia. Median ALT was 28 U/L (range 13-77) and median serum HBV DNA was 5.1 x 10 7 (range 4.5 x 10 4 -3.4 x10 8 ). On biopsy, 10 of 13 (77%) had evidence of fibrosis: None had cirrhosis or septal fibrosis; 6 of 13 (46%) had periportal fibrosis or rare portal-portal septa, resulting in fibrosis scores of 2, and 4 of 13 (31%) patients had portal fibrosis with at most mild periportal fibrosis, yielding fibrosis scores of 1 or 1-2. Mean liver biopsy grade was 1.23 (range 1-2) and mean stage was 1.30 (range 0-2). The R-square coefficient for a correlation between ALT and liver biopsy stage was .07, indicating that ALT was poorly correlated with liver biopsy fibrosis score (see graph). Four of 5 patients with a liver fibrosis stage of 2 had serum ALT Ͻ 30 IU/L. Conclusions: A high proportion of Asian immunotolerant HBeAg positive patients have hepatic fibrosis on biopsy. Serum ALT level may not accurately predict histologic stage in these patients. These preliminary findings support recent recommendations to perform liver biopsy to guide treatment decisions in HBeAg positive patients even if serum ALT is normal. Virologic rebounds due to resistance were observed in 10% of LVD refractory patients treated with ETV for 2 years. Of the 12 patients exhibiting a rebound, 2 had been on suboptimal ETV therapy (0.5 mg) and 3 others received ETV/LVD combination therapy. body_text.text: HBeAg negative CHB is a progressive disease with low spontaneous and drug induced resolution rates. We evaluated the Sustained Response (SR) rate to IFN and factors influencing both treatment and disease outcome in a large series of patients (pts). We followed up prospectively 558 anti-HBe positive CHB pts (451 males and 107 females; mean age 41 y, range 12-66 y) from 13 Italian Centers. Patients were treated for at least 3 months ( antiviral therapy: one received successively lamivudine, add-on adefovir ϩ lamivudine, followed by a lamivudine ϩ adefovir ϩ Hepatitis B immunoglobulins (HBIg) after liver transplantation, and the 2nd received IFN, lamivudine then entecavir. For genotypic analysis, a 1142 bp region of the polymerase gene encompassing the rt domain and overlapping the S gene was amplified by PCR for each sample, cloned and sequenced. For phenotypic analysis, an HBV replication-competent plasmid was constructed from HBV DNA isolated from patient serum (Durantel et al. Hepatology 2004) . The rt gene from the selected clones previously sequenced was then subcloned in this vector. Transfection of these HBV mutants in hepatoma cell line led us to determine their replication efficiency and drug susceptibility. At baseline, all HBV genomes carried a wild-type (wt) rt gene but, for the first patient, 36 % harbored the P120S mutation within the S gene associated with vaccine escape. Following viral breakthrough to LAM monotherapy, a complex mixture of LAM-resistant HBV strains emerged, with the prevalence of the rtL180MϩM204V mutant for the first patient and of the rtV173LϩL180MϩM204V mutant for the second. In vitro, all the tested mutants showed a 1000 fold resistance to LAM relative to wt HBV. Following the switch to ADV for the first patient, or to ETV for the second, the viral load dropped but rose again after 3 and 2 years of therapy respectively. During this rebound, we observed a complex mixture of LAM ϩ ADV or ETV resistant strains. For the first patient, the selection of only one HBV mutant was finally observed. This mutant harbored the rtV173LϩL180MϩA181VϩN236T mutations, a combination of resistance mutations to both drugs, and the sP120S mutation escaping to HBIg. Interestingly, the main LAM resistance mutation rtM204V disappeared from the viral population. The dominance of this complex rt mutant may be explained by our in vitro findings of a greater resistance to ADVϩ LAM, and a level of replication equivalent to wt HBV. For the second patient, we observed a mixture of 3 mutants during rebound. All these mutants had the rtS202G mutation, not yet described, but also the rtL180MϩM204V LAM resistance mutations despite the absence of LAM during ETV therapy. All these mutants were resistant to both LAM and ETV in vitro. Our results show the evolution of viral quasi-species towards the selection of mutants escaping to multiple selective pressures. This suggests that de novo combination therapy should be further evaluated to prevent drug resistance.

body_text.text: Background: During the immune tolerance phase that characterizes infancy-acquired chronic hepatitis B, hepatitis B virus (HBV) wild-type and variant strains coexist, although the wild-type dominates. During combination antiviral treatment most wild-type strains are eliminated and stable HBV core antigen variants become prevalent. The emergence of mutations within HBV core immunodominant epitopes may interfere with effective immune response and viral control. Aim: To evaluate the dynamic changes in serum HBV DNA levels during combined antiviral treatment in relation to the emergence of mutations within the HBV core gene and to study their contribution to treatment outcome. Patients: Twenty-three children (8 males, median age 10.2 years, range 2.9-16.8) with infancy-acquired hepatitis B (all HBeAg positive) were treated with lamivudine (3mg/kg/d) for 52 weeks and interferon a (5MU/m 2 TIW) from week 9 for 44 weeks. According to treatment outcome, patients were divided into 5 responders (R) and 18 non-responders (NR). Seven untreated HBeAg positive paediatric patients (3 males, median age 9.8 years, range 3.8-14.1) served as controls (C). Methods: HBV DNA levels were measured in serial serum samples by real-time TaqMan PCR before (treatment week 0 -TW0), during (TW2, TW9, TW28, TW52) and after (follow-up week-FUW24) antiviral treatment. The number of HBV DNA copies per ng of genomic liver DNA was evaluated at baseline by the same method. Mutations within the HBV core gene were determined at baseline within the liver and in sequential serum samples by restriction fragment length polymorphism after nested PCR, and by direct sequencing at the same time-points as HBV DNA levels.

Background and Aim: Lamivudine (LAM) monotherapy suppresses HBV replication in only 20-30% of HBeAg-negative cirrhotics treated for 5 years. Aim of the study was to assess in these patients the 5-yr efficacy of a sequential LAM to LAMϩADV therapy and its impact on disease progression and death. Patients and Methods: We prospectively followed up for 60 months (5-99) 124 HBeAg-negative cirrhotic patients (106 males, 54 years) who were given lamivudine alone or LAMϩADV in patients developing lamivudine resistance (LAM-R). Purpose: Evaluate HBV viral load (VL) after 24 weeks of treatment with either emtricitabine 200 mg (FTC) plus clevudine 10 mg (CLV) versus FTC monotherapy and to perform resistance surveillance for viremic patients. Methods: Nucleoside naïve or experienced (48 weeks FTC 200 mg qd) patients were evaluated. Results: Seventy-eight HBeAg-patients were enrolled; 38 (nϭ24 experienced and nϭ14 naïve) received FTCϩCLV and 40 (nϭ28 experienced and nϭ12 naïve) received FTC monotherapy. body_text.text: Background/Aim: The treatment of chronic hepatitis B by antiviral agents has lead to the selection of polymerase (pol) reverse transcriptase (rt) mutations with concomitant mutations in the overlapping S gene encoding for HBsAg. For diagnostic and monitoring purposes it is important to detect both wild type and any mutant HBsAg that might result during antiviral treatment. Immunoassays use various combinations of monoclonal (mAb) and polyclonal antibodies for HBsAg detection, the impact of the drug-selected mutants in FDA approved HBsAg diagnostic assays is unknown. The aim of this study was to determine the effect of antiviral selected mutations on the antigenicity, detection, and structure of HBsAg. Methods: A number of lamivudine (LMV) and entecavir (ETV) resistant pol/S gene mutations described previously were synthesized by site-directed mutagensis in an HBV genotype D infectious clone. These include various combinations of the pol mutations at rtI169T (sF161L), rtV173L (sE164D), rtL180M, rtM204V (sI195M) and rtM250V. The wild type clone and the vaccine escape mutant sG145R were included as controls. All clones were transfection into Huh7 cells. Epitope mapping of HBsAg was performed by solid phase enzyme immunoassay using four distinct anti-HBs monoclonal antibodies directed against the "a" determinant and western blot analysis was also performed. Results: For all pol mutant clones tested, the "a" determinant immunoreactivity of these downstream mutations was similar to the wild type virus, indicating no alteration in major epitope reactivity for the anti-HBs monoclonal antibodies studied. A LMV resistant HBV mutant rtV173L ϩ rtL180M ϩ rtM204V (sE164D ϩ sI195M) that was previously reported to be associated with reduced HBsAg antigenicity was able to be detected by all four "a" determinant mAb's. The level of HBsAg secretion was lower for the ETV resistant antiviral mutant rtI169T ϩ rtV173L ϩ rtL180M ϩ rtM204V ϩ rtM250V. The ETV mutant encodes the HBsAg mutations at sF161LϩsE164DϩsI195M. The effect of the ETV mutant on HBsAg intracellular retention is under investigation. In contrast to the pol mutants, the sG145R HBV mutant did show a reduction in mAb reactivity to the "a" determinant. Conclusions: Importantly, the "a" determinant immunoreactivity of the described pol mutants is preserved, suggesting that commercially available HBsAg immunoassays should readily detect these mutants. The ETV resistant mutant which encodes HBsAg mutations at sF161LϩsE164DϩsI195M was detected in low levels in the supernatant. The effect of antiviral selected HBsAg mutations on other HBV functions such as HBsAg/virion secretion and on pathogenicity is yet to be determined.

The aim of this study was to document the efficacy and development of resistance to ADV in patients with lamivudine-resistant HBV infection treated with ADV. Patients and Methods: 116 patients with chronic hepatitis B and lamivudine resistance were treated with ADV 10mg/day. Following introduction of ADV, lamivudine was continued in 81 patients and stopped in 35. HBeAg was positive in 74 cases and negative in 42. Five patients had had liver transplantation (OLT) prior to starting ADV, and 8 underwent OLT after starting ADV. Follow-up ranged from 12 to 60 months (mean ϭ 22 months). The presence of mutations of the HBV-polymerase gene conferring resistance to lamivudine and/or adefovir was examined using a new INNO-LiPA test (HBV DR v2, Innogenetics) . The HBV-DNA polymerase was also sequenced to analyze nucleotide changes. Serum HBV-DNA was measured by the Bayer b-DNA or the Roche PCR assay. Results: After one year of treatment with ADV, 61% of patients had HBV-DNA viral load below 100,000 copies/ml. This percentage increased to 77% after 2 years. Five patients developed phenotypic resistance to adefovir as evidenced by a 1 log increase in serum HBV-DNA during treatment (two OLT patients and 3 non-OLT). Resistance occurred after 1 year of treatment in 4 cases and after 3 years in the fifth case. The N236T mutation in domain D of the polymerase was detected in 4 of 5 cases. In one additional patient, the N236T mutation was detected after one year of treatment without evidence of phenotypic resistance. Among the cases with phenotypic resistance, 2 were receiving both adefovir and lamivudine (1 OLT, 1 non-OLT) and 3 were receiving adefovir only (1 OLT, 2 non-OLT). Conclusion: Patients with lamivudineresistant HBV infection exhibit a slow, but sustained response to adefovir in all but 2.9% of non-OLT patients after 1 year of treatment. body_text.text: Results: To date 26 HBeAg positive patients (22 males, mean age 43 years) have been enrolled, 9 of whom were previously treated and had lamivudine resistance and 4 of whom had cirrhosis. Results of ALT levels, HBV DNA testing and liver histology on 22 patients who have finished 1 year of therapy are shown in the Table. The major difference in the two groups at 1 year was the degree of inhibition of HBV DNA. The combination group had more dramatic HBV DNA suppression compared to the monotherapy group, log change 5.94 vs 3.88 respectively, pϭ0.026. 10/11 patients receiving combination therapy suppressed HBV DNA Ͻ10 4 copies per ml versus only 6/11 receiving monotherapy. A combined response of normal ALT, undetectable HBV DNA and improvement in HAI score by Ն4 was seen in 7 combination versus 3 monotherapy patients, (p NS). Notably no evidence of clinical resistance was seen in any patient at 1 year. Therapy was well tolerated. Conclusions: The combination of adefovir and lamivudine provided more potent and consistent inhibition of HBV DNA levels than adefovir alone, but was not associated with further improvements in biochemical or histological features of disease. Adefovir monotherapy was associated with an inadequate virologic response in a number of cases. Longer-term therapy may be required to observe further benefits of combination therapy over monotherapy.

body_text.text: Year To investigate whether viral dynamics during pegylated interferon alpha-2b (PEG-IFN) monotherapy can predict response (defined as serum HBeAg loss 26 weeks post treatment), we analyzed 136 HBeAg-positive chronic hepatitis B patients who participated in a global randomised trial and who were treated with PEG-IFN 100 g/week for 52 weeks. PEG-IFN dose was halved after 32 weeks of treatment. Serum HBV-DNA levels were measured monthly during therapy and 26 weeks post treatment by Taqman PCR assay. At the end of follow-up, response was achieved in 49 of 136 patients (36%). During therapy responders exhibited a 4.23 log and non-responders a 1.22 log HBV-DNA decrease. Overall, early viral kinetics were not predictive for response. Only for patients with genotype A, responders had a pronounced decline of HBV-DNA whereas non-responders remained flat during the treatment period and follow-up. One log decline of HBV-DNA at week 32 of treatment was highly predictive for response in genotype A (table). In the other genotypes, i.e. B, C and D, both responders and non-responders showed a decline in HBV-DNA during treatment followed by a post-treatment HBV-DNA rebound in non-responders and a sustained low HBV-DNA in responders.

Davis, Coley Pharmaceutical Group, Ottawa, CanadaIntroduction: CPG 10101 is one of a novel class of drugs, CpG oligodeoxynucleotides, which target Toll-like receptor 9 (TLR9) found on human B cells and plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDC). It is being developed as an antiviral and Th1 immune enhancer for treatment of chronic infection with the hepatitis C virus (HCV). In two Phase I trials, CPG 10101 was shown to induce/upregulate certain cytokines and chemokines. Dose-dependent effects were demonstrated in both healthy volunteers and HCV infected subjects. Laboratory evaluations in those trials have been extended to immunophenotyping of peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) to ascertain maturation and stimulatory effects of CPG 10101. Methods: In the Phase Ia trial, forty healthy volunteers were enrolled and assigned to 5 sequentially higher dose cohorts (0.25, 1, 4, 10 or 20 mg); randomized to drug (nϭ6) or placebo (nϭ2); given as 2 subcutaneous (SC) single doses, 14 days apart. A 6 th cohort received 4 mg twice weekly for 4 weeks. Subjects were evaluated to Day 29 for tolerability, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and immunophenotyping. In a subsequent Phase Ib trial, HCV positive patients were randomized to CPG 10101 (nϭ6 or 7) or control (nϭ2) over the same range of doses administered twice weekly SC for 4 weeks, or at 0.5 and 0.75 mg/kg once weekly for 4 weeks. Antiviral response (HCV RNA change from baseline) was correlated with the immune effects of CPG 10101. Results: In healthy volunteers, CPG 10101 caused up-regulation of several immunophenotypic markers during the first week after dosing. These included increased CD86 and CD38 on B lymphocytes and increased number of pDC with up-regulation of CD86, all predicted by the mechanism of CpG ODN. Subjects also showed a dose-dependent up-regulation of CD69 and CD25 activation markers on NK (CD3-, CD16ϩCD56ϩ) and NK-T (CD3ϩ,CD16ϩCD56ϩ) cells. CD14ϩ cells (monocytes/neutrophils) showed a slight and transient decrease one day post-dosing followed by an increase by 2 days. Most of the cellular markers returned to baseline levels within two weeks after the first dose. Effects were similar after first and second administrations for a given subject. Analysis of immunophenotyping profiles in HCV subjects is underway.Summary: CPG 10101 activates and matures several types of immune cells in healthy individuals. We aimed to assess the number and function of the regulatory T cells CD3ϩ/CD4ϩ/CD25ϩ (Tregs) during the acute phase of HCV and HAV infections in relation to chronic disease evolution. Methods: Thirty four subjects, including 12 patients with acute hepatitis C (AHC; Group A 12 genotype 1), 12 patients with acute hepatitis A (AHA; Group B) and 10 healthy individuals (Group C) were studied. Diagnosis of acute hepatitis C was made according to Nomura et al; (Hepatology 2004; 39:1213-9). Tregs were enumerated in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) using monoclonal antibodies anti-CD3-APC, anti-CD4-PE, anti-CD25-FITC (Beckman Coulter). Immunomagnetically purified Tregs (Ͼ 95%) (Dynal Treg cell separation and expansion kit) were tested in five patients in each group for their ability to inhibit proliferation of CD4ϩ/CD25-T cells stimulated with anti-CD3 and anti-CD28 (1:2, 1:20 and 1:200 ratio). Results: A significant elevation of Treg percent (13% Ϯ3%), absolute number (124 Ϯ 38 cells) and inhibitory activity (ratio 1:2ϭ100%; 1:20 ϭ99%) was present in 10/12 patients with acute hepatitis C in comparison with both HAV acute hepatitis patients (6.3% Ϯ 1.5 %; 38 Ϯ 26; ratio 1:2ϭ80%; 1:20 ϭ70%) (U Mann-Whitney test z ϭ 2.45; p Ͻ 0.001; z ϭ 3.28; p ϭ 0.001; z ϭ 2.59; p Ͻ 0.01) and normal donors (6% Ϯ 1%; 46 Ϯ 13; ratio 1:2ϭ79%; 1:20 ϭ55%) (z ϭ 2.60; p Ͻ 0.001; z ϭ 3.50; p Ͻ 0.001; z ϭ 2.72; p Ͻ 0.01)(Figure;sample from 3 patients), in whom Tregs number and function were similar. In the 10 HCV with elevated Tregs number and function during acute phase, Tregs number remained elevated 6 months later (11%Ϯ 2%; 112 Ϯ 32 cells ) together with positivity for HCV-RNA and transaminase levels exceeding twice the upper limit of normal six months later. The two patients with lower regulatory T cells at diagnosis (8%; 96 cells) also had a lower level after six months (7%; 82 cells) and resolved the infection having negative HCV-RNA and normal transaminases, as did all the HAV patients. Conclusion: Increased Tregs number and function at the time of acute hepatitis in the HCV patients who developed chronic hepatitis suggests that these cells may predispose to chronic evolution. The Alb-UPA/SCID mouse is capable of proliferating and sustaining transplanted human hepatocytes, subsequently supporting HCV infection within the human portion of its chimeric liver. The Alb-UPA/SCID mouse model for HCV (HCV) infection was used as a platform for microarray analysis in which biological variables such as donor hepatocytes and HCV infection were tightly controlled. Within the chimeric mouse model, HCV genotype 1A (HCV-1A) infections have an attenuated response to IFN therapy relative to genotype 3A viral infections. Our primary mandate was to catalog the human hepatic genes whose expression levels change in response to infection with HCV-1A and in the absence of an active immune system. Secondly, we wanted to utilize this unique microarray platform to explore the mechanism by which HCV-1A evades interferon therapy. Thus, mice were transplanted with human hepatocytes, infected with HCV-1A, and treated with IFN-alpha. Human hepatocytes were recovered from the chimeric mice livers by collegenase perfusion followed by FACS analysis with monoclonal anti-human HLA class I antigen conjugated to FITC. Isolation of total RNA, synthesis of cRNA, and fragmentation of cRNA were performed according to Affymetrix protocols and quality control metrics were obtained using the Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer prior to hybridization to Human Genome U133A Plus 2.0 GeneChip Arrays (Affymetrix). The significantly changed genes between treatment subgroups were selected by a permutation t test using Significance Analysis of Microarays software (SAM v 2.1). Infection of transplanted mice with HCV-1A and treatment of non-infected mice with IFN-alpha induced significant changes in the hepatic transcriptome (having false discovery rates of 0% and 2-fold change values or greater). Our results also provide evidence that pre-infection with HCV-1A alters the hepatic transcriptome induced by the IFN-alpha monotherapy used in this study.Backgrounds and Aims:HCV infection is linked to increased insulin resistance. Insulin receptor substrate (IRS) 1/2 are central molecules for insulin signaling and down-regulation of IRS1/2 is a causative factor for increased insulin resistance in patients with HCV infection(Kawaguchi et al. Hepatology 2004). Since HCV has various biological effects, HCV itself is a candidate for the development of insulin resistance. However, the effect of clearance of HCV on glucose metabolism remains unclear. The aim of this study is to examine the effects of clearance of HCV on insulin resistance, beta cell function and hepatic IRS1/2 expressions. Methods: We analyzed 89 biopsy-proven chronic hepatitis C patients. All patients were received interferon-alpha therapy for 6 month. At the end of follow-up (6 month after the conclusion of antiviral therapy), all patients were classified as nonresponders (n ϭ 48), relapsers (n ϭ 12), sustained responders (n ϭ 29). Insulin resistance and beta cell function were assessed by homeostasis model evaluation (HOMA-IR and HOMA %B, respectively). In 14 sustained responders, liver biopsy was performed before and after conclusion of antiviral therapy. Hepatic IRS1/2 expressions were evaluated by immunoblotting and immunostaining. All parameters at the end of follow-up were compared to those before antiviral therapy in each group. Results: In nonresponder, BMI significantly decreased to 21.0 Ϯ 1.9 kg/m 2 from 22.7 Ϯ 2.3 kg/m 2 (p Ͻ 0.05) after antiviral therapy, however, there were no significant changes in HOMA-IR and HOMA %B values at the end of follow-up compared to those before antiviral therapy (HOMA-IR: 4.2 Ϯ 1.6 vs. 3.8 Ϯ 2.0, HOMA %B: 114.2 Ϯ 10.8 vs. 106.9 Ϯ 16.8). In relapsers, no significant differences were seen in BMI, HOMA-IR and HOMA %B values at the end of follow-up compared to those before antiviral therapy (BMI: 21.9 Ϯ 2.1 kg/m 2 vs. 22.6 Ϯ 3.3 kg/m 2 , HOMA-IR: 3.7 Ϯ 1.2 vs. 3.9 Ϯ 1.5, HOMA %B: 121.6 Ϯ 12.5 vs. 110.1 Ϯ 14.2). In sustained responders, there was no significant difference in BMI at the end of follow-up (22.7 Ϯ 2.5 kg/m 2 vs. 20.8 Ϯ 2.9 kg/m 2 ). On the other hand, at the end of follow-up, HOMA-IR value significantly decreased to 1.7 Ϯ 0.8 from 3.1 Ϯ 1.1 (p Ͻ 0.05). Similarly, HOMA %B value significantly decreased to 90.6 Ϯ 10.0 from 113.7 Ϯ 15.3 (p Ͻ 0.05). Immunoblotting showed 3-fold increase in IRS1/2 expressions by clearance of HCV. Furthermore, immunostaining disclosed that increased IRS1/2 expressions occurred in hepatocytes, but not in non-parenchymal cells. Conclusions: We report here for the first time that clearance of HCV improves insulin resistance, beta cell function and hepatic IRS1/2 expressions.

FIGREF14.text: Medical Branch, Galveston, TX; Kiwamu Okita, Yamaguchi University School of Medicine, Ube, JapanBackground and Aim: Despite evidence of hepatic iron overload in patients with persistent hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection, it remains unknown if iron overload is related to hepatocarcinogenesis in HCV infection. The aim of this study was to determine whether iron overload contributes to the development of liver cancer in transgenic mice expressing the HCV polyprotein. Methods: Male C57BL/6 transgenic mice expressing the HCV polyprotein (FL-N35 lineage, Gastroenterology 2002;122:352) and their normal C57BL/6 littermates were allocated to be fed iron overloaded diet (Fe diet, carbonyl iron 225 mg/kg diet) or control diet (carbonyl iron 45 mg/kg diet) at age of 8 weeks (FL-N35 fed Fe diet, FL-N35 fed control diet, nontransgenic mice fed Fe diet, nontransgenic mice fed control diet). 10 to 12 mice of each group were assessed for liver histology and development of liver tumor at 6 and 12 months after commencement of feeding. Results: There were no differences in the diet consumption and body weight gain between groups. At 6 months after commencement of feeding, hepatic iron concentrations were significantly higher in FL-N35 fed Fe diet (179.0 Ϯ 38.8 g/g liver weight) and nontransgenic mice fed Fe diet (216.4 Ϯ 66.3 g/g) than in mice in other 2 groups. Hepatic iron concentrations in mice fed Fe diet were comparable to those of patients with chronic hepatitis C (223.3 g/g). Hepatic iron was predominantly accumulated in the hepatocytes. There was no inflammation in transgenic livers. Compared with mice in other 3 groups, FL-N35 fed Fe diet showed marked hepatic steatosis including microvesicular one in zone 3, significantly increased triglyceride levels in liver (PϽ0.01), ultrastructural alterations of the mitochondria (swelling, disorganized cristae, bulging) and decrease in ␤-oxidation activity (PϽ0.05). At 12 months after commencement of feeding, intrahepatic lipid peroxides (4-HNE and 4-HHE) (PϽ0.01) levels and 8-OHdG (PϽ0.01) content were significantly higher in FL-N35 fed Fe diet than in mice in other 3 groups. The number of cells positively stained for proliferation cell nuclear antigen in liver was significantly higher in FL-N35 fed Fe diet and nontransgenic mice fed Fe diet than in mice in other 2 groups. Hepatic tumors including hepatocellular carcinoma were present at necropsy in 5 of 11 (45%) FL-N35 fed Fe diet, but not present in mice in other 3 groups. Conclusions: Iron overload enhances mitochondrial injury and increases the risk of development of hepatocellular carcinoma in transgenic mice expressing the HCV polyprotein.Disclosures:The following authors have indicated they have no relationships to disclose: Takakazu Furutani, Keisuke Hino, Sohji Nishina, Isao Hidaka, Yuki Yamaguchi, Masaaki Korenaga, Toshikazu Gondo, Shu-Yuan Xiao, Stanley Lemon, Kiwamu Okita, Michiari Okuda
