The frequencies of V␣24ϩ V␤11ϩ NKT cell subsets and their phenotypes were examined by flow cytometory. The number of ␣GalCer-reactive IFN-␥ producing NKT cells was determined by ELISPOT. The NKT cell lines were established with ␣GalCer-loaded DCs and the subsequent subtype-specific cell sorting for examining their ability to increase and release cytokines in response to ␣GalCer. The cytokine levels from NKT cells stimulated with ␣GalCer-pulsed DCs was quantified by ELISA. Results: The frequencies of NKT cell subsets were not different between CH and HS groups. The CXCR3 expression of both subsets in CH was higher than HS (p ϭ 0.044), whereas those of CCR7 and CD62L were not different, suggesting that NKT cells in HCV infection are tend to recruit inflamed liver. The number of ␣GalCer-reactive IFN-␥-producing NKT cells did not differ between the groups. No significant difference was observed in the level of NKT cell proliferation in response to ␣GalCer between the groups. The established NKT cell lines from CH, either CD4ϩ or CD4-ones, secreted more IL-4, IL-5 and IL-13 in response to ␣GalCer than those from HS, most significantly IL-13 (CD4ϩ NKT average, 17.1 vs. 5.2 ng/ml, p ϭ 0.047; CD4-NKT, 10.7 vs. 0.8 ng/ml, p ϭ 0.025). In contrast, IFN-␥ production did not differ between the groups. In CH, IL-4 from NKT cells was positively correlated with serum HCVRNA levels, showing their possible involvement in the control of HCV replication. Conclusion: At the steady state, peripheral NKT cells in HCVinfected patients are comparable with those in healthy subjects in the frequency and IFN-␥ production. However, activated NKT cells in HCV infection are able to release more Th2 cytokines, suggesting their active roles in the pathogenesis of HCV-induced liver disease.

In some experiments, we used both IFN-␣ and ribavirin for DC generation and examined their functions as described above. Results: In normal donors, IFN-DC stimulated CD4 T cells to produce more IFN-␥ than GM/4-DC (pϽ0.05). IFN-␣ up-regulated CD86 expression on DC (pϽ0.01). IFN-DC produced lesser amount of IL-10 than GM/4-DCs (pϽ0.01). Furthermore, the reduced IL-10 production by IFN-DC was inversely correlated with the increased IFN-␥ production by DC-primed T cells. There was a significant correlation between the increment of CD86 expression and that of IFN-␥ production. By contrast, in CHC patients, IFN-DC failed to enhance IFN-␥ secretion from DC-primed T cells. Although similar tendencies were observed in CD86 and IL-10 in IFN-DC in the patients, the fold increase of CD86 and the reduction of IL-10 in them were much less than those in normal donors (pϽ0.05). In addition, no correlation was found among any of these parameters in CHC patients. Of particular interest, the Background: Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is the major cause of chronic hepatitis worldwide. Treatment options are still limited to combination therapy with interferon-alpha (IFN) and ribavirin. Although more than 50 % of the patients with HCV genotype 1 show only a limited response to this therapy, the factors determining viral resistance to interferon are largely unknown. Carcinoembryonic antigen-related cell adhesion molecule 1 (CEACAM-1) has been implicated in several important cellular functions such as cell-cell adhesion, proliferation and angiogenesis. In addition this type I transmembrane glycoprotein serve as a receptor for different microbiological agents. Preliminary data suggest that CEACAM-1 may be involved in the cellular response of human hepatocytes to alpha interferon. Therefore, the aim of this study was to determine function of CEACAM-1 during the IFN response in HCV infected individuals in vivo and in hepatic cells. Methods and Results: 21 patients with HCV infection were subjected to mono therapy with pegylated IFN (1.5 g/kg/weekly). 12 h prior and after the first dose the RNA from peripheral blood mononuclear cells was isolated and analyzed for induction of known and unknown IFN sensitive genes using microarray and quantitative RT-PCR. With both methods, CEACAM-1 RNA was found to be significantly upregulated 12 h after of IFN stimulation in vivo. This increase was positively correlated with the extent of decline of the viral RNA within the first 36 h after initiation of IFN therapy. These results led to analysis of IFN-induced CEACAM-1 expression in liver cells with or without two different HCV replicons. In primary human hepatocytes and different strains of HCV-negative HuH-7 human hepatoma cells, both CEACAM-1 RNA and protein (determined by immunoblot) were significantly upregulated with a maximum increase 12-24 h after IFN stimulation in vitro. In HuH-7 cells containing a highly adapted subgenomic HCV replicon (con1, genotype 1b), the level of CEACAM-1 RNA expression was significantly lower than in the corresponding parental cell line. In contrast, HuH-7 cells harbouring a different replicon that contained the NS3/NS4 and NS5a regions of two interferon resistant HCV strains (AD4 and AD78), CEACAM-1 RNA showed both increased spontaneous expression levels and a sustained response to IFN in comparison with naive cells. Conclusions: Our results show a differential function for CEACAM-1 in the systemic and the intrahepatic response of HCV to IFN and suggest involvement of this molecule in the signaling process conferring resistance of HCV infected liver cells to IFN.Disclosures:The following authors have indicated they have no relationships to disclose: Philip Hilgard, Guido Gerken, Ruth Broering, Martin Trippler, Jö rg Schlaak, Sergei Viazov, Marc aus dem Siepen

Toms, University of Newcastle, Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom (Great Britain)Background: Hepatitis C virus RNA recovered from infected human serum and liver macerates is found in low density complexes termed lipo-viro-particles (LVP) containing both virus structural proteins and host apolipoprotein B-100. It has been suggested that HCV-LVP may enter hepatocytes in a virus envelope glycoprotein independent manner via its association with host lipoprotein. Candidate receptors include the scavenger receptor protein, SR-B1 and the LDL receptor (LDL-r). Here we have studied the capacity of HCV-LVP to bind to and enter human hepatocytes. Methods: HCV-LVPs, free of antibody, were recovered by iodixanol gradient centrifugation of liver macerates from the explant of a patient with high viral load as previously described (1). LVP were allowed to attach to HepG2 cells or primary human liver hepatocytes treated with insulin to enhance LDL-r expression and cell-bound viral RNA was determined by quantitative reverse transcriptase PCR.Results: Approximately 2% of the HCV RNA in LVP preparations bound to HepG2 cells and primary human hepatocytes. Prior heparinase treatment of HepG2 cells reduced binding by 30%.A post-attachment suramine wash to remove virus bound to cell surface glycosaminoglycans reduced binding by only 12%, suggesting internalisation of virus. Suramine resistant LVP binding occurred in a dose dependent manner reaching a maximum by 3h post infection at 37°C and by 24h post infection at 4°C. Binding to hydroxyl-cholesterol treated cells was 2.5-fold lower than that to insulin treated cells, correlating with a 2.2-fold reduction in the expression of LDL-r as assessed by DiI labelled low density lipoprotein (DiI-LDL) binding. Prior exposure of cells to excess LDL blocked HCV-LVP and DiI-labelled LDL binding to similar extents, providing some evidence that the LDL-r participates in binding of HCV-LVP. Prior exposure to oxidised LDL also blocked uptake of HCV-LVP, supporting SR-B1 as another candidate receptor. However binding was unaffected by treatment with antibodies to apoB-100, which completely abrogated binding of DiI-LDL. Conclusions: We conclude that liver derived HCV-LVP binding to human hepatocytes can be increased with insulin treatment and decreased with hydroxycholesterol treatment, in parallel with the uptake of LDL. HCV-LVP binding can be blocked by heparinase, purified LDL and oxidised LDL supporting the concept that HCV-LVP may utilise VLDL/LDL pathways for binding and entry into hepatocytes.1. Ribeiro, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM; Alan S. Perelson, Los Alamos national Laboratory, Los Alamos, NMBackground: Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is a major health concern worldwide. State-of-the-art therapy (peg-interferon and ribavirin) elicits long-term responses in only about 50% of patients treated, with no effective alternative treatment for non-responder. Recently, cell-based HCV replicon systems were developed and they have become the benchmark for testing new antiviral agents against HCV.Methods:We developed a mathematical model of subgenomic HCV replication assuming that its strategy of replication involves single-stranded RNA templates. The model describes the amplification of subgenomic HCV in Huh-7 cells from transfection to steady state. Following the establishment of a steady state, we simulated the effects of antiviral agents with different modes of action and efficacies on replicon copy number, and compared the results with published data. We tested the sensitivity of our model by simulating one thousand random combinations of parameter values. Results: After initiation of IFN-␣ treatment of Huh-7 cells harboring replicons, an immediate biphasic decline of HCV plus-strand RNA has been observed. According to our model only blocking of RNA transcription leads to an immediate biphasic decline of total plus-strand RNA. The observed biphasic plus-strand RNA decline with the introduction of small interfering RNA (siRNA) is in agreement with our model results when enhanced degradation of free plus-strand RNA is assumed as the mode of action of siRNA. Interestingly, we predict a transient plus-strand RNA decline (that last for about 14 days of treatment) when partial blocking of the formation of the intermediate transcription complexes occurs. Conclusions: Modeling HCV plus-stranded RNA viral kinetics during treatment in cell culture can shed light on the molecular mode of action of a given drug. According to our model, monitoring intermediate components of HCV replication (e.g. plusstrand RNA not attached to host ribosomes, and minus-stranded RNA) with frequent data sampling during the first hours of therapy will allow a better definition of different antiviral modes of action. In addition, the predicted transient decline of plus-strand RNA is reminiscent of the transient HCV RNA decline observed in patients treated with ribavirin monotherapy. In summary, our model can serve as an important tool in designing and evaluating new antivirals against HCV.

As it is well known, IFN therapy is not recommended after renal transplant due to the increased incidence of chronic rejection and graft failure. Furthermore, Ribavirin use is contraindicated for the increased risk of haemolytic anemia and renal impairment. The beneficial effect of the IFNϩRiba therapy in liver transplanted pts with HCV recurrence, demonstrated that the combined antiviral therapy doesn't modify the immunobiologic state of transplanted pts achieving viral eradication in about 50% of pts when all the genotype are considered. Aim of the Study: Aim of the study is to determine 1) the efficacious dose of Ribavirin which doesn't adversely affect the anemic state of the patients and 2) to test the clinical efficacy of the IFNϩRiba therapy accordingly to the haemathologic state of the patients Patients and Methods: Twentyfive naïve HCV pts on chronic dialysis and in waiting list for renal transplant were enrolled. In all cases transaminases were mild elevated. All were positive for HCV-RNA and the mean viral load was 310327Ϯ257147 IU/ml. HCV genotype 1b was detected in 50% of pts. Liver histology revealed a mild disease in all pts (grade1, stage1-2).The time that pts were on dialysis ranged from 2 to 16 years. All were in treatment with Epo at the beginning of therapy. The antiviral schedule consisted of Peg-IFN alpha-2a, 135 g/week and Riba 200 mg/day for 48 weeks. Results: Twentyone/25 pts completed study treatment. Four pts were discontinued for non compliance in 2 cases and for inefficacy at week 12 in the other cases. Therapy was clinically well tolerated. The main expected biochemical drawbacks was mild to severe anaemia which was controlled in all cases with reduction in Ribavirin dose (200mg on every other day) and by increasing EPO. A 1st virological analysis made at week 12, showed: 19 pts (90%) was HCV-RNA Neg. This results has been maintained until the end of the study. AST returned normal in all patients. Post-treatment F-Up is ongoing. Conclusion: Combined therapy with Peg-IFNϩRiba seems a feasible option in the particular setting of haemodialysis patients waiting for renal transplant. A careful pt monitoring is recommended as regards the anemic state. Ͻ1%) regardless of METAVIR score. Similar patterns of events and laboratory findings were observed for subjects discontinuing on or before week 18. Schering Plough Research Institute, Stock Holder of: Schering Plough Peter Savino -Employee of: Schering Plough Research InstituteIntroduction:The EPIC 3 program includes a large, prospective, controlled trial designed to understand the safety and efficacy of re-treatment of subjects who have significant fibrosis (Metavir F2-F4) with PEG-IFN ␣2b and ribavirin weight based dosing for 48 weeks in previous treatment failures to any IFN-␣ and ribavirin therapy. We have previously reported an SVR of 21% for these subjects. Aim: Here we report the effects of PEG-IFN ␣2b/ribavirin on platelet counts in these patients. Methods: HCV ϩ patients that did not respond or relapsed after previous treatment with any IFN-␣ and ribavirin received PEG-IFN ␣2b 1.5 g/kg subcutaneously once weekly plus ribavirin 800-1400 mg/day weight based dosing for up to 48 weeks. All enrolled patients had pre-treatment biopsies scored by a single reviewer using METAVIR criteria. Platelet counts were assessed at screening and at all treatment visits. We report on the 1964 (568 F2, 580 F3, 806 F4) patients who have been treated to date. Results: Most patients (94%) had decreases in their platelet count with only 3% having drops greater than 60%. The median decrease was 30%. Less than 5% of subjects experienced platelet count decreases of more than 60%. There were no differences in the percentage drop of any level between F2, F3 or F4 patients. While the median time to nadir platelet count was treatment week 18, 23% of patients reached their nadir at treatment week 36 or later; with 7% reaching their nadir at week 48.Of patients with a baseline platelet count of Ͼ150x10 3 /L, only 4 (Ͻ1%) had a decrease to Ͻ 50 x10 3 /L; all were F4. Of those with a baseline count of 100-149 x10 3 /L, 37 (8%) had decreases to Ͻ 50 x10 3 /L; 1 F2, 5 F3 and 31 F4. Of those with a baseline level of Ͻ99 x10 3 /L 31 (28%) had decreases to Ͻ50 x10 3 /L; 3 F2, 5 F3 and 23 F4. Oral doses of isatoribine are poorly absorbed in multiple species. The prodrug ANA975 was developed to improve oral delivery of isatoribine to systemic circulation.Methods: Toxicology studies, including GLP oral multiple-dose studies in cynomolgus monkeys, were performed to enable clinical studies. An open label, rising dose level, single-dose study in healthy volunteers was performed in the United Kingdom according to institutional and local regulatory requirements. Thirty-six subjects each received a single oral dose of ANA975 administered as a 5mg/mL solution in the fasted state at doses of 400mg (nϭ6), 800mg (nϭ18), or 1200mg (nϭ12). Results: Oral administration of ANA975 to monkeys resulted in efficient systemic delivery of isatoribine; the highest tolerated dose in monkey achieved plasma area-under-the-curve (AUC) values 6-13x higher than achieved with the 800mg IV dose in the clinical POC study. Monkeys showed a dose-related OAS induction in blood that persisted with once daily dosing for treatment periods up to at least 28 days. Single oral doses of ANA975 were well tolerated by healthy volunteers. There were no serious adverse events (AEs) and no withdrawals from the study. A total of 15 AEs were reported by 13 of 36 subjects. All reported AEs were mild (13 events) or moderate (2 events) in severity. The Investigator considered 1 AE (mild transient increase in CPK at 800mg) to be possibly related to ANA975 and all other AEs to be unlikely related or not related to ANA975. There were no reports of gastrointestinal AEs or flu-like syndrome. ANA975 was rapidly and extensively converted to isatoribine, with isatoribine Cmax typically occurring within 1 hour post-dose. At the highest tested dose, which has an isatoribine dose content of 988mg, plasma isatoribine AUC values (range 23-40, median 27mg*h/L) were similar to those observed in the clinical POC study with daily 1-hour IV infusions of isatoribine 800mg (first dose AUC range 19-38, median 24mg*h/L). The similarity of AUC values at comparable molar doses of oral ANA975 and IV isatoribine indicates that fractional oral absorption and conversion of ANA975 to isatoribine was very high. Conclusion: ANA975 is an efficient oral prodrug that achieves plasma isatoribine exposures comparable to those previously shown to reduce plasma HCV RNA in chronically infected patients

Aim: Assess persistence of HCV among patients successfully treated with PEG-IFN ϩ RBV. Methods: 25 randomly selected CHC patients with sustained virological response (SVR) after full PEG-IFN ϩ RBV treatment were included. Serum and peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) were collected 6 to 56 months (mean, 22 months) after end of therapy (EOT). 13/25 patients underwent a second collection at 13 to 49 months after therapy (mean, 28 months). PBMC were cultured for 48 hours under mi-togen and cytokine stimulation. Presence of HCV RNA was determined by sensitive real-time polymerase chain reaction of the 5'UTR. Institutional Review Board approved study. All patients provided written informed consent. Statistical analysis: Student's t test was used to compare means between groups; Chi square or Fisher's exact test was used for comparison of categorical data. Results: Demographics: 14 female, 11 male; mean age -52 years (range, 30-73); genotype 1-14 patients (56%). All patients underwent full course of antiviral treatment: 48 weeks for genotype 1 and 24 weeks for genotypes 2 or 3 and fulfilled SVR criteria. None of the 25 patients had detectable HCV RNA in sera by commercial qualitative PCR assay or by in-house RT-PCR of similar sensitivity and specificity at all time-points studied after EOT. HCV RNA was detected in PBMC cultures from 5 patients (20%); 3/25 during the first PBMC collection and 2/13 patients during second PBMC collection. No patient was positive on both PBMC collections. Conclusion: Our results suggest that in CHC patients, HCV RNA may persist in PBMC for 35 months after fulfilling SVR criteria following therapy with PEG-IFNϩ RBV. RNA persistence in PBMC and sera was lower among our patients than reported among those treated with standard IFN ϩ RBV. At present the clinical relevance of this finding is unclear. It is possible that viral persistence, and specifically presence of PBMC HCV RNA may lead to HCV reactivation. Branch, Mount Sinai School of Medicine, New York, NYBackground/Aims: During chronic HCV infection, some pathogenic effects are specific to HCV infection, while others reflect general liver injury. To identify gene expression changes that are specific to HCV infection, we cross-filtered mRNA profiles obtained through microarray analysis of human livers with parallel data from model systems of HCV replication and gene expression. This approach allows the direct and indirect consequences of HCV infection to be distinguished and enhances understanding of HCV pathogenesis. Methods: Using transcriptional profiling by single-color microarray (30-mer, Human CodeLink 10K), mRNA expression patterns were determined in HCV-infected human livers, in Huh-7 cell lines (stably expressing T7 polymerase) transfected with pH77, a full length infectious genotype 1b HCV construct that is under the control of the T7 promoter, and in HepG2 cells stably transfected with an HCV-1b core gene. Patterns were compared with those of appropriate controls (normal human liver, and Huh-7 and HepG2 cells transfected with empty vectors). Expression of selected genes that were up-or down-regulated by 1.8-fold or more in HCV materials versus controls was confirmed by real-time PCR. Results: Of the 10,000 genes profiled, 22 were up-regulated and 51 were down-regulated by at least 1.8-fold in HCV-infected human livers and in the pH77 transfected Huh7 cells. Microarray results were highly reproducible. The correlation coefficient among five human liver specimens was 0.92. The 73 differentially-expressed genes included TGF-␤1, which was up-regulated, and a number of genes whose expression is known to be co-coordinately regulated with TGF-␤1, such as SIP1/ZEB-2, integrin £]4, p42/p44 MAPK, and ILGFBP1, which were up-regulated; and cyclin b, which was down-regulated. ILGFBP1 was also up-regulated in HepG2 cells expressing the HCV core protein. Because of the predominance of the TGF-␤1 pathway among the differentially regulated genes, realtime PCR analysis was conducted on mRNA from pH77 and control cells; this method confirmed the microarray results.Conclusions: HCV expression significantly stimulates TGF-␤1 gene expression. TGF-␤1 exerts biologically relevant effects in human livers and in model systems, altering downstream genes in a relevant manner. These coordinate changes in gene expression may play an important role fibrosis and may also contribute to chronic infection by modulating immune responses. TABREF36.text: Disclosures:The following authors have indicated they have no relationships to disclose: Bin Gao, Rui Sun, Shailin Kulkarni, Barbara Jaruga, Svetlana Radaeva950 RAGE-EXPRESSING MONONUCLEAR PHAGOCYTE-DERIVED DENDRITIC CELLS IN LIVER MEDIATE UPREGULATION OF PROINFLAMMATORY SIGNALS IN MASSIVE LIVER INJURY Shan Zeng, Nikalesh Ippagunta, Hao Dun, Ann Marie Schimdt, Jean C Emond, Columbia University, New York, NYBackground: RAGE is a multiligand signal transduction receptor of the immunoglobulin superfamily that interacts with inflammatory S100/calgranulins and high mobility group box 1 (HMGB1). We previously have shown that RAGE blockade suppresses failure of regeneration after massive hepatectomy. In the liver, RAGE is principally expressed in mononuclear phagocyte-derived dendritic cells (MPDDC). Here, we explored the role of ligand-RAGE interaction on the properties of MPDDC. Methods: We isolated primary murine MPDDC, Kupffer cells (KC) and hepatocytes from mice to test RAGE expression in key parenchymal and non-parenchymal cells. Results: Quantitative real-time PCR revealed that RAGE was expressed to the highest degree in MP-DDC, and to a lesser extent in KC and was not detected in hepatocytes. We tested the hypothesis that RAGE mediated inflammatory signals in injured liver derived largely from MPDDC. MPDDC were isolated from WT and RAGE null mice and incubated with prototypic RAGE ligand, S100b (20 g/ml) for 4 and 10 hrs. In WT cells, an 4.7 and 10.4-fold increase in TNF-alpha transcripts, respectively, was noted vs incubation with PBS. In contrast, in MPDDC isolated from RAGE null mice, no increase in TNF-alpha transcripts was noted in the presence of S100b. LPS (10 ng/ml) was incubated with WT and RAGE null MPDDC for 10 hrs. Although WT MPDDC revealed a significant increase in TNFalpha and IL-6 transcripts, significantly decreased transcripts were noted in LPS RAGE null MPDDC. As LPS is not a ligand for RAGE, we tested the premise that LPS triggered generation/ release of RAGE ligand HMGB1. After 6 hrs incubation of MP-DDC with LPS (100 ng/ml), a 2-fold increase in HMGB1 antigen in supernatant was noted vs PBS-treatment. Consistent with the premise that RAGE stimulated proinflammatory signals in MP-DDC in vivo, six hours after massive hepatectomy, transcripts for TNF-alpha and IL-6 were increased in MPDDC, but not from MPDDC isolated from sham-treated WT or RAGE null mice (3.0 vs 1.0 and 3.3 vs 0.48 fold, respectively, pϽ0.05). Conclusion: These data suggest that liver MPDDC play a prominent role in RAGEdependent mechanisms that exacerbate inflammation in liver injury. The ligand-RAGE axis is a prominent pathway linked to autocrine/paracrine induction of inflammatory signals by MP-DDC. Accordingly, the practice of dispensing MCT to NASH patients should be reassessed.[Supported by a Merit Review Grant from the Department of Veterans Affairs]Disclosures:The following authors have indicated they have no relationships to disclose: Charles Lieber, Maria Leo, Qi Cao, Ki Mak, Chaoling Ren, Anatoly Ponomarenko, Xiaolei Wang, Leonore DeCarli953 DIETARY CURCUMIN PREVENTS DOWNREGULATION OF HEPATIC TRANSPORTER GENE EXPRESSION BY LPS Astrid Kosters, Ajay Gulati, Sundararajah Thevananther, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX; Jaap Mulder, University Medical Center Groningen, Groningen, Netherlands; Richard Von Furstenburg, Tracy Zimmerman, Romi Ghose, Saul Karpen, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TXBackground: Inflammation caused by bacterial lipopolysaccharide (LPS) leads to the downregulation of hepatic transporter gene expression which results in cholestasis. Notably, Ntcp and Bsep RNA levels were maintained at 78Ϯ50% and 60Ϯ46% of control levels, respectively.

back_matter.text: Introduction: In HCV 1a/b-infected patients, foci of amino acid mutations in NS5A associated with response to interferon-based treatment were identified around V3 region. In HCV 1-infected patients receiving Peginterferon alfa and ribavirin amino acid sequence of carboxyterminal part of NS5A including V3 region was now investigated the correlation of local accumulation of amino acid variations with virologic response and viral dynamics. Methods: 78 patients (HCV 1a nϭ21; HCV 1b nϭ57) were enrolled. All patients participated in the DITTO international multicenter trial and received Peginterferon alfa-2a (180g) plus ribavirin (1000-1200mg/day) for at least 24 weeks. HCV-RNA was frequently quantified during the first 4 weeks of treatment and patients were classified as rapid, slow, flat, or null responders according to their viral kinetic pattern. Local accumulations of differences to consensus sequence were analyzed on the basis of a nonparametric binomial regression model, assuming independent amino acid exchanges. For comparison of the total number of variations of all or specific sequences, Kruskal Wallis or Mann-Whitney U test were applied. A specific testing procedure based on smoothed mutational frequencies was applied in order to determine if there are local or global differences between groups and to determine if differences are due to local differences between the groups in addition to possible global differences in mutational frequency, respectively. Results: Summarizing over the whole NS5A region as well as summarizing over predicted exposed amino acids, revealed a higher heterogeneity in patients with sustained virologic response (SVR) compared to patients without SVR (mean variations from the consensus sequence: .13 vs. .08 and .15 vs. .09; pϭ.02 and pϭ.01, respectively). Significant higher smoothed mutational frequencies indicating also local accumulations were found in HCV 1-a infected patients with SVR compared to patients without SVR and in patients with rapid, slow or flat response compared to patients with null response (pϽ.001 in each case). In HCV genotype 1a-infected patients, main focus of accumulation of mutations was observed around aa 2320, in HCV 1b-sequences between aa 2350 and 2370. Conclusion: In the present study, sustained virologic response to Peginterferon alfa-2a and ribavirin therapy was significantly associated with a higher mutational frequency in the carboxy terminal part of NS5A. Two different mutational foci have been found in genotype 1a and 1b isolates upstream the V3 region. The functional role of these mutational foci on viral replication should be evaluated in the replicon system. Background: Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is characterized by an accumulation of CD4 (ϩ) T cells that are critical for the development of liver injury. Chemokines upregulated during liver inflammation have been implicated in the activation, recruitment, and retention of immune cells, including CD4 (ϩ) T cells, within the liver in AIH. Specifically, the chemokines IP-10 and MIG recruit activated immune cells expressing their cognate receptor CXCR3 to inflammatory sites. Accordingly, we employed an experimental model of AIH resulting from Concanavalin A (ConA) administration to test our hypothesis that IP-10 and MIG play important, non-redundant roles in hepatic immune cell recruitment during experimental T cell mediated hepatitis. Methods: C57BL/6 mice were given ConA (or PBS vehicle) (13.0mg/kg IV) and sacrificed 1.5, 8, 24, and 48 hours after treatment. Plasma ALT levels were used to biochemically confirm hepatitis (maximal at 8-24 hours) and this was supported by histology. Levels of chemokine mRNA (RPA) and protein levels (ELISA) were analyzed. Hepatic mononuclear cells were isolated and analyzed using FACS to identify hepatic CD4 (ϩ) T cell populations. Additionally, neutralizing antibodies against IP-10 or MIG were administered (50ug/mouse IV) 2 hours prior to ConA treatment. Results: Our results demonstrate that hepatic expression of IP-10 and MIG differ temporally; hepatic IP-10 levels increase 3-fold (pՅ0.001) above baseline by 90 minutes, and peak 8 hours after ConA treatment (3-fold increase; pՅ0.001). In contrast, hepatic MIG levels increase 32-fold above baseline at 8 hours (pՅ0.001), and remain elevated 7-fold (pՅ0.001) at 24 hours post-ConA. Interestingly, significant hepatic infiltration of CXCR3 expressing CD4 (ϩ) T cells occurred only after 24 hrs post-ConA and correlated with increased total hepatic CXCR3 mRNA expression. Treatment with neutralizing IP-10 or MIG antibodies resulted in striking 25-fold (pՅ0.01) and 85-fold (pՅ0.01) reductions in ALT levels 24 hours post-ConA respectively and were associated with marked improvements in liver histology. Our findings support essential and non-redundant roles for IP-10 and MIG in the development of ConA hepatitis. Moreover, given that CXCR3 expressing CD4 (ϩ) T cells are recruited Ͼ24 hrs post-ConA, our results suggest that IP-10 and MIG exert their proinflammatory effects in ConA hepatitis independent of recruitment of CXCR3 expressing CD4 (ϩ) T cells. Background: During endotoxemia, hepatocellular transport and biliary secretion are markedly decreased, in large part due to proinflammatory cytokine mediated decrease in hepatic transporter levels. The Retinoid X Receptor ␣, RXR␣, along with its heterodimer partners, are centrally involved in the transcriptional regulation of many hepatic transporters, as well as genes involved in detoxification. We have recently modeled this pathway in HepG2 cells, where IL-1␤ treatments lead to the rapid nuclear export of RXR␣ and subsequent decreased DNA binding of RXR␣containing heterodimers-however the fate of RXR␣ in response to IL-1␤ signaling has not yet been determined. We hypothesize that IL-1␤ induced cell signaling leads to the ubiquitination and subsequent proteasomal degradation of RXR␣. Methods: HepG2 cells were cultured for 48 hours and serum starved for 16 hours prior to a 1 hour pretreatment with either DMSO (vehicle) or 10 M MG132 (proteasomal inhibitor) and then subjected to 10 ng/ml IL-1␤ or saline for 3 or 6 hours before nuclear, cytosolic or whole cell protein extracts were prepared. Extracts were then subject to western blot analysis for RXR␣. For ubiquitination analyses, HepG2 cells were transfected with GFP tagged RXR␣ (RXR␣-GFP) and a HA epitope tagged expression construct of either wild type ubiquitin (HA-UBQ) or a nonfunctioning ubiquitin (HA-mUBQ). Twenty-four hours after transfection, cultures were pretreated with either DMSO or MG132, and exposed to saline or IL-1␤ as noted, before harvest of protein extracts from 0.5 to 5 hours later. Immunoprecipitation of HA-UBQ-tagged proteins using an anti-HA antibody, was followed by western blotting for both native RXR␣ and transfected RXR␣-GFP. Results: Pretreatment of cells with the proteasome inhibitor MG132 completely blocked the reduction in whole cell levels of RXR␣ seen in response to IL-1␤. Similar results were noted in nuclear and cytoplasmic extracts. Cell extracts obtained after MG132 pretreatment before exposure to IL-1␤ treatment showed a 4-fold increase in HA-UBQ-tagged RXR␣ compared to saline treatment. HA-UBQtagged RXR␣-GFP was increased 2-fold over saline by 30 minutes and remained high through 5 hours. No ubiquitinated RXR␣ or RXR␣-GFP bands were seen in either the DMSO pretreated cells or the cells expressing HA-mUBQ. Summary: Taken together, these data show a rapid ubiquitination and proteasomal degradation of RXR␣ in response to IL-1␤ induced cell signaling providing a possible mechanism for the broad and sustained down-regulation of RXR␣-regulated gene targets in the inflamed liver.

back_matter.text: Idiosyncratic drug-induced hepatitis (IDDIH) is the third most common cause of acute liver failure requiring transplantation in the United States. Studies suggest that IDDIH has immune and autoimmune features. Cytokines have been implicated in the pathogenesis of organ-specific autoimmune diseases. While roles for chemokines in organ injury have also been demonstrated, few studies have investigated potential interactions between cytokines and chemokines in organ-specific autoimmune disease. Moreover, no studies have investigated the roles of these two components in the development of immune-mediated injury in IDDIH. We developed a novel murine model of immune-mediated hepatitis consisting of neutrophils and eosinophils with features resembling IDDIH using covalently modified hepatic proteins linked to a trifluoroacetyl (TFA) chloride hapten (TFA-S100) formed from CYP2E1 oxidative metabolism of halogenated volatile anesthetics or similar drugs. We found that hepatitis directly correlated with serum anti-hapten IgG1 antibodies. We postulate that in our model, significant neutrophilic inflammation is induced by IL-4-dependent expression of neutrophil chemoattractants, KC or macrophage inhibitory protein-2 (MIP-2). Moreover, the formation of significant serum levels of anti-hapten antibodies is also IL-4-dependent. To test these hypotheses, we immunized IL-4 knockout (IL-4 KO) and wild-type (BALB/c) mice with TFA-S100 after institutional review board approval. We found significant hepatitis in BALB/c but not IL-4 KO mice. Methods: Virologic rebounds (confirmed Ն1 log increase from nadir by PCR) observed in patients from studies AI463-022 & AI463-027 (nucleoside naïve), AI463-014 & AI463-026 (LVD refractory), and AI463-901 (extended treatment) were analyzed for emerging ETVr. Genotypic analysis compared patient HBV RT sequences with those at study entry and with WT HBV. Phenotypes of emerging substitutions were determined using antiviral assays measuring HBV DNA yields from HepG2 cells transfected with plasmids expressing patient RT sequences. Results: Among Ͼ650 nucleoside naïve, HBeAg pos & HBeAg neg patients completing at least 24 wk of ETV therapy, 93% achieved HBV DNA reductions to Ͻ300 copies/ml. Over 200 patients completed Ն90 wks of therapy. Genotypic analysis of the 18 observed virologic rebounds (2 year treatment period) failed to show any evidence of emerging ETVr substitutions, with population pheno-Adefovir Dipivoxil (ADV) is effective for both wild type (WT) and YMDD variant (YMDDv) HBV which is resistant to Lamivudine (LAM). While the majority of LAM resistant patients respond well to ADV, some patients show slow/poor antiviral responses and even have an increase in HBV DNA levels while on ADV therapy. We investigated if this poor/worsening response was the result of ADV resistance. Materials and Methods: 133 patients after LAM resistance, were treated with ADV for varying periods. Good responses to ADV were seen in 87/133 patients while 46 showed slow /poor virologic responses although biochemical improvement was noted. Pre-ADV and on-ADV therapy serum samples were available from 13/46 patients. For the remaining 33, Pre-ADV and on-ADV specimens were unavailable since HBV DNA levels were measured elsewhere. To understand the nature of slow/poor responses, HBV polymerase genotypes were investigated using an YMDD PCR-RFLP assay and sequencing of the HBV pol gene. The PCR-RFLP assay examined the presence of mutations at 2 sites (rtL180 and rtM204)). The sequencing assay assessed mutations at codons, rt180, rt181, rt204, and rt236. Analytes of the sequencing assay included genotype and PMUL and PMUA, polymerase mutants for LAM and for ADV respectively. These 13 patients were Asian Americans, aged 19-67 years, 9 males and 4 females. Treatment with LAM lasted 12-60 months until viral breakthroughs were noted. Median pre-ADV HBV DNA levels were 5 x 10 6 copies/mL (range 1.2 x 10 6 -2.5 x 10 8 ) while median on-ADV HBV DNA levels were 9 x 10 6 (range 1.7x 10 4 -8 x 10 6 ). The median duration of ADV therapy for 13 patients was 13 months (range 6-30). Results: Polymerase genotypes were examined on 10 pre-ADV and 13 on-ADV samples, all of HBV genotype C. Among 10 pre-ADV samples, 8 contained YMDDv HBV and 5/8 also contained a small portion of mixed population; surprisingly 2/10 had mostly WT-HBV although they had viral breakthrough. Following ADV therapy (6-30 months), 10/13 patients had a return of WT-HBV; 3 of these10 contained a small portion of YMDD and 3/13 had YMDDv-HBV. One patient with 18months on ADV, showed WT-HBV return mixed with ADV resistant HBV (N236T). It appeared that YMDDv-HBV were suppressed by ADV but in some WT-HBV was strong enough to return even under ADV effect. Conclusion: These results suggest that in patients with LAM resistance who did not respond well to ADV, the majority of poor responses were due to the return of WT HBV and not due to ADV resistance. Continuation of LAM in combination with ADV, at least for a period of time, may therefore be the preferred management in patients with LAM resistance.

back_matter.text: Therapy with HBV-polymerase inhibitors is based on long term suppression of viral replication. At present sequential monotherapy is standard of care, however combination therapy with at least two HBV-polymerase inhibitors is considered a promising alternative approach. It is unknown to date whether combination therapy with lamivudine plus tenofovir could be superior to sequential therapy with tenofovir after the occurrence of lamivudine resistance for chronic hepatitis B treatment in coinfected patients. We conducted a multicenter, 1:2 matched pair analysis comparing patients with HBV/HIV-coinfection starting an antiretroviral regimen including tenofovir plus lamivudine with patients who had highly replicative, lamivudine resistant hepatitis B (Ͼ 100,000 copies/mL) and started therapy with tenofovir as the only active HBV-polymerase inhibitor. Resistance to lamivudine was demonstrated by HBV-genotyping. The lower limit of detection of HBV-DNA was 1000 copies/mL. At baseline patients starting with tenofovir plus lamivudine (nϭ23) had a median HBV-DNA of 59,000,000 copies/mL compared to 120,000,000 copies/mL in the tenofovir arm (nϭ46) (pϭ0.75). After 3 months on treatment, median HBV-DNA decreased to 138,450 copies/mL in the tenofovir plus lamivudine group compared to 27,950 copies/mL in the tenofovir group (pϭ0.26). After 12 months and 24 months median HBV-DNA was Ͻ1000 copies/mL in patients taking either tenofovir plus lamivudine or tenofovir alone (pϭ0.46, pϭ0.24). A sustained undetectable HBV-DNA Ͻ1000 copies/mL was achieved in 19/23 (83%) patients on tenofovir plus lamivudine and in 38/46 (83%) patients on tenofovir (p ϭ 1.00). A loss of HBe-antigen was observed in 7/22 HBe-antigen positive patients on tenofovir plus lamivudine and in 11/44 patients on tenofovir (pϭ0.57). HBs-antigen loss was found in 1/23 and 2/46 patients, respectively.In conclusion in this cohort of HBV/HIV-coinfected individuals, full virologic HBV-DNA suppression was achieved in the majority of patients independent of treatment allocation. In addition loss of HBe-and HBs-antigen was not different in both arms. Over a median observational period of 24 months tenofovir alone was as effective as tenofovir plus lamivudine in HBV/HIV-coinfected patients with highly replicative chronic hepatitis B.

Besides rtM204V/I mutation, rtL80V/I and rtL180M mutations have been reported to be associated commonly in patients with LAM resistance. In this study, we intended to examine the effects of a certain type of mutations at polymerase domain of Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) on the antiviral efficacy following adefovir dipivoxil (ADV) therapy in patients with LAMresistant chronic hepatitis B (CHB). Methods: One hundred and nineteen patients with LAM-resistant CHB were treated with ADV at a dose of 10mg daily for Ͼ12 weeks. The entire polymerase domain of HBV in the sera obtained just before ADV therapy was sequenced using direct sequencing method. Genotypes of HBV were determined by restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) following polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Serum HBV-DNA levels were quantified by real-time PCR method. The antiviral responses, which were evaluated by the change of serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and HBV-DNA levels at 12 weeks following ADV therapy, were compared in relation to the preexisting mutations at HBV polymerase domain. Results: All of 119 subjects revealed to have HBV of genotype C. Out of them, 105 patients (88%) had YMDD mutations; 70 (67%) rtM204I, 28 (27%) rtM204V variant and 7 (6%) both. In addition to mutations at YMDD motif, rtL80V/I mutation was found in 70 (59%) and rtL180M in 72 (61%). The rtM204I variant was accompanied by rtL80V/I (pϽ0.001) and rtM204V was associated with rtL180M mutation more frequently (pϽ0.005). Median serum HBV DNA level at baseline was 7.82 log(10) copies/mL and the median change of serum HBV DNA levels from baseline were -2.40 log(10) copies/mL at week 12. The rate of serum ALT normalization was 42% following 12 weeks of ADV therapy. The rate of serum ALT normalization (45% vs. 35%; pϽ0.05) and the changes of serum HBV DNA level (median, -2.43 vs. -2.93 log(10) copies/mL; pϽ0.05) at 12 weeks following ADV therapy were not significantly differ-ent between patients with rtM204I and those with rtM204V variant. Very interestingly, the change of serum HBV-DNA levels was significantly greater in patients with rtL80V/I mutation compared with those without it. (Median, -2.10 vs. -2.83 log(10) copies/mL; pϽ0.05) However, the presence of rtL180M mutation did not affect the change of serum HBV-DNA level following ADV therapy. (Median, -2.53 vs. -2.20 log(10) copies/mL; pϽ0.05) Conclusions: It is suggested that rtL80V/I variants of HBV may associate with poor antiviral response to ADV therapy. Little is known about the patterns of HBV-DNA decline and their relation to response for chronic hepatitis B patients treated with alpha-interferon. To investigate different patterns in viral decline during treatment and follow-up, we analyzed 254 HBeAg-positive chronic hepatitis B patients treated with pegylated interferon alpha-2b (PEG-IFN) 100 g/week for 52 weeks with or without lamivudine 100 mg/day. PEG-IFN dose was reduced to 50 g/ week after 32 weeks of treatment. Endpoints were HBeAg-negativity, HBV-DNA Ͻ 400 copies/ml and HBsAg negativity 26 weeks after therapy. The total trial population consisted of 266 patients. From 12 patients, insufficient HBV-DNA measurements were available to assess HBV-DNA patterns. In the patients treated with PEG-IFN monotherapy (nϭ124), 5 different patterns of viral decline could be recognized: a. early decline of at least 1 log during week 0-4 of therapy; b. delayed decline of at least 2 log from baseline HBV-DNA during week 4-32; c. late decline of at least 2 log between week 32 and 52; d. posttreatment decline of 2 log from baseline HBV-DNA after week 52; e. no substantial decline at any time point. Endpoints for these different patterns are shown in the table. A delayed rather than early viral decline was associated with highest response rates at the end of follow-up (HBeAg response 63% vs. 52%, respectively). Patients with a late or post treatment decline pattern had lower response rates (HBeAg response 31% and 27%, respectively). Interestingly, 7 out of 8 patients (88%) with HBsAg loss and all patients with HBV-DNA Ͻ400 copies/ml at the end of follow-up exhibited a delayed HBV-DNA decline. In the patients treated with combination therapy (nϭ130), a similar biphasic pattern of decline in HBV-DNA was seen in nearly all patients with a fast decline in the first four weeks and a slower decline thereafter. In conclusion, different patterns in HBV-DNA decline were found during PEG-IFN monotherapy. A delayed rather than early viral decline was associated with the highest response rate. This underlines the important immunomodulatory effect of PEG-IFN and the limited predictive value of early viral kinetics in PEG-IFN therapy for HBeAg-positive chronic hepatitis B. Results: Most patients were of Asian origin (87%) and infected with HBV genotype C (59%) or B (28%). Response in Asian patients closely reflected overall results. Among Caucasians (nϭ79), the highest response rates were seen with peginterferon alfa-2a alone (50% 12 ⁄24). Response rates were also high in patients with genotype A receiving peginterferon alfa-2a alone (52% 12 ⁄23). Patients infected with genotype C or B had the same response to peginterferon alfa-2a alone (31% vs 30%). Response rates were higher in females than males in all treatment arms; 35% vs 31%, 37% vs 25%, and 26% vs 17% with peginterferon alfa-2a alone, combination therapy, and lamivudine alone. There was no clear relationship between patient age and response, regardless of treatment. In the two peginterferon alfa-2a arms, response rates were comparable in patients weighing Յ65 kg and Ͼ65 kg. Response rates in lamivudine-treated patients weighing Յ65 kg were slightly higher than in those Ͼ65 kg (22% vs16%). In MV analyses across all treatment arms, ethnicity, genotype, age and bodyweight were not significant predictors of response (Pϭ0.757, Ն0.21, 0.716 and 0.790); gender was of borderline significance (Pϭ0.077). Conclusion: Genotype was not a significant predictor of response by MV analysis. The rate of response was the same for patients with genotype B or C, the predominant genotypes in the study. This contrasts with previous studies of interferon-based therapy. Genotype A patients, who represented a minority of patients in our study, treated with peginterferon alfa-2a alone had the highest rate of HBeAg seroconversion at week 72. Gender had a marginal effect on response and this was mostly seen with combination therapy and lamivudine alone. Patient bodyweight had no effect on response to peginterferon alfa-2a.

back_matter.text: The efficacy of encapsulated, chemically-modified siRNA targeted to hepatitis B virus (HBV) was examined in an in vivo mouse model of HBV replication. Stabilized siRNA targeted to a highly conserved site in the HBV RNA was incorporated into lipid nanoparticles and administered by intravenous injection into mice carrying replicating HBV. Three daily IV injections at 3 mg/kg/day reduced serum HBV DNA by 3.0 log 10 relative to controls. This reduction in HBV DNA was dose-dependent and persistent for up to 14 days after dosing. A single 3.0 mg/kg dose resulted in a 2.0 log 10 reduction in serum titers. Specific siRNA-mediated reduction of HBV RNA was observed in the liver. Furthermore, prolonged reductions were seen in serum HBV DNA with weekly siRNA dosing. Administration of the formulated siRNA did not induce cytokines (IFN␣, IFN␥, TNF␣, IL6), therefore indicating that the observed anti-HBV activity is siRNA-mediated. The potent activity was also correlated with improvements in delivery compared to unencapsulated siRNA. The advances demonstrated in this work are significant steps towards making siRNA therapeutics a reality.

back_matter.text: . ADV resistance is associated with rtA181V and rtN236T mutations but the resistance is much less common than for LAM. It has been reported that a cumulative incidence for ADV resistance is 2% after 96 weeks of treatment in na?e patients. In this study, we analyzed the emergence rate of rtA181V and rtN236T and the effects of those mutants on antiviral response after 48 weeks of ADV therapy in patients with LAMresistant CHB. Methods: Fifty patients with LAM-resistant CHB were treated with ADV at a dose of 10mg daily and followed for over 48 weeks. The baseline and 48-week samples were analyzed for the presence of mutations at rt181 and rt236 of HBV polymerase by restriction fragment mass polymorphism (RFMP) assay. The antiviral responses to therapy were evaluated by changes of serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT), hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) positivity, and, HBV-DNA levels at 48 weeks after ADV therapy. Serum HBV-DNA levels were quantified by real-time PCR method. Results: Of the fifty patients, YMDD mutations were identified in 44 patients (88%). Besides YMDD mutations, 3 patients had rtA181T before ADV therapy. After 48 weeks of ADV therapy, rtA181V/T and/or rtN236T mutations emerged in 9 (19%) out of the other 47 patients without mutations at rt181 or rt236 (rtA181V in 1 patients, rtA181T in 2, rtN236T in 3, rtA181VϩrtN236T in 1, rtA181TϩrtN236T in 2). There were no differences in age, gender, pre-ADV serum ALT, HBeAg positivity, and HBV DNA levels between patients with and without the mutants. The rates of normalization of serum ALT (67% vs. 47%) and loss of HBeAg positivity (10% vs. 12%) were not significantly different between two groups of patients (PϽ0.05). However, reduction of serum HBV-DNA levels was significantly less in patients with rtA181V/T or rtN236T than in those without the mutants (mean, -0.43 vs. -2.36 log(10)copies/mL) (PϽ0.001).

back_matter.text: Background: Kaplan-Meier (KM) estimates were originally developed to assess survival rates using death as the measured outcome. Recently, this statistical method has been used to assess the long-term efficacy of antiviral therapy for chronic hepatitis B (CHB). A basic assumption of the KM approach is that a patient who achieves an outcome (eg death) will always have that outcome whether they remain in the study or not. Since relapse occurs in CHB, we discuss the appropriateness of the KM approach in determining response to anti-HBV therapy. Objective: To compare HBeAg response rates obtained using the intent-to-treat (ITT) principle, which assumes that patients with missing data do not have a response, with rates obtained by KM estimation in patients enrolled in a large, randomized clinical trial. Methods: HBeAg-positive patients were treated for 48 weeks with 180 g peginterferon alfa-2a (40KD) (PEGASYS ® ) once-weekly (qw) ϩ oral placebo once-daily (qd), 180 g peginterferon alfa-2a qw ϩ 100 mg lamivudine qd, or 100 mg lamivudine qd. HBeAg seroconversion rates during treatment and up to 24 weeks posttreatment (week 72) were reanalyzed using the KM method.Results: HBeAg seroconversion rates at the end of treatment (week 48) in the ITT population were 27% 72 ⁄271 with peginterferon alfa-2a alone, 24% 64 ⁄271 with peginterferon alfa-2a ϩ lamivudine and 20% 55 ⁄272 with lamivudine alone. Corresponding KM estimates of HBeAg seroconversion at week 48 (day 337) were 36% with peginterferon alfa-2a (ϩ9% over ITT), 29% with combination therapy (ϩ5% over ITT) and 24% with lamivudine (ϩ4% over ITT). In the ITT population, HBeAg seroconversion rates 24 weeks post-treatment (week 72) were significantly higher with peginterferon alfa-2a alone (32% 87 ⁄271; PϽ0.001) and peginterferon alfa-2a ϩ lamivudine (27% 74 ⁄271; Pϭ0.023) than with lamivudine alone (19% 52 ⁄272). KM estimates of HBeAg seroconversion rates at week 72 (day 504) were 43% with peginterferon alfa-2a (ϩ11% over ITT), 38% with the combination therapy (ϩ11% over ITT) and 30% with lamivudine (ϩ11% over ITT). Conclusions: Using data from this large, randomized study, estimated rates of HBeAg seroconversion generated using the KM method were substantially higher than the HBeAg seroconversion rates generated using an ITT analysis. These findings suggest that KM estimation is not an appropriate statistical method for measuring long-term efficacy of antiviral therapy in patients with CHB as it biases the data. Results generated using KM estimates should be interpreted with caution especially when the associated rates of relapse are not also analyzed. Although, CPT score did not significantly changed in total group, an important decrease was detected in patients without virological breakthrough. On the contrary virologic breakthrough was associated with a statistically significant increase in CPT scores (from 6.08Ϯ1.2 to 7.2Ϯ2.3, pϽ0.02). Also the frequency of complications of cirrhosis decreased with LMV treatment in comparison to pretreatment period. There was no significant difference in rate of complications between patients with and without virologic breakthrough. Thirteen patients (3 virologic breakthrough) developed hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in mean 29Ϯ19 months (Cumulative HCC incidence 5.6%). Seven patients (2 virologic breakthrough) died within 41Ϯ21 months (5 HCC, 1 AML-M4, 1 hepatic encephalopathy and spontanoeus bacterial peritonitis). Three patients underwent liver transplantation. Conclusion: Long-term LMV therapy results in significant improvement in laboratory and clinical parameters of cirrhosis. Virologic breakthrough is not associated with clinical deterioration in compensated and mildly decompensated cirrhotics.

back_matter.text: Background: Our group has proposed a role for Toll receptors (TLR) in the antiviral response to CH-B, in which HBeAg downregulates TLR-2 as an immune escape mechanism. The importance of TLR expression during therapy for CH-B remains undefined. FTCB-201 was a phase 2 study comparing the efficacy of adefovir (ADV) plus emtricitabine (FTC) to ADV alone in the treatment of HBeAg-positive CH-B. Viral kinetics identified 2 subsets of patients, fast (FR) or slow (SR) responders, by viral clearance at 12 weeks (Ͻ300 copies/ml). Our aim was to examine monocyte TLR gene and protein expression in the two groups with comparison to quantitative HBeAg titres during the first 48w of the study.

back_matter.text: Results: TLR-2 and -4 protein expression on CD14ϩ monocytes (expressed as a ratio to matched isotype controls using mean fluorescence) from SR did not significantly change over the 48w of the study. In contrast, all FR significantly up-regulated TLR-2 at weeks 16 and 24. This increase was sustained to week 36, but by week 48 had returned to baseline. There was no change in TLR-4 expression in the FR group. The trend in TLR-2 protein expression was not seen at the mRNA level, reflecting the heterogenous PBMC population used for RT-PCR. Up to 12 weeks of therapy, the HBeAg titre declined in parallel with the viral load in FR but not SR. By week 12 the HBeAg titre of all FR was Ͻ300 PE IU/ml whilst in 6/8 SR it remained Ͼ300 PE IU/ml (PϽ0.05). In FR this represented a Ͼ90% reduction of mean HBeAg titre compared to Ͻ20% in SR (PϽ 0.05). No cases of HBeAg seroconversion were observed in either FR or SR. Discussion: We hypothesize that a critical level of TLR-2 expression is required for HBV clearance. Up-regulation of TLR-2 was seen in FR who achieved both a reduction of viral load to Ͻ 300 copies/ml and 90% reduction of HBeAg to Ͻ 300 PE IU/ml by 12 weeks of treatment. The reason for the decline in TLR2 expression after 36 weeks is unknown but may be consistent with the observed failure of HBeAg seroconversion. The effect of HBeAg on TLR-2 expression and antiviral escape provides a framework by which future treatments for CH-B may be optimized. Results: Of 144 patients who had a virologic response (Ͻ20,000 copies/ml) to peginterferon alfa-2a monotherapy at the end of treatment, 89 had available data 48 weeks post-treatment. Of these patients, 49 (55%) sustained HBV DNA levels Ͻ100,000 cp/mL during the 48 week follow-up period [among these, 22 (25%) had HBV DNA levels between 20,000 and 100,000 copies/ml; and 27 (30%) had HBV DNA Ͻ20,000 cp/mL]. Patients with sustained virologic response had higher mean ALT levels at baseline (94.7 IU/L) compared with patients with relapse (77.6 IU/L). Mean baseline HBV DNA levels were 7.18 and 6.99 log for sustained responders and relapsers, respectively. HBV DNA level at the end of treatment was not different in patients with sustained response and those with relapse (2.5 and 2.6 log, respectively). The rate of sustained virologic response according to HBV genotype was 60% 3 ⁄5, 43% 12 ⁄28, 64% 27 ⁄42 and 50% 5 ⁄10 for genotypes A, B, C and D, respectively (Pϭ0.08 for comparison of genotype B vs C). Conclusions: In patients with HBeAg-negative CHB, a finite 48week course of peginterferon alfa-2a was able to induce virologic response that was sustained 48 weeks post-treatment in more than half of the patients. There was no clear predictor of sustained response to peginterferon alfa-2a. However, there was a trend toward better response in patients with high ALT at baseline or who were infected with HBV genotype C. Baseline or end-oftreatment HBV DNA levels were not indicative of sustained virologic response.
back_matter.section: Methods: We have shown that the pattern of peripheral monocyte TLR expression is identical to that on hepatocytes and Kupffer cells. Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) and sera from 15 patients (FR ϭ 7, SR ϭ 8) were collected at weeks 0 4 12 16 24-36 48 of therapy. PBMC were stained using anti-CD14, anti-TLR-2 and anti-TLR-4 and analyzed by flow cytometry. PBMC were extracted for total mRNA and measured for TLR-2,-3,-4,-9 and TNFa by RT-PCR. back_matter.text: Background: Tenofovir (TDF) is licensed for the treatment of HIV and is known to be active and potent as well against hepatitis B virus. Anyhow, there is still a lack of data about the efficacy of TDF against HBV in HIV/HBV coinfected patients. In our center we treated 37 HIV/HBV coinfected patients with TDF containing antiretroviral therapies since January 2002. 21 of those had a viral load of hepatitis B of more than 100000 IE/ml bevor the start of TDF. 10 of these patients had previously shown a clinically diagnosed resistance of HBV against Lamivudine (LAM). Methods: Retrospective analysis of the virological effectiveness of TDF against HBV in 21 HIV patients with highly replicative HBV coinfection, who were treated with a TDF containing antiretroviral therapy. Previous LAM resistance of HBV was defined as an increase of HBV of 2 log or more under treatment with LAM. Results: The 21 patients were all male and were in average 41 years old (range: 37-49). The average time on TDF was 27 month (range: 12-39) and the average viral load of HBV (VL) at baseline was 1.7x10log12 IE/ml (range: 2x10log5-1x10log13; Nϭ21). At month 6 after start of treatment, the average VL was 743042 IE/ml(nϭ19), at month 12 it was 3769 IE/ml (nϭ17) and at month 24 the average VL was 230 IE/ml (nϭ15). The 10 patients with HBV resistance against LAM showed the following results: Baseline: VL 1,2x10log12 IE/ml (nϭ10), month 6: 33425 IE/ml (nϭ8), month 12: 7019 IE/ml (nϭ9), month 24: 386 IE/ml (nϭ8). In the reported patients we did not see any viral break through of HBV of more than 1 log under therapy with TDF so fare. Conclusion: According to our experience TDF is a long-term effective drug against HBV in HIV/HBV coinfeted patients with or without HBV resistance against LAM.

back_matter.text: Background: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) genotype has been reported to correlate with response to interferon (IFN) treatment in several studies. The relationship between HBV genotype and thymosin␣1 (T␣1) treatment is unknown. We retrospectively examine HBV genotypes, precore and core promoter mutations in patients treated by T␣1 and analyze the correlation between complete response (CR; ALT normalization plus seroclearance of HBeAg and HBV-DNA by solution hybridization) of T␣1 therapy and HBV genotype. Patients and Methods: 98 patients with clinicopathologically proven chronic hepatitis B were randomized allocated to three groups: 1) T6 group (nϭ32) received a 26-week course of T␣1 with a 1.6 mg subcutaneous injection two times a week; 2) T12 group (nϭ34) received the same regimen as T6 group, but T␣1 therapy extended for 52 weeks; 3) T0 group (nϭ32) served as a control and was followed up for 18 months without specific treatment. Retrospectively analyze the HBV genotype, precore and core promoter mutation using stored serum and correlated with CR. Results: There were 90 stored serum available for HBV genotyping from patients completing the treatment and follow-up study (29 in T6 group; 31 in T12 group and 30 in T0 group). Of them, 49 (54%) were genotype B and 41 (46%) were genotype C. Genotype C had a higher frequency of core promoter mutation.Stepwise logistic regression analysis showed that genotype (odds ratio [OR], 3.747; 95% confidence interval [CI],1.066-13.170; Pϭ0.039), precore mutation (OR, 6.285; 95% CI, 1.874-21.086; Pϭ0.003) and T␣-1 treatment (OR, 12.045; 95% CI, 2.220-65.354; Pϭ0.004) as independent factors associated with CR. The CR of T␣-1 was higher in patients with genotype B compared to patients with genotype C (52% of genotype B vs 24% of genotype C; Pϭ0.036) and in patients with precore mutation (14/22 or 64% in responder vs 6/31 or 19% in non-responder; Pϭ0.002). Conclusion: Genotype, presence of precore mutation and T␣-1 therapy were independent predictors to CR. Genotype B, compared to genotype C, is associated with a higher response rate to T␣1 therapy.

back_matter.text: In this follow-up study, all patients who presented residual HBV replication by PCR between year 4 and 5 of treatment were studied for the presence of HBV polymerase resistance mutations on serum samples. The HBV-RT was sequenced and compared to the sequences obtained before ADV introduction. Among the 35 patients included in the initial cohort, 29 were still followed at year 4 and 14 had an undetectable viral load by PCR (Ͻ200 copies/mL). 15 had available samples with a viral load high enough to perform sequencing analysis. Median duration of add-on ADV of these 15 patients was 235 weeks and the median HBVDNA was 3.55 log10 cop./mL. 14/15 patients had constant fluctuating low viral loads between 2.3 (LLD) and 5 log10 cop./mL with no evidence of viral breakthrough. 10/15 patients had the same LAM-resistant pattern as their baseline sequence rtV173L/ L180M/M204V (nϭ2); rtL180M/M204V (nϭ8) and no noticeable change was observed in their RT sequences along time. 2/10 of them had ADV replaced by tenofovir (TDF) when the background HIV treatment required adjustment. 4/15 patients lost their LAM-R mutations. For 2 of them failure of compliance was documented. For the 2 remaining, analysis of their HIV and HBV viral load kinetics clearly suggested lack of compliance. 1/15 patient had a viral breakthrough with a HBVDNA rise over 1 log10 on two consecutive samples. At that time, LAM-R mutations rtV173L/ L180M/M204V were still present but no ADV mutation (rtA181V/T or rtN236T) or new conserved site mutations were identified; ADV was replaced by tenofovir and HBV DNA started to decline. Sequential monotherapy, after LAM-R breakthrough, could potentially increase the risk of subsequent HBV resistance selection. A strategy based on ADV add-on therapy seems very effective and is very unlikely to select for double ADV and LAM resistant variants, even in difficult to treat patients such those with HIV coinfection. The persistence of initially present LAM-R mutations, the low variability of the RT sequence and the absence of selection of further compensatory mutation indicate a strong pressure on a replication impaired virus. Results: 18 out of 55 (33%) were HBcAbϩ; 15 were HCV-RNAϩ (27%) and 6 HBsAgϩ (10%). HBsAgϩ patients were treated with pre-emptive lamivudine therapy. Five (15%) HBcAbϩ patients experienced HBV related hepatitis reactivation and they were found positive for c and s genes on liver tissue (occult B virus) but not on serum samples. These subjects were compared to a historical group of HBsAgϩ patients (n.9) who also had a disease reactivation under the same circumstances (pre lamivudine era). In both groups lamivudine promptly dominated the pathological process and all the patients recovered. HBV-DNA titration on liver tisssue was significantly higher in HBsAGϩ (10 4 -10 5 copies/ml) and occult B virus patients (10 3 -10 4 copies/ml)compared to HBcABϩ subjects in whom the occult virus was not identified (Ͻ10 3 copies/ml). Levels of serum HBV-DNA (RT-PCR) were not useful to discriminate between "occult" HBcABϩ and "non-occult" HBcABϩ patients. Conclusions: In NHL the prevalence of HBcABϩ is higher than HBsAGϩ and occult infection plays a major role in HBV reactivation as well as overt HBV infection. However, its onset is not as frequent as in HBsAgϩ patients. At the moment routinely used blood test to identify occult B virus does not exist. Lamivudine pre-emptive treatment should be also considered in HBcAbϩ subjects undergone chemotherapy for NHL.

back_matter.text: Background: Lamivudine (LAM) was the first oral treatment for CHB, although its efficacy is limited by drug resistance, with 70% of patients becoming resistant within 4 years. back_matter.section: Methods: A Markov model using individual patient simulation was constructed to model disease progression in CHB and calculate the cost per quality-adjusted life year (QALY) gained. Unlike previous analyses, this model included patients with HBeAgnegative disease and/or drug resistance. Eleven disease states were modeled: immunotolerant; viral suppression; active CHB; HBsAg seroconverted; HBeAg seroconverted; compensated cirrhosis; decompensated cirrhosis; hepatocellular cancer; liver transplant; post-liver transplant; and death. Three treatment strategies were compared with LAM followed by no treatment after resistance develops ("LAM-NT"): continuing LAM irrespective of whether resistance develops ("LAM-LAM"); LAM followed by ADV after resistance develops ("second-line ADV"); and ADV followed by LAM after resistance develops ("first-line ADV"). Costs and resource use were based on a UK costing study and clinical opinion, disease progression rates with/without treatment were based on a systematic review and utility scores were based on published estimates. Costs and benefits were discounted at 3.5% per year.

back_matter.text: Recurrence of serum HBeAg has been reported to be uncommon both after cessation of interferon and lamivudine therapy for HBeAg-positive chronic hepatitis B. We investigated the frequency of relapse after Peg-interferon alpha-2b therapy alone or in combination with lamivudine in chronic hepatitis B. A total of 266 chronic HBeAg-positive patients were treated with 100g Peg-IFN weekly for 52 weeks combined with lamivudine (n ϭ 130) 100 mg/day or placebo (n ϭ 136). After week 32 the Peg-IFN dose was reduced to 50g. The post-treatment follow-up lasted 26 weeks. At the end of treatment, HBeAg loss was seen in 44% in the combination group and 29% in the monotherapy group (p ϭ 0.01). Overall, post-treatment HBeAg recurrence was seen in 27 patients (10%), but was strongly associated with treatment allocation. Twenty-two patients (17%) receiving the combination with lamivudine and 5 (4%: p Ͻ 0.0001) receiving Peg-IFN alone relapsed for HBeAg after treatment discontinuation. Except for treatment allocation, no other baseline variables could be identified as predictive factor for relapse. Among patients in the combination group post-treatment relapse occurred less frequently after HBeAg seroconversion (i.e. HBeAg clearance and development of anti-HBe) and was found in 8 (6%) patients versus 5 (4%, p ϭ 0.35) receiving Peg-IFN alone. Multivariate analysis showed combination therapy with lamivudine (RR 3.8 CI95% 1.2 to 12, p ϭ 0.02) and absence of anti-HBe at week 52 (RR 6.3 CI95% 2.2 to 16.7, p Ͻ 0.0001) as independent predictors for relapse. In conclusion, recurrence of HBeAg is more often seen after combination of Peg-IFN with lamivudine than after Peg-IFN monotherapy. Treatment allocation and absence of anti-HBe at the end of therapy were the only independent predictors for post-treatment HBeAg relapse.

back_matter.text: However, the N236T mutation in domain D of the hepatitis B virus (HBV) polymerase is associated with phenotypic resistance to adefovir. In vitro data suggest that the N236T mutant exhibits only a 4.5 fold decrease in sensitivity to tenofovir. We therefore examined the efficacy of tenofovir in patients with adefovir resistance. We also explored the usefulness of tenofovir in patients with suboptimal response to adefovir, but without genotypic resistance. Methods: Two patients who were receiving adefovir because of lamivudine resistance developed resistance to adefovir, after 36 and 12 months of treatment respectively. The first case was receiving lamivudine ϩ adefovir and the second case adefovir monotherapy. The N236T mutation of the HBV-polymerase was demonstrated by the INNO-LiPA test (HBV DR v2, Innogenetics). They were treated with tenofovir 300mg id plus lamivudine 100mg id and adefovir was stopped. Four additional patients without genotypic resistance, but with sub-optimal response to adefovir were also switched to tenofovir 300mg id. They were also receiving adefovir ϩ lamivudine because of lamivudine resistance. These 4 cases had HBV-DNA viral loads of 97 x 10 6 , 42 x 10 6 , 14 x 10 6 and 3.6 x 10 6 millions copies/ml after 13, 23, 29 and 25 months of treatment with adefovir respectively. HBV-DNA viral loads were measured by the Bayer b-DNA assay (lower limit of detection ϭ 2000 copies/ml). Results: The two patients with resistance to adefovir showed a good response to tenofovir. In the first case, serum HBV-DNA decreased from 93 x 10 6 copies/ml at baseline to 9,300 copies/ml after 6 months of treatment with tenofovir. In the second patient, serum HBV-DNA decreased from Ͼ 100 x 10 6 copies/ml at baseline to 23,000 copies/ml after 7 months of treatment. In the 4 patients with sub-optimal response to adefovir, tenofovir treatment produced a Ͼ 1 log drop in viral load after 1 month and a Ͼ 2 log drop after 3 months of therapy. Conclusion: Treatment with tenofovir induces a rapid decrease of HBV-DNA viral load in patients with resistance or sub-optimal response to adefovir.

back_matter.text: Background: Adefovir (ADV) resistance is less common and occurs later than lamivudine (LAM) resistance. A study of 67 HBeAg-ve patients reported that ADV-resistant HBV mutants were detected in 0%, 3%, 11% and 18% after 1, 2, 3 and 4 years treatment, respectively. Aims: To characterize the virologic response to ADV, to determine the rate of ADV resistance, and to explore risk factors associated with suboptimal response and ADV resistance in patients referred to our Liver Clinic from 5/00 to 3/05. Methods: All patients who had received ADV for Ͼ 6 months and had virologic breakthrough (BT) or failed to achieve an initial virologic response (IVR) were tested for ADV resistance. LAM-and ADVresistant mutations were detected by a line probe assay (InnoLipa, DR2) and confirmed by direct sequencing. HBV DNA was quantified using the Roche Cobas Amplicor assay (LLOD 200 copies/ ml). BT was defined as Ͼ 1 log c/ml increase in HBV DNA after initial suppression; IVR was defined as serum HBV DNA Ͻ4 log c/ml after 6 months of ADV. The rate of ADV resistance was estimated by Kaplan-Meier analysis. Results: 39 CHB patients (36M, 26 Caucasians and 11 Asians, mean age 48 years, 26 HBeAgϩve) were included and mean duration of treatment was 20 months (range 7-57). 30 (77%) patients had prior LAM (mean duration 25 months) of whom 14 were switched to ADV monotherapy and 16 received combination of LAMϩADV; 9 (23%) were started on ADV as de novo therapy. 25 (64%) patients had LAM breakthrough or confirmed resistance. IVR was observed in only 44% patients. Factors associated with an IVR included lower HBV DNA (pϭ0.03) and the absence of HBeAg (pϭ0.02) at the onset of ADV treatment. 16 patients had BT or lack of IVR on ADV and 5 were found to have ADV-resistant mutations (3 rtA181V, 2 rtN236T). All 5 patients with ADV resistance had prior LAM therapy. At the time ADV resistance was detected, 4 had viral rebound Ͼ5 logs and ALT flares Ͼ2XULN. The rate of ADV resistance at months 6, 12, 18, and 24 was 0%, 0%, 9%, and 19%, respectively. Patients with ADV resistance were more likely to have been switched to ADV monotherapy (100% vs. 36%, pϭ0.014) and to be infected with HBV genotype D (60% vs. 9%, pϭ0.019). Conclusions: Half of our patients failed to achieve IVR on ADV. Lack of IVR was associated with high baseline HBV DNA and presence of HBeAg. The high rate of ADV resistance (19% at yr 2) in our clinic population may be related to referral bias and predominance of patients with LAM resistance. ADV resistance was associated with HBV genotype D and switch to ADV monotherapy. Combination therapy in patients with LAM resistance may prevent the development of ADV resistance.

At multivariate analysis, patients with pre-treatment lower HBV-DNA (pϽ0.0001), higher ALT levels (pϽ0.005) and HBeAg negative (pϽ0.001) had higher chances of achieving undetectable HBV-DNA. Time to undetectable HBV-DNA was significantly shorter in patients with a pre-treatment HBV-DNA below 5 log, than in those with levels between 5 and 6 or above 6 log (pϽ0.00001). ADV-R was looked for in 13 cases and confirmed in 3 patients. By multivariate analysis, patients treated with ADV monotherapy (pϽ0.0001) and those with detectable HBV-DNA at week 24 (pϽ0.0001) had higher chances of a virological rebound. back_matter.text: In the analysis we included 64 adult patients (M/Fϭ53/11, median ageϭ58) with CHB who developed breakthrough due to lamivudine-resistant strains. All patients had compensated liver disease, elevated transamine levels and serum HBV DNAϾ105 copies/ml before initiation of ADV. In all patients ADV (10mg once daily) was added to lamivudine (100mg/daily) for 3 months and thereafter patients were assigned to continue combination treatment (group 1, 44 patients) or to receive ADV monotherapy (group 2, 20 patients). Results: Baseline parameters were similar between the two groups. At the time of this analysis the total duration of treatment was 16 to 31, median 26 months. No difference was observed between two groups in the patients with normal ALT levels at 12th and 24th months (group 1: 87% / 65%, group 2: 72%/ 92%). Median reduction of serum HBV DNA at 6th, 12th and 18th month was 3.17/3.29/4.34 logs respectively in group 1 and 3.41/3.32/3.39 logs in group 2. The difference became significant at the 18th month (pϭ0.027). At 12th month serum HBV DNA Ͼ105copies/ml was observed in 2 patients (one at each group) and at 18th month in one patient in group 2. Two patients on ADV monotherapy developed virological breakthrough at 12th and 15th months of treatment respectively. None of the patients receiving combination developed breakthrough phenomenon. Conclusions: Our data suggest that ADV is an effective antiviral agent in patients with HBeAg-negative CHB who developed YMDD mutations. However, ADVϩlamivudine combination appears to confer higher antiviral efficacy and may prevent ADVresistant CHB.

back_matter.text: Background: The cumulative incidence of adefovir (ADV) resistant mutations in the nucleoside-treatment naive chronic hepatitis B (CHB) patients at weeks 48, 96, 144 were known to be 0, 0.8-3% and ϳ5.9%, respectively. The aim of this study was to analyze the incidence and clinical consequence of ADV-resistant rtA181V/T and rtN236T mutation in lamivudine (LMV)-resistant CHB patients who were treated with ADV. Methods: A prospective randomized study was conducted, recruiting 73 consecutive HCC patients undergoing TAC using combined epirubicin 50 mg/m 2 and cisplatin 60 mg/m 2 at monthly intervals. Patients were randomly assigned to receive lamivudine 100 mg daily before TAC (preemptive group) or not (control group). Hepatitis due to HBV reactivation was defined as a 3-fold or greater increase of serum ALT in patients with HBV reactivation (a 10-fold increase of viral load). Virological test was serially done at monthly intervals, and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level was measured at biweekly intervals. Results: During the study period, 11 (29.7%) of 37 patients in the control group and 1 (2.8%) of 36 patients in the preemptive group developed hepatitis due to HBV reactivation. There was a significantly more occurrence of hepatitis due to HBV reactivation in the control group than in the preemptive group (Pϭ0.002). In addition, moderate (ALT Ͼ2ϫthe upper limit of normal [ULN]) or severe (ALT Ͼ5ϫULN) grade of hepatitis of all causes were more frequently observed in the control group as compared with the preemptive group (51.4% vs. 27.8%, Pϭ0.040), irrespective of viral reactivation. There was a tendency towards more episodes of treatment disruptions in the control group than in the preemptive group (40.5% vs. 22.2%, Pϭ0.092). With multivariate Cox regression model, baseline HBV DNA level of Ͼ10 4 copies/ml was independently predictive of hepatitis due to HBV reactivation during TAC (Pϭ0.046).
