back_matter.text: The following authors have indicated they have no relationships to disclose: Jeong Jang, Jong Choi, Chang Kim, Si Bae, Seung Yoon, Jin Yang, Chang Lee, Young Lee, Kyu Chung, Hee Sun Background/Aims: Patients with chronic hepatitis B are being treated with Lamivudine (LMV) and/or Adefovir (ADV) whilst patients co-infected with HBV and HIV can be treated with LMV and/or Tenofovir (TDF) to control HBV replication. Resistance to ADV has been associated with three clusters of mutations, (i) D and A domains of the HBV polymerase (pol) which includes the mutation at rtN236T (ii) the B domain mutations at rtA181T/V and (iii) the C-D interdomain mutations rtV214A, rtQ215S which are distal to the active site. Resistance to TDF is associated with a mutation at rtA194T in the B-C interdomain region. The aim of this study was to determine the cross-resistance profiles of these mutations in vitro and analyse the molecular basis for resistance using molecular modelling. Methods: The ADV and TDF resistance HBV mutations were created by site-directed mutagenesis in an HBV infectious clone. In vitro phenotypic analysis of the HBV clones was performed by transient transfection in the presence of ADV, or TDF or LMV using standard techniques and the IC50 determined from doseresponse curves using Table Curve 2D Results: In vitro antiviral testing of the C-D interdomain HBV mutants demonstrated a 4 to 10 fold increase in IC50 to ADV consistent with drug resistance and also a 10 fold increase in IC50 to LMV. HBV encoding the TDF resistance mutation at rtA194T showed a 7 fold increase in IC50. Molecular modelling of the two groups of B-C and C-D interdomain mutations revealed that these mutations are in loop regions at the opposite ends of the beta sheets that encompass the YMDD loop region. These two interdomain regions appear to be involved in structural integrity of the polymerase active site even though they are not located within the nucleotide binding pocket, nor directly interacting with the DNA. Mutations in these regions can result in conformational changes within the active site, affecting the cross-sensitivity profile to a number of antiviral agents including LMV. Conclusion: We have identified two distal regions in the HBV polymerase within the HBV polymerase that are associated with potential multidrug resistance to the class of acyclic phosphonate nucleoside analogues such as TDF and L-nucleoside analogues such as LMV. Molecular modelling in association with in vitro testing can aid in determining the significance of mutations in the context of chemical class resistance and thus may aid in the choice of the next therapeutic agent.

back_matter.text: Background and Aims: Pharmacological stimulation of PPAR␥ attenuates liver fibrogenesis in animal models. Moreover, expression of PPAR␥ in vivo during liver injury appears to inhibit stellate cell activation and fibrogenesis. Here, we have hypothesized that depletion of PPAR␥ would exaggerate the fibrogenic response to liver injury in vivo. Methods: Wild type (WT) and PPAR␥ mutant mice (loxP sites were add to either side of exons 1 and 2 of the PPAR␥ gene) were subjected to bile-duct ligation or sham operation; adenovirus expressing cre-recombinase was injected through the portal vein. PPAR␥ was measured by immunoblot. Collagen I ␣1, TNF␣, and smooth muscle ␣ ␣actin expression were detected by realtime PCR and/or by immunohistochmistry of liver sections. Collagen content was assessed morphometrically and by hydroxyproline assay. The lipid peroxidation product, 4-hydroxy-2-nonenal (HNE), was detected by immunohistochmistry. Results: Infection of PPAR␥ mutant mice with adenovirus expressing crerecombinase led to reduction in PPAR␥ expression, as expected. Bile duct ligation-induced elevations in aminotransferases were similar in WT and PPAR␥ deficient mice. Ten days after bile duct ligation, PPAR␥ deficient mice had histologic evidence of inflammatory cell infiltration and severe septal fibrosis. In contrast, WT mice had minor fibrotic lesions, mainly in peribiliary areas. Collagen accumulation, assessed histomorphometrically and by measuring hepatic hydroxyproline content, was markedly lower in WT mice compared to PPAR␥ depleted mice (1.28Ϯ0.14 versus 1.89Ϯ0.21, PϽ0.03). TGF␤ protein and TNF␣ mRNA levels were increased in PPAR␥ deficient mice compared to WT mice, as assessed by ELISA and Realtime PCR, respectively. Moreover, immunohistochemical analysis revealed increased smooth muscle ␣-actin expression in PPAR␥ deficient mice. Finally, lipid peroxidation products were increased in PPAR␥ deficient mice compared to WT mice. Conclusions: PPAR␥ deficient mice exhibited enhanced oxidative injury, histological inflammation, and fibrosis after bile duct ligation induced liver injury. These studies further support an important role for PPAR␥ the integrated fibrogenic response to injury.

back_matter.text: Background/Aim: Recent studies have shown that hepatocyte growth factor (HGF) suppresses the progression of experimental hepatic fibrosis. However, it is not clear whether HGF has a direct inhibitory effect on collagen gene expression in activated hepatic stellate cells (HSC). In the present study, we examined the effects of HGF on alpha 2(I) collagen gene (COL1A2) transcription from the viewpoint of a signal cross talk between Smad3 and mitogen activated protein kinases (MAPK). Methods: Effects of HGF and specific MAPK inhibitors on COL1A2 transcription were examined in an activated HSC clone transfected with COL1A2 promoter/luciferase reporter constructs. MAPK phosphorylation and intracellular localization of Smad3 were analyzed by Western blot analysis and immunofluorescence study, respectively. To study the inhibitory actions of HGF on COL1A2 promoter activation in vivo, we generated double transgenic mice harboring albumin promoter/HGF and COL1A2 promoter/luciferase fusion con-structs. Results: HGF counter-suppressed TGF-beta-stimulated COL1A2 transcription in activated HSC. This inhibitory action was mediated through the -313 to -185 COL1A2 promoter sequence, where a Smad-binding element also existed. HGF administration caused a rapid phosphorylation of ERK1/2 and decreased the amount of Smad3 in the nuclei of activated HSC. Specific ERK1/2 signal inhibitors significantly increased COL1A2 transcription and enhanced nuclear localization of Smad3, whereas a specific p38 MAPK inhibitor markedly decreased gene transcription and suppressed intranuclear accumulation of Smad3. In the HGF-overexpressing transgenic mice, COL1A2 promoter activity, as well as endogenous COL1A2 mRNA levels, elevated following a single carbon tetrachloride injection was significantly suppressed as compared with the wild type littermates. Conclusion: COL1A2 transcription in activated HSC is under control of a reciprocal balance between ERK1/2 and p38 MAPK signals. HGF directly suppresses COL1A2 transcription, and this inhibitory action is exerted, at least in part, through a signal cross talk between Smad3 and MAPK.

back_matter.text: Cholestasis is occurred in a variety of clinical settings and often results in secondary biliary fibrosis. Several matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) are up-regulated in the cholestatic livers and believed to play a role of regulating extracellular matrix (ECM) degradation. MMP-13 is one of interstitial collagenases (ICs) and is a key enzyme for degrading fibrillar collagen. Recent studies have shown the function of ICs for reducing liver fibrosis. In these studies, genes coding ICs were administrated to fibrotic liver after the removal of fibrotic stimuli, resulting in the regression of liver fibrosis. However, the function of MMP-13 in the initial phase of liver fibrosis is still unclear. Aim: The aim of this study was to evaluate the role of MMP-13 during the development of cholestasis-induced liver fibrosis by using MMP-13-deficient mice. Methods: The wild-type (WT) and MMP-13-deficient mice were of a mixed 129/C57BL6 genetic background. Cholestasis was induced by bile duct ligation (BDL). Serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) was measured on day 5 after BDL. Neutrophil accumulation in the liver was evaluated by chloroacetate esterase staining. Transcripts of MMP-13, inflammatory mediators, and fibrogenic markers in the 5-day BDL liver were quantified by TaqMan RT-PCR. Collagen accumulation in 3-week BDL liver were evaluated by Sirius Red staining and hydroxyproline content. Activation and proliferation of HSCs were detected by immunohisotochemistory using anti-alpha smooth muscle actin and anti-desmin antibody, respectively. Results: The expression of MMP-13 mRNA increased significantly in BDL liver of WT mice. Liver fibrosis was suppressed in MMP-13 deficient mice versus WT animals after BDL for 3 weeks. Activation and proliferation of HSCs were also suppressed in the liver of MMP-13 deficient mice after BDL. To clarify the mechanism of this suppression, samples from 5-day BDL mice were used for evaluating liver injury. Compared with WT animals, the levels of serum ALT and the number of hepatic neutrophils were reduced in MMP-13-deficient mice. The increase in mRNA expression of inflammatory mediators was significantly suppressed in the liver of MMP-13-deficient mice. Up-regulation of fibrogenic markers was also significantly suppressed in the liver of MMP-13-deficient mice versus WT mice. back_matter.text: Methods: HSC were isolated from male rats, culture-activated on plastic and whole cell protein and total RNA extracted for 1-6 days. In addition, day 5 HSCs were incubated with LT-␤ (1ng/mL -316ng/mL), serum free, for 1-24 hrs. Whole cell protein was subjected to Western blot. RNA was subjected to quantitative PCR (qPCR) using SYBR green technology. LT-␤R knockout (KO) and wild-type C57BL/6 mice (WT) were fed a choline-deficient, ethionine-supplemented (CDE) diet for up to 14 days to induce liver damage, before livers were subjected to immunohistochemistry for ␣SMA expression. Results: qPCR and Western analysis of HSC activation demonstrated that LT-␤R was highly expressed in day 1 HSC and expression remained constant up to day 6. Day 5 HSCs incubated with LT-␤ for 3 hrs demonstrated significantly increased gene expression of ICAM1 and IB␣ (up to 12-and 8-fold vs controls, resp.), however no changes in ␣SMA or Collagen ␣1 (I) gene expression were observed. Following 7 days on the CDE diet (mild damage) the median ␣SMA immunohistological grading for both WT and LT-␤R KO mice was 1ϩ. On day 14 of the diet (peak damage) the median ␣SMA grade for WT mice was 3ϩ (Fig 1A) where as LT-␤R KO demonstrated significantly reduced ␣SMA expression with a grade of 1ϩ (Fig 1 B) .
back_matter.section: Aims: This study examined the expression of the LT-␤R on quiescent and activated rat HSC and the functionality of LT-␤ in terms of its ability to alter the expression of key fibrogenic markers.

back_matter.text: The following authors have indicated they have no relationships to disclose: Grant Ramm, Richard Ruddell, Belinda Knight, John Olynyk Most current animal models of hepatic fibrosis are driven from intermittent administrations of different hepatotoxins associated many side effects. We have developed an animal model of fibrosing steatohepatitis elicited by the transgenic protein without any complications. It was based on the conditional transgenic mouse in which expression of HCV core protein is regulated by the tetracycline-off system and liver-specific promoter. Matings were carried out with mice on doxycycline (dox)-containing chow, which fully suppresses core expression. HCV core protein was detectable in the liver of all lines but with variable expressing levels. Microvesicular steatosis was present and highly associated with core expression. Inflammation was minimal in the lines with extremely high and low expressing levels. In the lines with moderate core expression, however, marked inflammation and perisinusoidal deposition of extracellular matrix were detected accompanied by the activation of hepatic stellate cells as shown by staining fibronectin, collagen and alpha-smooth muscle actin (alpha SMA) in the liver. Furthermore, transforming growth factor (TGF) beta level in the liver correlated with both the core densities and inflammation degree. CD8 lymphocytes had been proved to be the predominant infiltrating inflammatory cells. By means of terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase mediated dUTP-biotin nick end labelling (TUNEL) staining and caspase bioassay, the apoptotic rates of the liver were found to increase significantly higher than that in the non-transgenic littermates. Oxidative stress evaluated by labeling the liver in situ with 8-hydroxydeoxyguanosine (8-OHdG), 4-hydroxynonenal (4-HNE), Malondialdehyde (MDA) and thioredoxin were also significantly higher and most positive stained-hepatocytes were nearby the inflammatory areas. It was found that the number of hepatocytes positive for HCV core decreased progressively over 2-8 months, so did the inflammation and fibrosis. Anyhow, by applying a cyclic induction-deinduction protocol of (dox)-containing chow administration, liver fibrosis re-occurred within a few cycles and progressed further when cyclic induction was continued. Conclusions: We have developed mice that are conditionally transgenic for HCV core protein. In addition to hepatic steatosis, the lines with moderate transgene expression revealed significant hepatic inflammation and fibrosis, which associated with predominant CD8 infiltration, marked apoptosis and oxidative stress elicited by the core protein. The diminution of both core protein and inflammation as time passing by could be reverted by applying the cyclic induction-deinduction of HCV core expression.

Montgomery Bissell Liver fibrosis is causally related to the activation of fibrogenic cells into myofibroblasts. This process is regulated by many biological molecules. Thrombin is the key enzyme of blood coagulation since it converts fibrinogen into fibrin. In addition, thrombin signalling via protease-activated receptor (PAR)-1 is profibrogenic in cultured myofibroblasts, whereas in vivo antagonism of thrombin or of PAR-1 is protective against liver fibrosis. Activated Protein C (APC) is generated from inactive Protein C (PC) when bound to the Endothelial Protein C receptor (EPCR) in the presence of thrombin bound to thrombomodulin. APC is the physiologic inhibitor of thrombin generation and could thus be considered as anti-fibrogenic agent. However, its overall effect can not be predicted since EPCR-bound APC also signalizes via PAR-1. The aim of our study was to investigate the role of APC on fibrogenic events in human liver myofibroblasts. Immunohistochemistry performed on fibrotic liver tissue showed that EPCR mainly localized to endothelial cells, as expected. However, a fraction of alpha-smooth muscle actin-positive myofibroblasts also expressed EPCR. EPCR expression was confirmed on cultured human liver myofibroblasts by RT-PCR and flow cytometry. Myofibroblasts also express PAR-1 and thus provide an adequate interface for APC signalling. The EPCR-PAR-1 complex was functional as evidenced by increased MAPK p42/p44 phosphorylation in response to APC; the effect of APC was maximal after 10 minutes of treatment and for a 100 nM concentration, reaching 311.3 Ϯ 47.2% of control values (p Ͻ 0.001). This was similar to the induction by 18 nM thrombin (406.1 Ϯ 88.1%). In contrast PC had no effect (106.2 Ϯ 17.8%) and induction by APC was not significantly modified by the addition of hirudin, a specific thrombin antagonist (269.8 Ϯ 40.1% stimulation vs 301.3 Ϯ 48.8%). Tissue inhibitor of matrix metalloprotease-1 (TIMP-1) is a major actor of liver fibrogenesis as it inhibits extracellular matrix degradation. TIMP-1 is secreted by myofibroblasts, and up-regulated during liver fibrosis. We show that APC increased TIMP-1 secretion in conditioned medium by 2.4 Ϯ 0.4 fold (p ϭ 0.04), similarly to thrombin (2.3 Ϯ 0.4 fold, p ϭ 0.05). Finally, using flow cytometry, we demonstrate that myofibroblasts also express membrane thrombomodulin and are able to generate low levels of APC from PC in the presence of thrombin. These data show that liver myofibroblasts are able to generate APC, and that APC has profibrogenic effects in cultured myofibroblasts. Ongoing work will indicate the precise in vivo function of APC in liver fibrogenesis.

back_matter.text: Background and Aim: In all types of liver injury, there is a complex balance between hepatocyte cell death, regenerative and fibrogenic responses. Activation of the IGF-1R signaling pathway contributes to the proliferation of hepatocytes during posthepatectomy liver regeneration. The aim of this study was to examine the role of IGF signaling on other aspects of liver tissue repair, i.e. hepatocyte cell death and fibrogenesis, using a conditional knockout mouse in which IGF-1R is deleted in hepatocytes. Methods: To specifically invalidate the IGF-1R in hepatocytes, mice homozygously floxed on IGF-1R alleles were bred with mice that expressed the Cre recombinase under the control of albumin promoter and ␣-fetoprotein enhancer (LIGFREKO mice). LIG-FREKO mice and control littermates underwent bile duct ligation (BDL) and were investigated 3 days later. Serum concentrations of transaminases (ALAT/ASAT) and of bile acids were measured. Histological analysis was performed on paraffine embedded, hematoxykin-eosin-stained liver sections and hepatocyte necrotic areas was measured by morphometric analysis. mRNA expression of ␣-smooth muscle actine (␣-SMA), collagen I and TGF-␤1 was quantified by real-time RT-PCR using Light Cycler technique. Results: No difference in ALAT/ASAT nor in bile acid concentrations was found in comparing LIGFREKO mice with controls. However, the LIGFREKO mice exhibited significantly less extensive parenchymal bile infarct and hepatocyte necrosis as compared to control mice. The expression of ␣-SMA, collagen I and TGF␤1 were also reduced by 40-50% in 3 days-BDL LIGFREKO compared with control mice. Conclusion: Our results show that the invalidation of IGF-1R in hepatocytes attenuates hepatic injury and the fibrogenic response induced by biliary obstruction.

back_matter.text: A reduction in expression/activity of endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS) in chronic liver disease will lead to depletion of nitric oxide (NO) causing vasoconstriction and reduction of hepatic blood flow and could accelerate fibrosis. The relationship between the expression of eNOS and fibrogenesis in the liver remains unclear. This study aimed to establish a possible pathway by which L-Arginine attenuates chronic liver fibrosis presumably via eNOS expression. Male ICR mice administered carbon tetrachloride (CCl4) for 8 weeks together with 5-methylisothiourea hemisulfate (SMT), an iNOS inhibitor, or L-Arginine, a NOS substrate were used to study the effect of NO inhibition and increased substrate provision on liver fibrosis. Blood and liver tissue were analyzed. RT-PCR, Western Blotting, EMSA, serum ALT and total 8-isoprostane measurements were performed. Sirius Red staining for fibrosis was quantified using image analysis. CCl4 induced hepatotoxicity and oxidative stress were shown by high levels of serum ALT, serum total 8-isoprostane and nitrotyrosine. Extensive accumulation of collagen in the liver tissue was confirmed by Sirius Red staining. The mRNA and protein levels of iNOS in the liver after CCl4 treatment were increased (p Ͻ 0.01) but eNOS was decreased (p Ͻ 0.05). Both SMT and L-Arginine effectively reduced CCl4 induced oxidative stress but L-Arginine showed a greater suppression of collagen formation (p Ͻ 0.001; TGF-B1, procollagen-I and Sirius Red staining) and of iNOS expression. Administration of L-Arginine restored the level of eNOS. NF-kB which regulates iNOS was upregulated (p Ͻ 0.05) in CCl4 treated mice. AP-1 which regulates eNOS was, in contrast, downregulated (p Ͻ 0.01) and both effects were reversed after treatment with L-Arginine. Our results showed that the administration of L-Arginine was more effective than SMT in the suppression of liver fibrosis although both drugs reduced the level of oxidative stress to the same extent. It is possible that L-Arginine, by improving production of NO, facilitates hepatic blood flow and thus retards the progression of liver fibrosis. This is supported by our observation that reduced eNOS expression in CCl4-treated mice was reversed by L-Arginine. Furthermore, L-Arginine also reversed the downregulation of AP-1, an eNOS promoter.
